SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.

This bill seeks to ensure that the Australian National Flag cannot be changed unless the people of Australia have been consulted and a majority of those voting indicate their support for a different design.

The government believes that the people of Australia are entitled to be consulted about their nation's symbols. Nowhere is this more important than with the Australian National Flag—our oldest and most important national symbol.
Our National Flag has a history which goes back to 1901 when its design was selected after a public competition which attracted over 30,000 entries.
The existing National Flag is declared in section 3 of the Flags Act 1953 and its design is reproduced in a schedule to the act.

Madam President, when the Flags Bill was introduced in 1953 it received enthusiastic bi‐partisan support. I trust that this bill, which gives legislative expression to the commonly held view that any change to the Flag is a matter for the Australian people, will receive equally enthusiastic support from all sides of the House.
I now turn to the details of the bill.

The bill does not seek to override the right of Parliament to legislate. Any new flag which might be chosen would become law by the action of Parliament. What this bill does say in subsection 3(2) is that the current National Flag shall only cease to be the Australian National Flag if a new flag is submitted in each state and territory to the electors qualified to vote for the election of members of the House of Representatives and is approved by a majority of all the electors voting.

Subsection 3(3) of the bill requires Parliament to prescribe the manner in which a proposal for any alternative design or designs for a new Australian National Flag should be submitted to the electors, the manner in which the vote is to be taken, and the arrangements that might need to be put in place if an alternative design is ever selected as a new National Flag.

The key intent of this legislation is to reflect the principle that the Australian National Flag belongs to the Australian people; and that the Australian people have the right to be consulted in any proposal to change the Flag. Of course, at any vote retaining the existing National Flag would be one of the options.
Madam President, this bill provides the Parliament with the means to give to the people of Australia, a guarantee that they will decide if the National Flag, their National Flag, should be changed.
It is a flag which was chosen by Australians, it is the flag the people of Australia have been united under since federation.
It has been the symbol of our nationhood and our community for five generations.
It is the only flag flown over a whole continent. It symbolises our history, our geography and our system of government.

It is the flag Australian men and women have served so well under in times of war. It is the flag under which we have claimed sporting glory. It is the flag under which this very Parliament meets‐it flies above this very chamber as a reminder of the sovereignty of the people.
We are committed to recognising that sovereignty by giving the Australian people the right to decide the future of their National Flag.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first day of sitting in 1997, in accordance with the order agreed to on 29 November 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the adjournment last night, Senator Cook was concluding his remarks on the running sheet at item 16, which is his amendments 71 to 73. He had put the very strong case on why we want to keep syndication as part of the R&D process in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite all the government rhetoric that this is a rorted system and is being abused, they have yet to provide evidence of examples where someone has got through the net and run a rorted syndication arrangement. We even had theoretical examples, rather than an actual case, earlier in the debate a few weeks ago. The government has not yet proven that to us or to the Australian people—or, above all else, to that very important segment of the Australian business community that is committed to R&D and is properly using syndication to make Australia more innovative and to produce value added products.

BREAK.PARA: We therefore strongly urge the Senate to support Senator Cook's amendments to keep syndication as a way of providing the funds to develop R&D in Australia in the private sector. If we do not have these procedures, we will actually reduce our ability to become a more innovative, more clever country.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens' support for R&D syndication has been put on the record. We will be supporting the move by the ALP to delete these sections of the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend Senator Cook's outstanding defence and his contribution throughout the estimates hearings on syndication. My own belief is that the government behaved badly, quite frankly, in pursuing this question of syndication rorts in the manner they did. Either there was a case to prove or there was not. In our mind, both in the parliamentary and public forums, they have not proven it and we had real misgivings about it.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the government did correctly pursue the issue of whether syndication is the most cost effective and appropriate mechanism. As you know from our minority report, we have some misgivings about that case. But we have decided on balance to support the government's view, and that is based on two conditions which we believe they have met. The first is a medium‐term commitment to START over a number of years and the second is the introduction of an amendment to prevent unfair retrospective conditions on the syndication.

These amendments ensure that all the applications that were in the pipeline before 23 July can be dealt with and are not retrospectively knocked out. This is not to say they will all be granted. We fully support the requirement that they have to go through a very tough, transparent process to see whether they are eligible to meet the rules. But we believe people who applied—lodged their applications—up until 23 July should have the right to have the matter heard under the existing rules.

I am surprised, because the Liberal government has always campaigned on the issue in its policy. One of the few principles it seems to argue is that it is totally opposed to retrospectivity. There is a strong element of retrospectivity when people lodge their application before 23 July and then get knocked over by the rules being changed. To use good old Aussie rules vernacular or metaphor, this is shifting the goalposts from one end of the ground round to the wing, or to the half forward flank, while the match is still in play. We do not believe that is fair, especially in the area of encouraging R&D in Australia. This amendment is about removing that aspect of retrospectivity.
I want to point out to the Senate that last year on 9 August, the now Deputy Prime Minister of Australia, Tim Fischer, wrote to a constituent when we were considering these issues. His reply was:

I carefully note the fundamentals involved with this important matter and I have to say that I am totally opposed to legislating retrospective detriments. My endeavours, deliberations and representations will continue on this matter in line with the aforementioned position.
Tim Fischer made it pretty clear what he thought about any element of retrospectivity.

One of the examples—I think this may have already been drawn to the attention of Senator Harradine—that will be knocked out if we do not get this amendment carried is an R&D project to apply to Gold Mines of Australia at the Mount Lyell mine in Tasmania. That is an R&D project of $14.9 million over a three-year period, leading to developing leaching techniques for extracting copper and copper sulfide ores. If that were successful, that would be a major boost to employment and economic development on the west coast of Tasmania—an area that we all know has got economic problems as far as employment opportunities for its people are concerned. These are the sorts of proposals this government is knocking over.

We have not heard any evidence that this particular application is a rort. One would have thought that something that encourages the economic development of the west coast of Tasmania would be a reasonably sound proposition. The technology may not develop; they may not be successful. It is not the point of the R&D program to try to predict beforehand in absolute terms whether it will be successful. It is to encourage people to get into the R&D so that there is a chance this new technology will help the economic development of Australia.

It is still not clear how many of the applicants will get through with the successful carriage of government amendment No. 15. The government is making a number of accusations that we want up to 120 applicants to go through. We would like the minister to give us an indication—for the public record—as to what the amendment does. The real reason we have proposed our amendments is that we do not think the Senate ought to support a proposal that knocks people out who apply before 23 July under one set of rules—that would retrospectively knock them out.

The Liberal Party have always argued very strongly that they are against the issue of retrospectivity. In this case, we are not talking about the bottom of the harbour scheme—which got the former Liberal Treasurer and now Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in a fair bit of strife with some Liberal senators many years ago. We are talking about an R&D program. The government has not shown any evidence that this is a bottom of the harbour scheme at all. Therefore, the retrospectivity element should not be proceeded with.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know whether this bill is aptly described as the gravedigger's bill, but that is the phrase that has got into the lexicon around this place. We announced on 6 December a measure as part of our innovation statement to chop out what is called gravedigging. We believe that was an appropriate decision to stop this process. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for debate has expired. The question is that the amendment moved by Senator Brown be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.

BREAK.PARA: Report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Kemp) proposed:
That the bills be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have my remarks on the previous amendment incorporated.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
Bob Brown's amendment
The Australian Democrats will be supporting this amendment.
It is important such information be readily available, especially if the program is to be adequately monitored.

I note that a few months ago I had discussions with Treasury officials. I asked them to provide me with a breakdown of information on which industry sectors were using the tax concession and a number of other questions on how the concession was being used.
I have still not had a response from Treasury. I think this reflects the Treasury influence on this debate in general.
If such information were readily available we would avoid such problems.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (BUDGET AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1996SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (FURTHER BUDGET AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (BUDGET AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1996
Consideration resumed from 12 December.
The bill.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The government amendments to this bill were originally circulated as requests. The government drafters appear to be persisting with the view that an amendment should be a request where it modifies a proposed reduction of expenditure in a bill but does not result in any increase in expenditure over the current legislation.

INTERJECT.PARA: As I have pointed out in other recent statements, this notion has not been accepted by the Senate and is contrary to the recommendations of both Senate and House committees which have reported on the interpretation and application of section 53 of the constitution. A statement made by the Speaker in the House of Representatives on 2 December this year indicates that the House of Representatives now agrees with the view expressed by the Senate. The proposed requests will therefore be treated as amendments, and the same will be done with any further requests of this type which are circulated by the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are in committee and I wish to make one short observation. If the department cannot get it right and if it cannot understand the rules in this particular area then in other areas they may indeed be quite wrong as well. We are being faced with the persistent attitude of the bureaucracy of drafting amendments contrary to the clear understanding of both houses of parliament. I am concerned about the accuracy of the body of material in the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —On this issue: I have had some dealings over the last few weeks in trying to resolve this impasse. I think it is fair to say that that is a matter that the Attorney‐General's Department is focusing its mind on as a result of a number of submissions, not the least of which have come from me because I believe that we are wearing out the granite between here and the House of Representatives more than is required because of this insistence. I assure Senator Harradine, you, Mr Chairman, and others who are interested in this so-called section 53 matter that the government is working very hard to try to solve this impasse so we do not have to keep having these statements every time this fight over requests and amendments is dealt with. I am spending a lot of time on this. Hopefully, when we come back in 1997 it will be resolved.
—I thank the parliamentary secretary for that.
—The question before the chair is that the bill stand as printed. Minister, do you have an amendment?
—No, Mr Chairman. In the interests of saving time, I will allow the other parties to start the running.

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. The usual approach in these matters is to deal with circulated amendments according to the running sheet. I know that Senator Newman is very inexperienced at taking a bill through committee, but could I respectfully suggest that you, Mr Chairman, indicate to her that it would be appropriate for her to move government amendment Nos 1 and 2 which seek to amend the commencement provisions. Perhaps if we progress through the bill in this way we might proceed more quickly.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the minister may not have had the running sheet at that stage. I think she does now.

INTERJECT.PARA: Amendments (by Senator Newman)—by leave—agreed to:
(1) Clause 2, page 1 (lines 10 and 11), omit subclause (2), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (2) Schedules 3, 6, 13, 14 and 22, Parts 1, 2 and 5 of Schedule 5 and Part 1 of Schedule 24 commence on 1 January 1997.

INTERJECT.PARA: (2) Clause 2, page 3 (line 1), after "20", insert ", Parts 3 and 4 of Schedule 5".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 2, page 1 (line 8), omit ", (7)".
(2) Clause 2, page 2 (line 8), omit clause (7).

The aim of these amendments is to get around the retrospectivity of the government's proposal with regard to compensation settlements. We are concerned that the new arrangements would mean that a compensation settlement made to people between the ages of 16 and 18 after 1 July 1995 would be taken into account after the passage of this bill in calculating the youth training allowance. It would mean a reduction in that allowance or potentially the removal of that allowance because of the past compensation payment.

BREAK.PARA: This is going to catch people out. It is going to mean that people who have budgeted on the youth training allowance, taking into account a compensation payment that has been made in the last couple of years, are suddenly going to find their budget does not matter. The government is going to reduce the training allowance according to a new formula and it is going to put people in extreme circumstances.

We had a debate here last night about retrospectivity. There was a strong feeling in this chamber that retrospectivity was not fair when it applied to people who had interests in mining. I do not think it is fair when it applies to young people who are living close to the breadline and who are dependent upon a budget that they have made out according to existing rules. We should not be allowing retrospectivity in this matter. Therefore, we have moved to do away with the government's proposal that the legislation be retrospective to 1 July 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hear what Senator Brown is saying, but the Democrats accept the undertakings given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and in the subsequent communications we have had with her office. We will not be supporting these amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments to be moved to this bill. For the information of honourable senators, this memorandum was circulated in the chamber on 3 December 1996.

—I would like to hear from the minister an explanation of this issue. The memorandum may have been circulated but it has not satisfied us. We are still concerned that this move is going to make changes to the allowances that people have budgeted for. It has an element of retrospectivity in it. The assurances that have been made on this matter have not satisfied us.

BREAK.PARA: I reiterate that there are a number of young people who are going to be affected by this. The minister might like to tell us the amount the government hopes to save by this measure. The committee would therefore be able to judge what the impact on people in the 16 to 18 age group is going to be as far as the delivery of the youth training allowance is concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I say on behalf of the opposition that I actually appreciate the concerns that Senator Brown raises about retrospectivity. It is an issue that has obviously been canvassed before in the Senate chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I also want to indicate that we recognise why the government is doing this. It is to line up compensation provisions in the Student and Youth Assistance Act with provisions in the Social Security Act. I think Senator Brown would be aware that they were introduced by Labor when we were in government.

I think it would be useful for the committee, given the comments that Senator Brown has made, if the Minister for Social Security was to repeat the assurances that she has indicated are in the supplementary explanatory memorandum. It would be useful for the minister to advise the committee on that and perhaps reassure Senator Brown on an issue that I am sure all senators would agree is an important one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the committee's attention to the fact that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee initially had some concerns about these measures. Having been a member of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, I well understand their important role in assessing such matters and their experience. I draw the committee's attention to the fact that the ninth report of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee dated 30 October 1996 stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The committee thanks the Minister for this response, noting that the retrospectivity of the amendments will not adversely affect any present recipient of youth training allowance and that it is not intended to revisit any decision made between 1 July 1995 and Royal Assent that might be affected by these amendments.
The impact of schedule 16, as originally introduced in the bill, not being taken to have commenced on 1 July 1995 would result in other previously made amendments continuing to be misascribed.

The undertaking given by me—that no-one will be adversely affected by the amendments taking effect from 1 July 1995—and the fact that the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills did not make any adverse comments on the retrospectivity issue means that the preferable outcome is to maintain the commencement date of schedule 16 as 1 July 1995 rather than agreeing to the amendments proposed by the Australian Greens. In direct response to the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner), I recommit myself to the assurances that have previously been given.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I have two difficulties. Firstly, the assurance from the Minister for Social Security is against the legislation. I would like the minister to say how her assurance is going to overcome the legislative retrospectivity—in other words, the fact that this is going to apply to young people as of 1 July 1995. How is the minister going to administratively overcome the legislative direction, if you like, that compensation payments since 1 July 1995 shall be taken into account in assessing a youth training allowance?

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the earlier question I asked was this: what is going to be the difference to the budget line of this measure? Has the minister or the department calculated that? Could the minister let the committee know if you have?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The advice I have from officials is that there is a general discretion already in this situation and minimal savings are expected as a result of this measure.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bill will be divided in respect of schedule 3 and the question will be that schedule 3 stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will oppose schedule 3. I did indicate at some length during my second reading contribution on this bill why the opposition will oppose this schedule and why we propose that it be omitted from the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact of the matter is that the government is proposing to introduce a youth allowance from January 1998. Effectively, that proposal would merge all forms of income support for young people. The proposal is that it be means tested on parents' income and that it cover young people who are aged between 16 and 20 years of age and students up to the age of 25.

The government has given commitments that it will consult on this proposal, and we accept that that is a proper course of action. It certainly requires a very significant degree of consultation because this proposal has very far-reaching implications for young people on their incentives to train and look for work.

This particular budget measure is one that received considerable scrutiny during our committee inquiry on the bill. In the opposition's minority report we pointed out that rather than prematurely legislate to bring social security payments to young people into line with Austudy it would be far more appropriate for these measures to be considered in the context of a broad community consultation process.

We have indicated our concerns now for a long time that abolishing the minimum rate of YTA and cutting off under 18‐year‐olds from payments on the basis of the parents' income really does open the door for this being the same situation for young people up to the age of 25 years. We think this measure is very premature.

As I indicated, I made some remarks during my speech on the second reading and I would be interested to hear what the minister has to say about the consultation process and about this pre‐emptive strike on young Australians, particularly—and this is a very important consideration for the committee—when we have the situation we do in this country in relation to youth unemployment and the unwillingness of the government and the responsible minister to set targets in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I move the Democrat amendment No. 1 in the sense that we will be opposing schedule No. 3. This schedule will abolish the minimum payment of $65.75 a fortnight for young people who receive the youth training allowance, the payment for young people or sickness allowance. The government says that this is in line with attempts to establish a common payments structure and there is currently no minimum payment available through Austudy. I point out that as a result of this change 1,800 young people will receive a reduced rate of payment while 3,900 young people will lose their payment entirely.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats agree with the need to push for a common youth payment. As a matter of fact, I can go back to 1984 when I was part of a group of consultants to all of the major churches in Australia and we produced a document called It's a Rocky Road. In that, we argued for a common youth payment. So I have been living with this idea for quite a long time.

What I say to the minister is that although we agree with that push for a common youth payment, we do not believe this should be undertaken simply by reducing the various payments to their lowest common denominator. I point out that despite the good news about unemployment yesterday—and it was good news to see a drop in the rate—the unemployment rate for young people still stands at 29 per cent. I know the government is not happy with that, but at the same time I want to say to the government that we really do not think that this reduction should happen while consultation is still being undertaken for this common youth payment. For that reason, the Democrats will oppose schedule 3.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true, as Senator Faulkner says, that we have been engaged in a substan tial consultation process around the country on the common youth allowance. I think it is fair to say that there has been little or no dissenting voice on the need for a common youth payment.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not just a common youth payment that people are concerned about; there is wide concern about the disincentives to young people that are currently perceived to be in the system in terms of whether they go into education or become unemployed. I think all of us in this chamber would be wanting to see encouragement of young people into education rather than any financial disincentive for that.

The situation with the common youth allowance proposal is that any change from that would not be implemented for some time and it would be unduly restrictive to suggest that no change should be made in any of these areas pending resolution of the wider reform directions.

The issue of whether payment to under 18‐year‐olds should be parentally income tested is not in question in the consultations. The change is consistent with the directions indicated in the youth allowance proposals, that is, to align payment conditions for students and the unemployed and to avoid disincentive to entering full‐time studies.

As far as whether it would lead to hardship for families is concerned—which, I believe, is behind the concerns expressed in the chamber this morning—it will affect only those families with income and assets above the parental income assets limits and only imposes the same limits as for Austudy. After all, if we are taking a decision to move to a common youth payment, it is surely appropriate that the same means test be applied to the 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds for both Austudy and youth training allowance.

Under the current arrangements and the proposed labour market assistance reforms, young people are eligible for priority assistance regardless of their income support status and specific programs or measures to improve school to work transition will also address that issue. So the concerns which senators may have on that score, I think, should be put to rest as well.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Woodley talked about the number of clients who would be affected by the proposal and I think it is important to recognise what the financial situation is for families. Currently, the minimum rate of $65.75 a fortnight is reached when parental assets exceed $393,750 and when parental income equals $30,435 per annum. Under this initiative, a nil rate of payment will be reached when parental income equals $37,273 per annum or parental assets exceed $393,750. As I have said already, the people who are disqualified from payment due to the initiative will still retain their entitlement to labour market support.

This measure is, as Senator Woodley points out, consistent with the common youth allowance and it is just not realistic to provide a minimum payment to all young people. The cost is very great. I am not aware of any key concerns in the consultations over the youth allowance with this particular measure and I would suggest to the Senate that their youth allowance should be no excuse for inaction now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I ask the minister, Madam Chair, what is the evidence of disincentives? Can she put it on the table?

—Speaking as a representative of an electorate, as you are yourself, senator, I would say that, over quite a long period now, I have had parents in particular but also some youth workers come to me concerned that we appear to be not treating young people in the same way and that, if anything, the incentive is towards unemployment rather than to education. While that can be just simply a perception, it is also borne out by the differential in terms of the way we treat the assessment of income and assets of the parents in both cases.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like something better than one of Senator Newman's homespun anecdotes on this.
—Homespun yarns.

—Homespun yarns. I thought you might be able to do a little better than someone who might have popped in to your office down in Tasmania, minister. So let us get real and see whether we can have an answer to the question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think there is any need for that language if we are trying to get this done in a civilised fashion. You would well realise yourself, if you spend a great deal of time in your electorate office, that that is a concern of many people. But, in addition—perhaps you are not interested in the remainder of the answer—those concerns were borne out in the consultations and those consultations ranged widely not only with parents but also with organisations working with young people. So it was part of the anecdotal evidence, if you like, given to the consultative process, but nevertheless valuable because after all the government is committed to involving the community in establishing this common youth allowance. And that was very clearly the concern of many organisations that consulted in this process.
—Is there any departmental work that Senator Newman can put on the table to support the position that she is arguing for in the chamber?

—I am advised that the difference in payments between the Austudy and the unemployment rates is the most frequently raised issue with the department. It is raised with them directly by the organisations that they deal with throughout the year, and again, as I said, in the consultative process. That differential is pointed to as a concern by many people and is in reports on this area of social policy. You either accept my advice, as I do, or you do not, that that is a continuing concern and has been for some time. It is not something that suddenly arrived with this government.
—I ask Senator Newman whether she can put any numbers on the table and perhaps just explain to the Senate what incentive would be provided by cutting kids off. Let us hear it.

—I think perhaps I should draw to the committee's attention that, over the years of the Labor government, they recognised that this in fact was a problem and over time they were bringing the rates closer together. They did not in fact achieve parity themselves, but that was the trend in their own administration.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Conroy interjecting—

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take Senator Conroy's interjection. I think it was another no; I think it was another non‐answer, minister. Can we have any numbers on the table and an explanation that I asked for in relation to what incentive would be provided by cutting kids off? That is the question I asked and I think it is reasonable to ask for an answer from the minister.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue is not whether you are trying to cut rates or whether you achieve something through cutting rates. The issue is whether you have a disincentive which can be redressed by treating all young people or families equally. Why would you endorse a situation which is continuing and which treats one group of families and young people more advantageously than another? Surely if you were wanting to do that you would be trying to make it more advantageous to encourage study.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry but I take issue with that. The issue is one of how much. I am not going to accept that these measures are simply for the good of the young or disabled people of Australia or whoever the measure is targeted at. We know, and the minister herself has repeatedly said in the Senate, that cuts by the government were necessary because of the $8 billion or $10 billion black hole, accept it or not.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a fiscal imperative. It is important for the committee to know what the government believes it is going to achieve by taking money out of the pockets of young people, as in this situation, by removing the minimal payment that they can get of $62.50 a week, and allowing some people to go to nil payments and others to go to smaller amounts than $62.50, which is not going to give them the independence they have under the current circumstances. It would help the committee during the next few hours if we could have a calculation on each of these items as to how much the government thinks the measures will save. It is an important part of the committee's ability to come to a decision.

The minister might take umbrage over this but the government is going to be working and has been working on saving money. Whichever way you look at it, saving money by the government in situations like this means taking money off potential recipients. The committee ought to have a clear answer. Last time we were told it was a minimal amount. I would have liked to have known what the minimal amount was that was being saved by the last measure. I do not think we can proceed just by knowing it is a big, small or medium sized amount. I would like to know the numbers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I well understand the value for the committee in knowing the savings on measures. I would point out that a number of measures proposed in the legislation cannot be said to be savings measures. The emphasis has very much been on trying to achieve simplicity in a very complex system, on treating people in like situations in the same way. This happens to be one of those measures which is treating people in like situations in the same way. We will come to others as we progress through the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I did mention earlier some of the figures as to the level of assets and income of the families we are talking about. There are not substantial massive savings in this measure because it is directed particularly at people on those higher income and asset levels who are currently ineligible for the Austudy assistance.

I will just take you through the cost of this amendment. The 1996‐97 savings are estimated to be $3.7 million. The following year they are estimated to be $8.2 million; the following year, $8.5 million, and the following year, $8.7 million. That should reassure you that this is not going to mean a massive effect on people across the board. It is very much targeted to making sure that the families who have substantial assets and reasonable incomes are all treated in the same way. They currently do not get that entitlement under Austudy and they would not get it under this proposal for the youth training allowance. I do not believe it is unreasonable. It is certainly not designed to be a massive producer of savings. Nevertheless, it is a worthwhile measure in terms of treating people in like situations in a like way. To me that is rational and fair.

It certainly is one step along the way to the common youth allowance which, as I have said, the consultations have demonstrated people very keenly endorse. I have had conversations with a number of organisations, as well as the formal consultative process by the department, and this is the direction in which people believe we should be moving—to have all youngsters treated in a similar way.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —If you are so committed to the community consultation process, could you explain to the committee why then you and the government are proposing this pre‐emptive change?

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I addressed that early on. It will be some time before the common youth allowance is in place. This is a first step in that direction. This is something which can be done now. It is totally consistent with the announcements that we made earlier this year. It is consistent with the proposals for future steps towards a common youth allowance which we will take into the community. There is nothing underhand and there is nothing that is inconsistent with that approach.
—Minister, could you explain what the timetable is for the consultations on the common youth allowance?
—The consultative process has been completed. The results are being written up now and they will come to government shortly, I understand.

—Minister, during the consultations that you and your department had on this matter what attitude did you take to this question? Is it not a fact that young people looking for jobs do in many cases have associated expenses which students do not have?

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand Senator Harradine's concern over this but I would suggest to him that while the students' expenses are not necessarily the same expenses, they also have the expenses of being a student. Travel is one, whether it is long distance or short distance. Travel is quite a considerable cost in anybody's budget these days, whether they are trying to find work or attending lectures. They have similar expenses that all young people have, but we are talking about young people here who are still of an age where they are being cared for by their families. They are surely in a pretty comparable situation. I do not really see it is necessarily so that looking for work imposes greater costs on a young person than attending full‐time studies.

—A YTA recipient needs to enter into a youth training activities agreement, so this was not a major issue in your consultations. Those, for example, who are looking for work at that age may indeed incur considerably more expenditure costs than those students on Austudy. So that was not an issue, was it?
—I am advised that in fact it was not raised at all by anybody, Senator Harradine.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, if the consultation process has been completed, which is what you advised the Senate just a few moments ago, why would you not see fit then to withdraw this schedule until we are all able to take account of the report on the consultation process? You perhaps could advise us whether you are planning to make that report available for public scrutiny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw Senator Faulkner's attention once again to the fact that his government over time was moving further and further in this direction itself. I do not see anything expressed in the chamber as to why this process should not continue.

SPEECH.PARA: For instance, you introduced closer rates for 16‐ to 17‐year‐olds, subject to means testing. You introduced 18‐ to 20‐year‐olds' new at home and away from home rates to specifically address these disincentive measures. So I question why it would be appropriate over time for you to do that and for this government to not move one step further.

As I said, it is not unfair. It is talking about people who have reasonably high assets and income. It is treating the children of students and those on the youth training allowance in exactly the same situation. I do not really understand why you have a problem with it. If you do, why did you not do something about the 16‐ to 17‐year‐olds who were on Austudy if you thought that was unsatisfactory?
As far as the consultation report is concerned, that will be a matter for cabinet to decide. As I say, we have not received it yet, so we have not had it before cabinet.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, thank you for answering a question I did not ask. Now let me make it a little clearer. Are you planning to make the report on the consultation process available for public scrutiny? Or are you seriously suggesting that is a matter for cabinet consideration and not a decision that is within the gift of the minister?

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you are misunderstanding, Senator Faulkner. This is not an issue just for the Minister for Social Security; it is a matter also for the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. This is across portfolios; the consultative process was run by both departments. The report will therefore come to cabinet and cabinet will make a decision both as to whether the report will be published and also as to its decisions taken on the basis of that report. I am sure that is the same procedure that would have happened under your government.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I ask Senator Newman whether she would be willing to give an ironclad guarantee to the Senate that any young person who is cut off will have access to whatever labour market programs are left under the policies of this government?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can give a guarantee to the Senate that the young people who are in this position will get the same labour market assistance as if they had been on the payment.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That schedule 3 stand as printed.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 5.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Schedule 5, item 1, page 15 (lines 13 and 14), omit ", or has lodged a claim for,".
(3) Schedule 5, item 2, page 16 (lines 7 and 8), omit ", or has lodged a claim for,".

This is obviously one of the most complex and, let us be frank, contentious schedules. I think there will be a considerable amount of debate around all parts of the schedule. I would like to make a couple of general points. I do not want to waste the time of the committee, because this is something that I have canvassed in the second reading debate and on many other occasions in the public arena.

It is important to make it absolutely clear at the outset of the debate on schedule 5 that the opposition does support tough measures with regard to fraud and compliance, although, of course, we do not believe people should be cut off from benefits without good reason. We do not believe people should be cut off from benefits for an inordinate or indefinite period of time. It is for these reasons that we have, in a general sense, some very serious concerns about measures contained within this schedule. It is for that reason that we are proposing amendments to address them.

I can say that we genuinely believe that the proposed activity test regime is one that is excessively harsh. It is unreasonable—particularly in the absence of any measures from the government to assist unemployed people returning to the work force. We really believe that many aspects of this proposal are unworkable. We believe they will very unfairly penalise genuine job seekers, honest job seekers. We do not believe, as the government seems to, that it is the intention of nearly everyone on unemployment benefits to defraud or rort the social security system. We believe the vast majority of those people are genuinely looking for work and warrant the support of government in the difficult circumstances they find themselves in.

Part 1 of schedule 5 of the social security bill tightens up the use of employer contact certificates. We believe that it is unreasonable to require completed employer contact certificates to be provided with an initial claim for unemployment payments. Our amendments ensure that the employer contact certificates can continue to be utilised, but not until a person is actually receiving a payment. I commend the opposition's amendment to part 1 of schedule 5 to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens oppose the employment contact certificates. I draw the committee's attention to the fact that our amendment that is coming next would get rid of this pretty iniquitous system. The employment contact certificates are a means whereby people when they go to employers—this is selected people—have to get that employer to fill in a certificate to say they have been, they have applied, they have made contact but they have not got the job.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem with it is that it not only annoys the people who have to get the certificates filled in but also annoys employers right round the country. It is a particular impost on small businesses. There is no requirement for the employer to fill in the certificate. So the young person—or the old person for that matter—or whoever it is who is unemployed can go to an employer, can go to a series of employers, to get these certificates filled out to show that she or he has been there, only to have the employers refuse to fill them in.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is better than the present system, though.

—I think the present system is bad enough. It should be revoked as well. The problem is that some employers will find themselves with a queue at the door, with a big lot of certificates to fill out. Other employers might be amenable to this, but some will simply say no. So through no fault of their own, the hardship falls on the people who are trying to find a job.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no research to show that these certificates help people find work. There is plenty of anecdotal evidence to show that it is quite the reverse. It becomes an impediment to people finding work. The employers get upset because they have to fill in these certificates. They are sick of being a statistical piece of evidence for the government, and they simply get their back up. It provides an obstacle to the person who is applying for the job: the employer is annoyed at the outset if the person appears with a certificate.

What is worse is that the certificate brands the person who is coming up for a job. The employers know that these people are, in some way or other, under special surveillance by the government. So they say, `Hello. Here is somebody with a certificate. I have to watch out here. This person has not been too good at finding a job. I will short cut the whole process of giving a fair interview and giving them a fair go and show them the door. If I feel it is a bad day, I am not going to fill in these certificates.' So they would have wasted their morning, blighted their hopes a bit more, demoralised them a bit more and sent them back to try to explain to the employment office how come they haven't got a certificate filled in. It is a really nasty little system and it is very unfair.

Now the government wants to allow this system to be put onto anybody who comes through the door. Until now, there has at least been some check on it whereby people had to be, in the view of the secretary at least, not doing too well in getting a job. The department might have thought they were not being assiduous enough in finding a job and said, `Get some certificates filled out so that we know you have been to the employers.' Now that is no longer required. So there will be persons who can be, and will be, I think, inevitably, punished on appearance—on how they look, on how they walk through the door—

TALK.START.PARA: —How they purposely look, too.

—Senator Panizza says, `How they purposely look.' Just let me take that up for a second. On that ground, you want to interject: `Everybody purposely looks the way they do.' The discrimination that you are showing towards people who do not look the way you want them to look is exactly the point I am trying to make.
—Is that the official government position?

—It is. He is there as Government Whip saying, `These people look the way they want to look.' He wants them to look the way he wants them to look, to clone them. Of course that is the attitude that the government wants to see here.
—Ask the minister if that is the official government position.
—Ask the minister.

—I certainly would like, in view of Senator Panizza's interjection, to ask the minister: will appearance be taken into account? If appearance is not taken into account, what are the parameters that will be used for people who have a reasonable record on all other scores? Crikey!

SPEECH.PARA: Let me go a little further while I am on my feet. We were discussing here last night the rebates given to companies involved in research and development. What we discovered is that those rebates, to the tune of some $3.5 billion a year, come without government assessment. So the government is handing over $3.5 billion without a requirement for assessment to the rich, to the corporate sector.

But when it comes to kids going to get a job it says, `Get a certificate filled out. We want accountability for you that we do not apply to the people getting research and development funds.' Just a while ago—and I must not reflect on a vote—the committee disagreed with a move from the Greens to at least have some basic accountability about how much the corporations are getting in terms of their cut out of that $1.2 billion a year.

Let us look at the diesel fuel rebate—$753 million this year. Some corporations like BHP are getting $100 million. Where is the accountability there? It is simply a cheque given to these corporations on request. It can be checked on, but it does not have to be up front. We have not seen that legislation in here. So there is an amount of some billions of dollars being given to the corporate sector that does not require the certification that is being used on these people down on their luck in our community.

They are double standards of the worst sort. It is not just a case of having to appear dressed the way that Senator Panizza might want people to be when they come through the door to assess whether or not they are going to get the requirement for employment contact certificates foisted on them in a discriminatory fashion. Every one of those folk know that there are big corporations that are not required to provide such evidence of their bona fides when they put out their hand for a multi-million dollar tax rebate.

It is an unfairness that reeks. The Greens are totally opposed to it. Let us have a bit of fair handedness here. This employment certificate scheme is wrong, is punitive and actually gets in the way of many people getting work. I would like to ask the minister what evidence she has that it works. How much does it cost to administer this scheme? How much does it cost employers around the country who are diverted from their otherwise productive works to either fill out these certificates or decide they will make it harder for jobseekers by refusing to fill them out?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to go back to the previous question that is on the running sheet. I think we are going to deal with Senator Brown's amendments separately. I would like to indicate that the Democrats' amendments 2 and 3 are identical to the Labor Party's amendments 2 and 3. So, clearly, I am not going to press mine but I support the Labor Party's amendments. I certainly do not want to hold up the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Just let me make some brief comments. These amendments deal with part 1 of the bill and they will clarify some of the provisions relating to employer contact certificates. If you can fix up employer contact certificates, we would like to try to do that—at least make them a little less severe. That is why we have moved this amendment ourselves and now support the Labor Party amendment.

We have great concerns over the use of employer contact certificates just in principle. But we will not be opposing this path as it does have some beneficial aspects to its operation. We are concerned, however, that if employer contact certificates must be used, then they should only be issued to people whom the department has good reason to believe may not be undertaking sufficient job search. As such, we believe it would be inappropriate to impose these requirements on a person who has simply lodged a claim for newstart. The amendments, therefore, simply remove the words `or has lodged a claim for' from this part 1.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of issues here. I have a brief story from when I was in Carnarvon, Western Australia, which is an area where there are times of the year when there are few jobs and times of the year when there are jobs picking and so on, with not a lot of other choice in other parts of town. However, young people go to growers and say `Have you got a job available?' One grower said, `Look, I get sick of them coming and asking me. I have told them if they come and ask me I will charge them $5 a time.'

SPEECH.PARA: That, obviously, is not allowed, but it is an indication that there are people who do refuse because it is annoying, and that was even under the existing scheme which is not as onerous as what the government is suggesting now. Basically, it gives you an idea of what the feeling is in the community and in a community where there is this definite gap. There might be seasonal employment at some time of the year and very little at other times of the year, and the continuous requirement to get these statistics will get up everybody's nose in the end. I do think it is counterproductive.

I do not know whether that kind of response—asking for $5 to sign it—is out of the ordinary, but I know that it happens. I know that there are many areas in Australia, because of various issues to do with pulling out training and capacity to benefit, where the cumulative effect will be ghettos of unemployment and ghettos of non‐assistance from government. It will be made worse by what appear to be requirements to fill out forms in a certain way which may, in fact, in some areas of Australia, be impossible to fill.

I remember asking questions in estimates in relation to some of these changes. I asked a public servant whether or not he could foresee a time when we would have mini‐Brixtons throughout Australia. The public servant replied, `Senator, I understand what you are saying, but that was during a time in Britain of great social turmoil.' Well, yes.

So, basically, here we are creating a worse situation. We are blaming the young person—this is part of what is happening—by saying obviously it is their fault they are not employed.We are using statistics and bureaucracy to justify draconian situations, just like Senator Newman came in here not too long ago with statistics showing how many people the government had thrown off benefits. It would be really interesting to know exactly how many of those people were thrown off on technicalities—for not filling out their form right or getting it in an hour late or a day late or for various reasons—just so that the government could get some good statistics which showed that, say, $15 million was saved in some particular program—$15 million worth of suffering. I think that is the kind of thing we are being asked to support in the government's proposals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to what has been said. I, too, believe that the amendment put forward by Senator Faulkner and Senator Woodley should be accepted. I do not agree that if a person has merely applied for the newstart allowance, then that person should, presum ably before they are accepted, take reasonable steps to apply for a particular number—we do not know how many—of advertised jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: It is presumptive and pre-emptive of the department to extend this to those who have applied for newstart. I think that you are going to find also that a number of people will just fall between the two stools. In other words, a number of people who are initially quite timid and diffident about going out looking for jobs may well be picked up by the department when the application is made.

Those people can be trained, but why should they have to wait? It is assumed, I imagine, Minister, that they will not be getting the newstart allowance until they have satisfied the department as to the number of ECCs that they have got. I repeat: I am supporting the amendment. I again suggest that this measure is pre-emptive and presumptive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there are some misconceptions in the comments that have already been made. Therefore, while recognising that there does not seem to be support on the face of it for these proposals, I would like to put on the record that in fact there is a beneficial part of the proposals which seems to have been overlooked.

SPEECH.PARA: The employment contact certificates are currently issued to some newstart and youth training allowees to provide evidence that they have applied for work. The certificates have to be signed by an employer who has advertised a job vacancy. If a person does not return them completed and has no reasonable excuse, they may not be paid for two weeks or more. That is the current situation. That means that a person who does not comply with the requirement and who does not satisfy the activity test is therefore subject to a non-payment penalty.

The provision seems to operate irrespective of whether people have made reasonable efforts to apply for advertised work but, for one reason or another, cannot get an interview to have the ECC completed. Our amendments will remove the ambiguity in the existing legislation to ensure that the ECC provisions do not disadvantage or result in penalties for genuine job seekers.

That problem has been highlighted by other senators and our proposals will go some way towards addressing it. Although the government believes that people who are not genuine about looking for work should be penalised, it does not consider that such penalties should be imposed where there are legitimate reasons for not being able to meet the administrative requirements and the person is otherwise genuinely meeting those requirements.

A number of other matters have been raised, particularly by Senator Brown, which it might be more appropriate to deal with when his item comes before us. Perhaps some senators are not aware that the department already has the administrative ability—not exercised constantly but available to be exercised—where a person appears to have had an unsatisfactory work record in the past, to require an employer contact certificate to be obtained by the person applying for benefits. That is administratively in place now; that happens when it is deemed necessary. We propose to enshrine that ability in the legislation. That is the sort of circumstance in which this provision would be used.

Therefore, both the Australian Democrats' and the opposition's amendments restrict the department in an area where you would expect the department to be vigilant about somebody who has had an unsatisfactory work record in the past. The department has a duty, at the same time supporting those who are in need, to protect the revenue. I would see this provision as a proper exercise of that responsibility; that where they are aware of somebody's unsatisfactory work record, they would require this ECC to be obtained if it is reasonable in the circumstances to obtain it.

The department can do that now, administratively. We are asking the Senate to endorse that ability through the legislative process. I would urge honourable senators to reconsider what I think is a not unreasonable proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like the minister to tell the committee the administrative costs of the employer contact certificate scheme, and what they will be after these proposed changes. The minister and I had a good meeting, for which I thank her, a week or two ago. One of the things that came up was the costing of administration within the department, which was of concern to the government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Greens want to do away with these certificates. We believe that they are costly to administer. We have seen no evidence to show that there is a cost benefit to the government's proposals. I wonder what is driving the minister if there is no cost benefit.

I have figures that show that these and other government amendments will save the government $260 million over three years. I do not know what component of that money comes from this particular proposal, and I would like to know that. I think we also should know what the administrative costs of this scheme will be because, obviously, there will be an increase. Secondly, I would like to know what evidence the government has of the cost to the business sector of filling out or deciding not to fill out these certificates?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Those are the matters I was referring to when I said earlier that I was proposing to address certain matters when we came to Senator Brown's amendment. I am happy to address them now, if it helps.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know whether I can provide Senator Brown with the figures he is asking for at the moment. Already I have been advised that there is a minimal administrative cost with the ECCs because they are issued and returned with the regular fortnightly forms. The scheme works to allow job seekers to confirm their job search efforts.

As for the employers, I understand that representatives from leading employer organisations have stated publicly that they do not believe that the changes will result in a considerable burden to employers. The secretary to my department has written to major employer organisations detailing the changes to the activity test and requesting their support for the measure.

BREAK.PARA: In addition, I point out that the employer contact units, set up, firstly, in Tasmania and now in operation around the rest of the country, are bringing in thousands of calls from employers who find it an easy, low cost way to deal with the department on a range of issues. Some might be formal matters, others just inquiries, while others alert the department about people you could call `work shy'.

Employers' needs and the cost of doing business with government were very much taken into account in the introduction of those employer contact units. The employer contact certificates are not used indiscriminately. They are used particularly where people are seen to be at risk of not pursuing job opportunities. That is not the only situation. Over the years statistics have found certain people, particularly young people, are a vulnerable part of the community, and where such groups are identified the certificates will be introduced.

I do not know whether I have the information Senator Brown requested. I have not mentioned the problem of employers refusing to sign; I can say that our amendment addresses that problem. The current legislation provides that allowances be cancelled if people cannot get certificates completed. Our changes allow that, provided people attempt to get them signed, they would not be penalised. Those are the sorts of reasons I believe it is appropriate to pass the government's proposals.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask Senator Newman very quickly whether she could indicate clearly to the committee what savings would flow from the adoption of part 1 of schedule 5, tightening up the use of the employer contact certificates.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that there would be no savings flowing from this particular employment contact certificate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Then again, I would like to know why the administrative costs are minimal. I found on one other occasion it was, I have forgotten, either $9 million or $13 million, so it would be good to know what the administrative costs are on this particular occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, how many people are affected by the current requirements for filling out these certificates in a given year? How many more will be affected by the government's increased requirement for employment contact certificates to be returned to the department?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not want Senator Brown to think that I was trying to get away with only describing things as minimal. Where I can tell you precisely, or to the best advice we have, I will do so.

SPEECH.PARA: The advice I have as to this question is that it is not possible to disaggregate this particular element of administrative savings from the totality of the administrative savings in this section, Senator Brown. So I am not trying to evade the issue, I just cannot tell you as to the proportion that is applicable to the employer contact certificates.

In terms of the number of people, we do not have reliable statistics—I give that proviso—but we believe that it is in the order of 50,000 people a year currently affected by these certificates. We would expect that to increase in the order of 50 per cent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —So 25,000 extra people in a year are going to be required to line up probably to the same employers—probably increasing the employers' frustration—at cost to both small business and the government in terms of administration. It does not seem to be a very smart way to go. It is punitive on unemployed people in this country whom the minister might—I do not—see as work shy. We are in a country where there are far fewer job vacancies than there are unemployed people, and I think those unemployed people have really drawn a short straw.

SPEECH.PARA: However, can the minister remedy this situation? We are not getting information on this, but can she remedy the situation by giving a commitment to the committee that by the estimates of next year an audit will be done to see what the cost of administering this scheme is and what the number of people who are involved is—that should be statistically easy? Also, the more difficult one, but it is important, what is the cost to the business community of this scheme?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am perfectly prepared to give the commitment as to the departmental role. It will be harder to achieve the second part of your question because I think it will be quite difficult to get any figures that are really reliable from the business community as to the cost. But, in that I said to you the business community had already indicated to the department that it was not unhappy with the activity test measures that were coming forward, I would expect there would be cooperation, where it was possible, from employers in trying to get that information, which we might be able to make available in the estimates.

SPEECH.PARA: I just do not feel I can give you a cast iron guarantee as to the involvement of the business community. As you would be aware, the department is not going to be able to get that information from its own sources; it would rely on others to do it. To the extent that we could, we would. As far as the cost of the matter in the department and the numbers involved are concerned, yes, I am happy to ask the department to do that work and have it made available to the estimates committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I look forward to that, Minister. I wonder also whether the department might break it into its regional components when it does bring that forward.
—Yes, of course.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Schedule 5, Part 1, page 15 (line 7) to page 16 (line 24), omit the Part, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Part 1—Repeal of certain provisions relating to employer statements

PARA.TAB: Repeal the subsections.
Repeal the subsections.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment from the Greens is to do away with these employment contact certificate schemes. I will not go into this at length, but I just reiterate that we believe they punish people unnecessarily, they are a great administrative burden both on the government and on small business and they lead to people who have difficulty finding a job being confronted by angry employers who do not want to waste their time filling out certificates. It is then up to the person to go back to the employment office and explain why she or he did not get a certificate filled it. It demoralises people. It is an impediment to people getting jobs, and the money could be much better spent on initiatives directly aimed at creating jobs.

The other point that I made earlier, and I just reiterate, is that, in a way, this is a forced self-assessment scheme on people who do not have jobs, but the government does not insist on the same sort of assessment for people getting millions of dollars in tax rebates—mining corporations, other big corporations involved in the self-assessment to get research and development returns. The unemployed people have to get the assessment, if you like, from a prospective employer they do not know and may never see again and who can just make life difficult for them because it is annoying the employer.

So we oppose this system. I think Senator Margetts gave an extremely good example of how it is readily abused and can cause great heartache to people unnecessarily. The money should be spent elsewhere.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will be opposing the amendment moved by Senator Brown. We do not support a proposal that would repeal all provisions requiring people to state the details of jobs applied for and providing what we think is appropriate evidence of that to the Department of Social Security. I indicate on that basis that we will be opposing the amendment. We certainly accept the principle of this provision. It is reasonable. It does not place unreasonable demands on people. That is why the opposition sponsored the amendment that I moved a short while ago. I see no reason to support this amendment. The opposition will be opposing it.

—The amendment does not get rid of all checks and balances. The minister mentioned that there is already the ability administratively for the department to do those checks. This amendment will give less choice to the people in the bureaucracy. Next time the minister wants a purge perhaps we will have more figures of people who she can throw off and then she can say, `Aren't we making good savings.' It is not a matter of there being no ability to check people's work records. That already exists and the minister has said so herself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the chamber needs an explanation from the Democrats as to why we will support the amendment moved by the Greens. It does seem to fly in the face of the previous amendments which were passed. The previous amendments tried to make a bad system a little better. That is why we moved those amendments. In fact, we do not agree with the system at all. We have real problems with the use of employer contact certificates.

SPEECH.PARA: The Welfare Rights Centre, in a recent submission to the community affairs committee, said that there is no evidence to show that these certificates actually help people to obtain work and that they may be the kiss of death to some people's chances of getting a job. That is because when someone presents with a employer contact certificate, the employer says, `Here is someone who is already under a cloud. Therefore, are they the kind of person I want to employ?' Although we admit that there are perhaps some beneficial elements to the certificates, on the whole the negatives far outweigh the positives. For that reason we will support the amendments moved by the Greens.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Brown 's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it might be useful if I moved opposition amendments 4 to 13 inclusive on part 2 of schedule 5.
—No, we cannot do it that way. Senator Faulkner, are you suggesting that we look at items 3, 4, 6, 7 and 9 together?
—No, I am suggesting that opposition amendments 4 through 13 inclusive relate to part 2 of schedule 5 of the bill. I am just trying to assist the committee, and I think this is a sensible way—
—I'm just trying to follow what you're trying to do.
—We really are better following the running sheet, because some involve opposing items and some are amendments.

—I am having a close look at the running sheet to find the amendments relating to part 2 of schedule 5, which are opposition amendments 4 to 13 standing in my name. This would assist the committee, would it not?

—I am advised that you cannot do it that way because No. 6 on the running sheet is part of amendment 4, No. 7 is part of 4, No. 8 is part of 5 and Nos 11, 13 and 14 are over the page. It would be quicker to do them as we are going through because they are all part amendments. That is the advice I am given.

—Can I support the chairman on this. I do recall that, when we debated the migrant waiting period bill in the way you are suggesting, we ended up with some terrific problems about consequential amendments and things later on. If we stick to the running sheet, we would know where we are at least. But thank you for trying to speed it up.
—I understand what you are trying to do, Senator Faulkner, but I think this is the only way we can do it because the amendments involve parts.

—If it would help the committee—I know that starting a sentence with that statement often means the opposite—I would be prepared to indicate that the Democrats will oppose item 3 of schedule 5, which is part of our Democrat amended No.4 and the same as opposition amendment No. 4. The Democrats will oppose item 3 of schedule 5.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will assist the committee also, Mr Chairman, by addressing part 3 of schedule 5 and oppose, in accordance with—
—Senator Faulkner, can I suggest that you can speak to them all but we will need to put them separately.

—I appreciate that, Mr Chairman. I think this is one of the key measures that we have before us: extending the penalties for breaches of the activity test to six weeks for the first breach and 13 weeks for the second and subsequent breaches. The activity test regime that we introduced while in government is, I think, a tough one.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Chairman. I think that Senator Faulkner is ahead of himself. I think this should be on what is unsuitable work.
—Thank you, Mr Chairman. If we are on suitable work, let us deal with that. That is schedule 5 part 2. Are you still assisting the committee, Senator Woodley?
—Yes.

—I am really pleased to hear it. In relation to this issue, the opposition has argued that the government has introduced a new—but, we say, extreme—definition of unsuitable work. The new definition puts the onus on job seekers to negotiate and overcome issues that might make a job unsuitable.
