SPEECH.PARA: We believe that it is unreasonable to compel job seekers to undertake any work offered where there is no training provided and where they lack the qualifications, the skills or experience necessary to provide proof of an attempt to rectify a situation with the employer where the work conditions constitute a risk to health or safety, to become self‐employed or to move away from their home and community to look for a job which might not exist.

The opposition says that these measures place unreasonable obligations on job seekers to negotiate with prospective employers despite not having the requisite skills, the knowledge, the capacity and the confidence to do so. It is for that reason that the opposition is seeking to omit large parts of the schedule in accordance with the approach that is outlined in the running sheet that we have before us.

We do concur with the government—I indicated this, I think, very clearly in my speech on the second reading—that it is unreasonable to compel a person to enlist in the reserve forces as part of taking up a job offer. We certainly support the government on that issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —What we are doing is simply having to take pieces out of amendments 4 to 13 of the Democrat amendments, which are the same as the Labor Party amendments 4 to 13 in numbering, so that we can deal with them logically. What I want to do, to save the committee time, is to speak to all of my amendments 4 to 13 in a comprehensive speech now.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments 4 to 13 deal with activity test and penalty periods. We have a lot of concerns about what the government is proposing. The government proposal seeks to clarify the meaning of unsuitable work for the purposes of the unemployment activity test. That clarification will be done through a number of measures. We will be supporting some of those measures but opposing others, as indicated by Senator Faulkner.

One measure that we simply cannot support will give the department the power to require someone to move to another town to take up what the department believes is suitable work. If implemented, this provision may force people to choose between their house and their unemployment payment. The Australian Democrats believe that there can be no justification for putting people in this position. I thought I would give the committee a real example. It is one that happened in Queensland during the drought. Some people had a property at Bollon, which is between St George and Cunnamulla and is hundreds of kilometres from Brisbane.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the middle of nowhere.

—It is in the middle of nowhere, but it is a very nice part of the country nevertheless. They have three sons. Because it was in the middle of that incredibly severe drought in Queensland, the three sons, of their own volition, moved to Toowoomba to seek work. They got to Toowoomba and, for months, were still on the unemployment benefit because there was no work in Toowoomba. They wanted to return home so that they could at least assist their parents on the property in the middle of the drought in a terrible situation. They were unable to do so because of this measure, which was in place under the previous government.

SPEECH.PARA: This government is going to make it even worse. As I can show with that example, the anomaly was imposing an incredible hardship on people who themselves had moved because they really wanted to find work. But after months of being unsuccessful, they wanted to move back home. Because of these kinds of measures, they were unable to do so. That gives the committee an example of the kind of hardship that these provisions will impose. The government wants to make it worse.

A second measure will, in circumstances where an employment environment may constitute a risk to safety, require a job applicant to try to convince the prospective employer to rectify the situation. Have you ever heard of anything more ridiculous than that. If Senator Bob Collins were going to employ me in Darwin and there was something about the employment which I found to be quite out of the question, then, although he is a very kind-hearted person, I am not sure he would be willing to listen to my proposition as a condition of his employing me. It is a hypothetical situation, but nevertheless a real one.

PARA.BREAK: The Democrats, along with a number of groups that provided submissions to the community affairs inquiry, believe that this measure totally misunderstands the relationship between employers and job applicants. In particular, it will place too onerous a burden on job applicants who lose their unemployment payment if they fail to meet this require ment. The Democrats will be opposing the items of this part, as indicated in our amendments numbered 4 to 13. We will be doing so in the short steps indicated by the running sheet.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to draw the attention of the Minister for Social Security to item 4. I would like particular clarification of it, because it seems a fairly harsh and oppressive addition to the existing section 601(2A). It says that no training will be provided by the employer. Could you give me some idea of the training that is envisaged under this section? It is repeated elsewhere as well. Is it based on competency based training or employer sponsored or established training? What type of training are you talking about? Depending upon the answer you give, I may well have a further question on that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hogg is obviously not certain. He has asked me a question, so I will give him the answer.
—That was close.
—Yes. As I understand your concerns, it is whether it is appropriate training. Am I misunderstanding you?

—That is not my concern. My concern is whether it is competency based training. What sort of training are we talking about? Many employers will dream up their own training scheme. They may have dreamt up their own mickey mouse training scheme. Because this is now a provision under your bill, you would find that people who present themselves may well be excluded from the newstart allowance?

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of this is that if somebody goes to an employer and clearly does not have the skills, experience or background for the job, they have an opportunity, and it is reasonable for them, to ask whether they will be trained so as to be able to do the job. If the employer refuses to give them training appropriate to what is needed for that job, they have a reasonable excuse for not taking up that job. Does that deal with your concern?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem is that the employer will contrive that there is training when, in effect, there may well be no training for that person in the first place. That will exclude them from the job. The words `no training will be provided by the employer' must be added to these other words that already exist in the act:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . particular paid work is unsuitable for a person if and only if, in the Secretary's opinion:
(a) the person lacks the particular skills—
I can accept that—

PARA.TAB: experience or qualifications that are needed to perform the work.

SPEECH.PARA: Instead of the `or', you want to insert `no training will be provided by the employer'. Once you put that additional clause in there, that additional requirement means that if the employer provides training, regardless of its quality and quantity and whether the person is still unsuited for the work, they are going to find themselves excluded under this provision, as I read it. That is repeated elsewhere throughout the act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, the advice that I have been given is that the secretary has a discretion in this area, as you would realise. It will be up to that discretion to determine whether the person has lacked the particular skills, experience or qualifications they need to perform the work and, as a consequence of that, whether the training offered is inappropriate to achieve those. That would be within the realm of the discretion of the secretary.

SPEECH.PARA: You have a very legalistic approach to this which would not be the way a tribunal would look at it. The very essence of a tribunal's ability to range over these sorts of issues means that it would not be read in a constrained way. It has very much the opportunity to look at the reasonable doubt for the applicant. I think you are unnecessarily legalistic in your approach to that section.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for the explanation. With the greatest of respect, I am not trying to be overly legalistic and technical in this, because this is something which is repeated throughout various other amendments that you have in this bill. I feel that it is one area where some overzealous person may well misconstrue the meaning of this bill. Hence my question to you. In later life, people will be able to look back on this and say this is what it really meant. I am not trying to be overly technical, Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —Essentially what Senator Hogg is trying to say—I have actually asked these questions before in estimates—is: what guidelines will the department use to determine what is regarded as training? As Senator Hogg says, are we talking about off‐the‐job training or on‐the‐job training? When I asked these questions before of the secretary of the department, he indicated that it would be an agreement. He imagined they would strike some sort of agreement between the employer and employee.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not trying to be overly legalistic. We know how the Department of Social Security works, in the main. It is critical that there be guidelines to determine and define precisely what training is. We are saying it is not sufficient for something that the employer and the employee can strike a deal on without transparency and accountability by the department, given that the department holds the ultimate sanction—withdrawal of benefit.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The department will be issuing guidelines on this to settle one matter which Senator Mackay raised. She did talk about agreement, but it would be a misunderstanding if she was thinking that it was necessarily some formal agreement.
—He said he imagined it would be in the agreement—small `a'.

—A little `a' in agreement, thank you. As I understand it, the guidelines would be something along the lines of `What training is accepted as a standard in that industry as appropriate for that job or type of job?' The appropriate skills and training needed for that particular job are what we are talking about. The guidelines would refer to what were the accepted standards of training in that industry. On that basis, the department would assess whether that had been met or not.

—Thank you for that answer, Minister. It is difficult for us on this side of the chamber to make an assessment in relation to the bill without having access to the guidelines at this stage. I wonder why those are not available and when they will be available. It does, as Senator Hogg pointed out, leave it fairly open.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Mackay, I would say that what guidelines are needed and what are not depend somewhat on the form in which legislation ends up. Frequently guidelines are produced when the legislation is completed. I am very happy to make the guidelines available to the other parties in the Senate as soon as they are finalised, after the legislation. It will not be too long because, once the legislation is passed, we will be wanting to implement the measures. The guidelines will have to be ready very shortly but they are not available and not ready yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Normally those sorts of guidelines are not disallowable instruments. One of the problems that we have at the moment, as raised by Senator Hogg and Senator Mackay, is to get our minds around what is meant by `No training will be provided by the employer.' I would have thought that, if you were putting forward a proposition such as that, the department would have already prepared the guidelines. That is a sensible way of doing things.
—The cart before the horse, Senator.

—Yes, that is true. It is the cart before the horse. Either they expect us to agree with this or perhaps they did not expect it to go through and thought it might be a waste of departmental time to prepare the guidelines. This matter might well be revisited at some stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Initially, I felt it would be something that I could support because, obviously, if relevant training was competently given then it would be unreasonable for the applicant not to undertake that training. But what type of training? What are the guidelines and conditions? I suppose it would be paid training. Is it assumed that the applicant would be paid for the training, in other words, there would be on‐the‐job training? The minister may care to respond. Are we dealing with this cognately?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, perhaps I could enlighten you. Senator Brown has indicated that he is withdrawing amendment No. 10. To facilitate handling the bill, we may be able to deal with items 3, 4, 6, 7, 9, 11, 13, 14, 17, 18, 20, 21 and 23 together. I have spoken to the Leader of the Opposition about it because, as we are speaking to all of those amendments anyway, they may be able to be dealt with at once. On the running sheet it is items 6, 7, 8 and 11. They all deal with the same matters that we are talking about now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —On the specifics that Senator Harradine raised about training, the appropriate training would, in normal circumstances, be expected to be on‐the‐job training or, where that is not the appropriate training for that job, to be paid for by the employer, as you surmised.

PARA.BREAK: I give you the analogy of an emerging industry where people work in telecall centres but may have not had training in that. They may need a combination of on‐the‐job training as well as some specialised training paid for by the employer, as is happening at the moment with groups of new employees. It will vary depending on the industry's arrange ments and the employer's wishes or intentions. That is the belief of the government.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to your comments about guidelines. It is not normally the practice for them to be finalised before the legislation is passed, and this government is taking no different position on that than previous governments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, there is an assumption that it will be either on‐the‐job training or appropriate training in terms of the industry standard and the employer will pay for it. Senator Harradine has articulated the difficulty that there is no explicit prohibition, for example, on a job seeker saying to an employer, `I will pay you so that I can be trained.' I refer to the 19th century training practices. That is our difficulty.

SPEECH.PARA: For example, somebody who may be desperate for a job, of which there are many people, goes to a job interview and the employer says, `I'm sorry, you are not sufficiently qualified and I have a list of many people who are sufficiently qualified. These are the sorts of skills that you require.' We may, under what is a clearly deregulated regime, see the employer saying, `You could pay me or I could deduct X from your wages in order to provide you with that training.'

Senator Harradine is saying that because we do not have clear guidelines in front of us, we do not know whether that type of activity will be overtly, expressly and clearly prohibited by the department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is, quite clearly, that we would not endorse or allow compulsion of the employee to pay for their training.
—But how would you know?

—A complaint in the normal way by the employee which we would have to be followed up in the normal way. That is nothing different from a whole lot of allegations or claims and counterclaims which the department has to decide between. That is a normal administrative process the department would follow. Following up from that, there are tried and true appeals processes in place. There is no disadvantage to the job seeker in the current administrative appeal arrangements, so we are introducing nothing new in that area. So you are really focusing on the guidelines and what they will contain.

SPEECH.PARA: Employers will not be able to insist that employees pay for their training in one form or another through pay deductions or sending them out to finance their own training. Does that get to the bottom of what you are asking?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —The difficulty though is that we have a deregulated duality. We have the proposed deregulation of social security and a substantial deregulation of the labour market. What I am really getting at is that this imposes difficulties from the department's perspective. With an Australian workplace agreement negotiated from an individual to an employer, it will be very hard for a department to know precisely what is going on in relation to the small `a' agreement that the secretary referred to.

SPEECH.PARA: Maybe at this stage I could broaden it out to what kind of regulatory regimen the department is considering to take account of the deregulated regimen we now have with the passage of the workplace relations act. We now have a potential duality in terms of deregulation. In this particular aspect of the bill, I would like to know what provision the department has made for that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mackay, I think you focused so much on the industrial relations aspect that you are missing what we have under the microscope here: it is only the social security system; and it is called into play when somebody has in fact refused a job offer. It is on the basis of whether that refusal was reasonable or not that all this comes into question.

SPEECH.PARA: In those circumstances, the department would be looking to the facts of the case as to what was the basis on which they refused it. In this case, we are talking about the absence of appropriate training for that job. It is beyond that that you get to a question of negotiating terms and conditions of employment. If the employee says, `I haven't got the skills for this job. Will you train me?' and the employer says no, then they have not started to get into a workplace agreement situation. But the social security system is at this stage called in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Apparently we cannot see the regulations that are going to determine how this works, which is a dereliction in terms of the committee having to make a determination on whether it agrees with the application of these new rules. It is a pretty complicated system. I have sifted out a couple of things. Firstly, people who go for a job for which they are not skilled have the onus on them to negotiate with the employer that they will be skilled on the job. In some vague way, we are supposed to accept that the employer is going to get reimbursed for that training.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, a person who goes for a job and sees that the job is not safe with work conditions that are not acceptable has to negotiate with the employer about fixing up those work conditions, otherwise she or he is likely to go back and have their benefits cut off. It is up to this person who is going for a job not only to shoulder the burden of approaching an employer—which is a fair job for many people seeking work, and for youngsters in particular—but also to negotiate that they are going to get training and take back a report saying, `It didn't work. The employer did or didn't agree to give me training.' Also, if they spot that the workplace is not safe, they are going to have to negotiate and come back with a report as to whether the employer was agreeable to fixing up the unsafe conditions. The threat on job applicants is that they will lose their benefits if they have not entered those negotiations.

But we do not know the guidelines. We do not know the exact parameters which govern whether or not they have done the job properly. I submit that is totally unsatisfactory. The Greens oppose this measure, because we do not believe that added burden should be put on the shoulders of job seekers. It is hard enough as it is. It does depend on the whim of the employer saying, `Yes, I will skill you' or `No, I won't skill you' as to whether they get a job, or saying, `Yes, I will fix up the workplace' or `No, I won't fix up the workplace' as to whether they get a job. I think that is extraordinary.

Maybe the government ought to move in and say, `You fix up your workplace.' Maybe the government ought to say, `If you want assistance in getting people to fill your job, you make sure you train them adequately.' But to put that burden on the unemployed person is quite extraordinary.

TALK.START.PARA: —You misunderstand me.

—The minister might explain the exact parameters that we have not got so we are not left in this dithering position where the committee is being asked to make a decision on a lot of probables. That is not good enough, Minister. It will not be good enough for the poor job seekers out there who themselves have to get through this morass of obligations. It needs to be very clear, very specific, very easily laid out and very easily understood. If this committee is having trouble with it, God help the job seeker.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, it is not to be regulations, Senator Brown. The normal arrangements for social security legislation in this type of area traditionally—and we are doing nothing different—is to bring in guidelines when the legislation is completed. The guidelines, as I understand it, have always been drafted so they are consistent with the legislation but, in addition, they take into account the concerns of the Senate as expressed in the debate on the legislation. So that is how the guidelines will be developed.
—Are you serious? I am sorry, could I just hear that again: that the department takes account of the concerns expressed by the Senate. That is a refreshing change, I must say.

—Thank you, Senator. Maybe it is under a different regime, Senator Harradine. I do not know whether that was not the condition. But the advice I have had is that is how the department operates in developing guidelines. Perhaps if you know otherwise, you should tell me.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter that Senator Brown raised is this question of negotiation. It is not negotiation. That is why I was shaking my head at you. It is not expected that a job seeker will be negotiating. This is not developing a workplace agreement or any form of industrial activity. This is simply that we expect the employee to ask a question, `Will I be trained?' and to get an answer, yes or no. On the basis of which: if it is yes, they are expected to take the job; if it is no, they are expected to inform the department of that.

Similarly, if you are talking about occupational health and safety conditions, an employee has to say, `I believe this might endanger my health and my safety. Are you prepared to fix it up to conform to whatever might be the law? Are you prepared to improve the situation so that I could accept a job here?' If the answer is no, then the department will look at that and the discretion will be exercised.

That is what we are asking. We are not talking about negotiation. I think it is very important that that be hit on the head. I have heard other senators, some time ago, assume that that was the arrangement. Let me put it clearly on the record that they are going for a job interview and if a situation arises where questions of training or of occupational health and safety are asked, such as, `Will you fix it?' or `Will you give me training?' and the answer is no, they then go back to Social Security and report that fact.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —That is extraordinary. If you go for a job and you ask, `Will you give me training?' and the employer says yes, you go back to Social Security and lose your benefits if you do not accept the job. The employer becomes the total arbiter of your fortunes as far as your training is concerned. That is extraordinary.
—Regardless of the quality of training.

—Regardless of whether any training is given. All the employer has to do is utter the word yes and you are obliged to take the job. How will the government make sure that the employer comes good on that commitment, and what will be the quality of that commitment? Of course there will have to be negotiation. The whole exercise becomes facile otherwise. It becomes absurd.

SPEECH.PARA: Similarly, if a person goes to a clearly unsafe workplace and says, `I'm here to get a job, but this is unsafe. Will you fix it?' and the employer says yes, they then lose their benefits if they do not take that job. I would submit that, if there is an unsafe workplace, the employer must be under a great cloud of suspicion to start off with and is the least likely person to fix up that place. But on the glib answer of yes, a person's fortunes as to benefits depend. That is not satisfactory. It is not conscionable.

You are going to deprive job seekers of any income on the words yes or no coming from an employer, regardless of that employer's bona fides. That is not satisfactory. We have to remember in this place that we are dealing with people's lives and fortunes and their ability to make ends meet. We will have a litany of tragedies—as far as people's lives are concerned—coming to public notice further down the line if this circumstance is allowed to come into law, which is what we are talking about here. It is just not good enough.

If people have concerns about what an employer is doing or about how fair dinkum they are in providing training or making a place safe, the obligation ought to be on the authority that will take away the job seeker's money if they do not accept the employer's word. That ought to be your authority and your responsibility, Minister. I think this is just totally unfair. I think this is instituting a great deal of hardship and, in some cases, gross violations of people's right to a safe workplace, and an appropriate workplace, and to work in situations in which they are properly skilled.

PARA.BREAK: The government is setting up that situation, and I appeal to it to think again. This committee needs much clearer evidence that these measures will not be abused and that people will not find themselves caught between a rock and a hard place—they take an unsatis factory job or they lose their benefits—because of these regulations. That is not good enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister has said categorically, as I understand it, to the committee that we are not talking about negotiation. I think they were your words, Minister, and you are nodding in agreement. I do not want to put words into your mouth, so I appreciate your indication across the chamber. How does this fit with item 4, amending paragraph 601(2A)(a), at page 18 of your explanatory memorandum, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: This requires the customer to take an active role in seeking out training from the employer so as to obtain the necessary qualifications, skills or experience to perform the work.
That is in your own explanatory memorandum, Minister.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is nothing contradictory in the two things. It is an active role to ask the question, `Will you give training for this job?' It is an active role to ask, `Will you clean up your workplace?' It is an active role to say, `This workplace looks as if it might aggravate my medical condition. Will you do something that will ameliorate that problem?' That is activity; that is speaking up and asking a question. That is not negotiating. They are two different things.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, Minister, you now are really straining credulity on this. Are you seriously suggesting that what you are demanding of people is not negotiating? You are saying that taking an active role is different from negotiating. I would like you to explain to the committee what is the difference.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a question of just not accepting that if they do not have the skills they do not get the job. It is appropriate that people ask that question. There is then an opportunity for training, for example, to be offered.

SPEECH.PARA: If it is offered—this is something I think Senator Brown said a minute ago—and the employer does not keep his word, then the employee is perfectly within their rights to say, `I can't work at this job without the training' or `I can't work at this job with the occupational health and safety standards the way they are' or `I can't work at this in an unhealthy environment. I cannot continue with this job', and they will be back on benefits again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, what you have just said goes to the nub of what I was trying to express earlier, and that is that it is impossible to differentiate between the social security regime and the fact that we now have a change in the labour market. That is the point. You have now got a situation whereby all jobs, or the conditions other than the basic minima prescribed in the act, will be negotiated.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, the government says, `We want you to negotiate with the employer in terms of an AWA, or whatever'. The difficulty with this is that it is all about negotiation. That is the problem. In order to actually attain a position, the government has encouraged job seekers to sit down and negotiate what the conditions would be in that position, other than the seven prescribed minima. Therefore, for example, training is a negotiable matter in terms of the contract that is finally hammered out between the employer and the employee.

The broader question that I am asking is: what provision has the department made for the accountability—the checks and balances—of areas like occupational health and safety under a deregulated labour market, where there is a clear nexus between the activities of a department and the activities of the labour market. Even in the term `unsuitable work', `work' equals `labour market'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am just concerned that you are still focusing on the changes to the IR system, which are obviously very important to you as a former trade unionist.
—How can you not focus on it?

—Because the occupational health and safety standards, being administered by state governments, have not been deregulated and remain in place, and workplaces are still meant to conform to those. It is not a negotiating matter—
—What about all the other conditions?

—There is one. You just used occupational health and safety yourself. You might acknowledge that that is not a relevant issue in terms of a prospective employee, believing that he is going to have a problem with occupational health and safety, asking the question, `Are you going to make this site safe?' and the employer saying, `Mind your own business.' The employee then has perfect entitlement to stay on benefits.
—What about training? That is negotiable.

—It does not have to be a question of negotiation at all. It is a straight information getting exercise. For example, I come along, I receive a social security benefit right now and somebody has lined up a job interview for me, or I've lined it up for myself.
—You negotiate a contract.

—No, we have not got to the negotiating stage yet. We are asking, `Is there a job available—yes or no?' `Yes, there is a job, because I have come along to an interview that has been organised.' `Suppose I do not have the training or the skills for that job. Are you providing training for new employees coming into this industry?'

SPEECH.PARA: It would be a jolly silly employer that said no, but if they say no, then you do not have to go any further. You do not have to get into the issues of pay and conditions and what kind of training is available and who pays, or those sorts of elements. You have just got to that first step. You are not qualified, but the employer will not provide training. Well, you do not have to be taken off benefits, because you are still perfectly entitled to stay on benefits in those circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —This gets worse as we go along. We are now in the situation where a moment ago the minister said that, if a person takes a job because the employer said they would fix up the workplace but they do not fix up the workplace, the person can leave the job and go back to benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: This means that the government is going to have a situation where people have gone into an unsafe workplace because they were coerced—that is, they were told they would lose their benefits if they did not take the job. The situation is then at the whim of the employer, and it could take some time before the employees finally recognise that the employer's whim is not coming good for them. Is the government going to indemnify these people while they are in that workplace? I think there is an onus on the government to accept such an indemnity.

The problem here is that the onus is being taken off the department and put on the shoulders of the unemployed to negotiate proper work conditions and to ensure that proper work conditions pertain. When employers are involved in this arrangement—whereby they are de facto arbitrating whether a person is taken off benefits or not—the onus should be very clearly put on them by the department and by the minister. If the employers are not providing training, they should not have the opportunity of taking the unemployed person's services. If they have not got a safe workplace, then the unemployed person ought not be in there.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.

—Minister, you just said that the employer only has to say, `Yes,' and the unemployed person must take the job. The employer only has to say, `Yes, I am going to fix up this place,' and the person must take the job. Fix it up when? Where are these guidelines? I do not think the person should be taking the job until it is fixed up.

BREAK.PARA: Even if we did accept that it is up to the unemployed person to negotiate—and it is negotiation: it is more than saying, `Yes;' it is saying, `How are you going to fix it up? How are you going to skill me?'—I think it is up to the minister to show this committee that the guidelines are in place to stop the unemployed person being abused in those circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether I might put a slightly different question to the minister. I think this is where the minister's responsibilities really are being questioned, and that is why I would like to add a question to the debate we are having. I really want to get at what the department's response is to the worker reporting back to them. How will the department check on the person's report?

SPEECH.PARA: I can give you an example in the situation of occupational health and safety. The person not only will have to take steps to have the employer address those issues but also will have to satisfy the department that they took those steps. I want to get at that question. A person could say to an employer, `Will you rectify the safety issue?' and the employer would say to them, `Well, forget it,' which is the most likely response. The person then goes back to the department and reports this.

Is the department going to take their word or will the department check on the person's report, which I presume is most likely? Then, say, the department rings up the employer to check on this. The employer is not going to admit that there is a safety issue. He probably will not even admit that he told the person to get lost. So the poor applicant is in really a terrible bind. What I want to know is: how is the department going to check on the person's report in any way that will not put that person in a situation which could be disadvantageous to them?

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Newman, given that, in your own words, this is a straight information gathering exercise—I think I quote you accurately—how does that relate under part 2, item 6, which says `made a reasonable attempt'? Could I please have an answer to that question?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let it be clearly on the record again, Senator, that, by asking that question, it is a reasonable attempt. We are not asking potential employees to be negotiating either for their training or for how an employer might change the work force to make it healthier, perhaps, for that individual. We are just asking: will you or won't you?

SPEECH.PARA: If there is a conflict between the employer and the employee as to who is right or not, which is of course something which the department was well used to in the past, it will be a question on which it will be using its judgment. In most cases, unless it is a situation where perhaps you might have somebody who has a very poor work record or unwillingness to work, it could be that the department would find against the person on benefits. Once again, that is appealable through the existing system.

I would also draw your attention to the fact that some employers, Senator Brown, have a reputation for unsafe workplaces. The Department of Social Security is pretty well aware of that situation on a local basis. So there would be the benefit of the doubt of course given to the person applying for benefits in those circumstances. It would help to aid the department in the exercise of their discretion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the minister could explain to the committee how a straight information gathering exercise correlates with a requirement that the customer take an active role in seeking out training from the employer so as to obtain the necessary qualifications, skills or experience to perform the work?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the comparison between being active and inactive—asking a question or not asking a question. Does that not satisfy you? Really, you have asked the same question again and I am essentially trying to give you the same answer in another format that would convince you.

SPEECH.PARA: If it would assist the Senate in its consideration of this matter, I would be very happy to give an undertaking to the Senate that as soon as the guidelines are completed I will table them in the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am interested in this issue of the guidelines that has been raised now by a number of senators in the chamber. I was interested in how this again might compare to the situation in relation to the issue of the two‐year waiting period for migrants. Is it true, minister, on that occasion, that claims were refused on the basis of guidelines which anticipated legislative change? If it is, Minister, can you explain your different standards in this regard?

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the guidelines that you are referring to, Senator, were in fact relating to special benefit and were existing at the time. They were not changes developed by the prospect of the incoming legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I notice that you sought advice. I am glad you are seeking some additional advice. Perhaps you could consider that answer. I really am interested in the difference here, because the issue that has been raised in relation to guidelines is an important issue of principle.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The advice I had is that the guidelines were changed and were consistent with the legislation in place at the time.

—I am partly reassured by the minister saying that when there is a dispute between the information given by the employer and the information given by the employee, the department is able to make a judgment about it. But let me place on the record the concern I have that, where the department is in the mode of wanting to crack down on defrauders, that becomes the overriding attitude of the department. In that kind of mode, I think that the employee will be at a tremendous disadvantage. I am just putting my concern on the record. I guess that down the track we will find out whether my concern is justified.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —A word of caution here: the department would be very ill advised to take that route because it would show up in the appeal process. For the long‐term benefit of the department, such action would be most unwise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister would have gathered that the chamber is rather concerned that full protection be afforded to the most vulnerable. I am sure that would be the minister's concern as well. A person presents for employment; the interview takes place, and during that interview the prospective employee says that they do not consider themselves competent for the particular job. The employer says that they will give them adequate training specific to skilling them for the particular job. You could understand that, if that person just walked out of that interview and went back to the department, the department might well consider that a problem.

SPEECH.PARA: However, in respect of the matters raised by other senators—particularly Senator Woodley, Senator Hogg and Senator Mackay—and before voting for the government's training provisions, I would like to see the guidelines the department will have in place in order to protect the prospective employee. Persons who are unemployed are among the most vulnerable in a high unemployment situation. This is why I am not too sure what the government is getting at here.

I do not think this measure will save a great deal of money because there would be plenty of people eagerly wanting any one job. People are lining up for jobs. I cannot see the point of some of the government's amendments. Perhaps the government thinks these measures should be in place for the time when there is very low unemployment, and fair enough, but at the present time that is not the case, sad to say.

I am inclined to support the particular provision provided we have a very clear indication, firstly, of how the department will ensure that the most vulnerable are protected and, secondly, that these particular training provisions are not mickey mouse but provisions which will give real skills to the unemployed.
I am not inclined to support paragraph 601(2)(AC). That seems to me to be a pretty clear‐cut issue. Either there are risks to health and safety or there are not.

What if a vacancy is caused by a worker leaving a job because he considered it unsafe? The department then sends an unemployed person along to fill the advertised vacancy. The person goes along to get an ECC or genuinely seek to fill the vacancy and after interview he is told that there is a safety problem on the job. What happens there?

TALK.START.PARA: —He doesn't have to accept it. I answered that earlier.
—I must have been snoozing away because I did not hear it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —If there is an occupational health and safety problem on the job, and an employer will not rectify it, there is no question: a person does not have to take the job. If they take the job and the situation is not rectified in reasonable time, they can walk out and not be penalised in any way for going back onto benefits. Have I missed something that Senator Harradine is concerned about?

—I have not made myself clear, and I apologise to the chamber. I am talking about a situation where a person goes along to seek appointment to a vacancy. With this provision, the government is saying that the person has to make reasonable attempts to remove or reduce the risks through discussions with the employer concerned. I do not think that should be a requirement. Why should that requirement devolve upon the employee?
—It is an employer obligation.

—I take the point that Senator Hogg has said that it is an employer obligation. We are dealing with item 9—that is, the provisions relating to obligations on the restrictions of where to move. Senator Woodley asked a very interesting question about three sons who lived in outback Queensland where there was a drought. They went to Toowoomba and sought work there. Finally, they could not get jobs, or some of them got jobs and then lost them, so they decided to go back to help their parents on the farm. They were denied a benefit? I do not think that question has been answered.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, if a person leaves because the occupational health and safety issue has not been fixed, will they have to serve a waiting period for leaving the job voluntarily?

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer is no, Senator.
—Could you just indicate on what grounds, Minister?

—The penalty only applies if somebody leaves a job without good reason, and that would not be deemed to have been without good reason. Senator Harradine was referring to another item in this clutch of items relating to going to get a job in another locality—or were you referring to going to an area of low employment?

—I am sorry, Minister, I was referring to the question raised by Senator Woodley which related to the existing provisions. I assume Senator Woodley was really getting at what steps in our consideration of 9 we should take to consider the issue of obligations to families. Does the department have discretion in that particular matter? I would like to feel that this government has regard for family obligations. These sons obviously went to an area of low employment, or high unemployment, to help their folks out on the farm, which had been devastated by drought. They were trying to pick themselves up. They lost their benefits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The discretion will always be exercised on a case by case basis, so it is a bit difficult here to be giving a specific answer to a specific example without having an opportunity to really take it all into account. If somebody is going to a job, which appeared to be what Senator Woodley was saying about going to work on the farm, they would not be eligible for benefits anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: If they are going to a job anywhere, if they have a job to go to, they would be expected to take that job except in the circumstances that are set out in the amendment, which I think cover a lot of areas, though there is still an additional clause, or for any other reason. So there is an opportunity there for people to not move to an area where there is a specific job in a number of circumstances, but there is that other clause as well. If they are going to an area of low employment and they are not going to a job, there are penalties already in the system and we would be seeking to extend those penalties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I just make a case very clear. There was a person who was unemployed and had gone to a place from the farm to get employment but was not able to get employment. It was not an area of high employment—in this case I think it was Toowoomba; theoretically it could be any other place. That person was going to that place to get a job. That person was unsuccessful. That person, therefore, was not eligible for the benefits. That person had been on the benefit for some time, unable to get a job in that area, and responded to a call from his parents to come home to help on the farm, which had been devastated by drought, and to rebuild the place. They were in debt up to their ears and he went back to help the family. There might be illness, or whatever.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the provisions of this legislation, even the current legislation, that person loses the benefit. Is it just that that person should lose the benefit because that person is discharging a family obligation? That is all I am asking. Where in the legislation—and I have just been having a quick look—is that particular matter catered for? It would not be an isolated example; I should imagine, it would be replicated time and time again in situations in various parts of Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation that Senator Harradine is describing is best addressed in this way. If the person concerned was available to take work if it was offered then they would still be entitled to a benefit. There are nevertheless—
—Even if they moved to a place of high unemployment?

—Yes, I was going on to say that. There is residual discretion within the legislation to treat individual circumstances on their merits. In the example you give, one can well envisage that that would be an appropriate situation in which discretion was exercised beneficially. As you know, this legislation is to be used beneficially for the sake of those who need help. While I cannot be specific about that particular case, I am trying to give you an indication of what the advice is to me and what the department would use as a basis for assessing those circumstances.
—What are the parameters for people risking losing benefits if they do not undertake self-employment?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Brown will bear with me, I will respond to him in a minute. I have further advice on the particular matter Senator Harradine was raising. Section 597(3) of the act provides in relation to moving to an area of lower employment prospects:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes of subsection (1) a person has a sufficient reason for moving to a new place of residence if and only if the person:
(a) moves to live with a family member who has already established his or her residence in that place of residence; or
(b) moves to live near a family member who has already established residence in the same area . . .

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —What has the department advised are the savings in relation to part 2 of schedule 5, the amendments to clarify the meaning of unsuitable work?

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry to tell Senator Faulkner that the department is not able to extrapolate that item out of this clutch of measures in the activity testing. I am not in a position to give you the precise figures on this. I have a lot of precise figures on a lot of other things, but some of them are difficult to get for you.
—Why is that?
—The department has made an allocation as to how much these measures will save and it is difficult to—
—What is it?
—It will be $133 million in a full year.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —When you say $133 million for a full year, do you mean for the whole of the schedule?
—For the activity testing.

—When I asked a similar question in relation to part 1 of schedule 5, you were able to provide the chamber with an answer. Senator Harradine, in one of his earlier contributions, indicated a view, which may or may not be accurate because we have no advice from you, as to possible savings. Can you indicate to me why you were able to provide information in relation to part 1 of the schedule but not part 2?

—What we have to remember as a committee is that that figure of $133 million is not just a saving. There is actually some extra administration in these measures. This is money that is going to come from penalties on people who do not comply with these measures. I think we have to keep that very much in mind. They are increasingly difficult parameters and people may be at the whim of a prospective employer. If an employer says that they are committed to give training or fix up a workplace this may determine whether or not a person gets a job or is deprived of benefits. That is going to affect thousands of people across Australia who refuse to take a job where an employer is not likely to keep their word. I think we have to keep that very clearly in mind.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 1 p.m. to 2 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to make a brief comment. I think many of us realised over lunch that we have a long way to go before we get to the end of this bill and all of us, I hope, would like to expedite its passage. I understand that Senator Faulkner has a proposal that he has been talking to the other parties about.
—Well, no. I was just giving it out. I was asked to do something.

—We have had a brief look at it and would be very happy to support such a move. I did want to put a couple of things on the record now. There have been concerns about the occupational health and safety issue, and I am happy to give an undertaking on behalf of the government in relation to that, but I will wait until Senator Harradine arrives in the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I will move first to the question of savings that Senator Faulkner asked me about, because he is in the chamber. The following information was provided by the department in response to questions by the opposition in the legislation committee about calculation of savings from the activity test measure.

Savings arising from the changes to penalty periods were calculated separately, as were changes to the definition of an activity test breach. Savings for each of the other measures identified as part of the activity test package were not calculated separately because of the interaction between the measures. They were costed as a package on the basis of their expected impact in terms of extra breaches, increased incidence of successful job search and increased voluntary compliance.

However, the Department of Social Security and the Department of Finance have estimated their contribution to savings from the legislative measures other than the changes to the penalty periods as follows: in 1996-97, $1.4 million; 1997-98, $2.1 million; 1998-99, $2.1 million; and 1999-2000, $2.1 million. The bulk of these came from the measures to define unsuitable work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have made a suggestion to the senators in the chamber in relation to possible time frames for handling the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Budget and Other Measures) Bill. I am not wedded to any of these suggestions.

SPEECH.PARA: As we left the chamber at lunch there was, as Senator Newman has indicated, a realisation that, if the debate continued to progress at the rate it was and if it were not for the guillotine, we would be here until well past Christmas. We have a guillotine and we have obviously a constraint on us, and that is going to require us to be disciplined in the way we deal with the issues before us.

This is an informal suggestion—I do not put it at any higher level—as to how we might deal with this. Obviously, we need to deal with the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Further Budget and Other Measures) Bill also today.

In that spirit it might be possible that, when we move to voting on a range of measures which obviously are of interest to senators, we consider holding divisions over until the conclusion of the committee stage of the bill. There is a very short time for a lot of amendments in the very complex area of public policy. That is my suggestion so that time for divisions does not actually get caught up in the guillotine. I propose this suggestion by leave, Mr Chairman, on the principle that you can do anything you like in the Senate if leave is granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Up to a point. Are there any further matters in relation to items 3 to 23 of schedule 5?

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to simply put on the record, as I started to do earlier before Senator Harradine arrived, that I am happy to give an undertaking on behalf of the government that the guidelines will specifically address the issue of occupational health and safety. Clearly such guidelines will require that employer assurances that unsafe workplaces will be made safe must occur within a reasonable period of time. Where the occupational health and safety issue is of such severity as to pose a genuine risk to the employee, people will not be removed from benefits. The guidelines will also provide that people will be given the benefit of the doubt. I give a commitment to the committee to table the guidelines in the Senate in the first week that parliament resumes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) for that assurance, but I also wish to respond. I indicated to the chamber that I was going to vote against that provision. The matter that I was seeking information on and seeking some indicative guarantees on—I think they were the words I used—and I thought it would not be beyond the department to produce this because, obviously, it would have been thought about over lunch, was the matter that was raised, particularly by Senator Hogg and Senator Mackay, in respect of training. What training is meant by part 2 clause 4? That is the matter that I was particularly interested in.

SPEECH.PARA: I admit that I did indicate, in a general sense, that what we are all on about is the protection of the most vulnerable. In that sort of context, I was particularly referring to the training matter. I do not believe that clause 6 is at all useful, and I would be inclined to vote against it.

However, I did say—and I thought I made it very clear—that I accept the viewpoint that it would be unreasonable for unemployed persons to deliberately walk away from a situation where their skills can be improved on the job in a structured, properly trained way which is focused on giving them skills. It would be unreasonable to do so on the basis alone of saying `I'm not qualified for the job' when the offer is there to ensure that the person is absolutely qualified for the job. But I indicated that I would look for some indicative guarantee, and maybe that can come forward between now and the time we get the division.

TALK.START.PARA: —The other point I brought up before lunch—and I do not recollect the minister responding to it—was the business of self‐employment. There is provision here for people to potentially lose their benefits if they do not undertake self‐employment. I do not know that people working in the department have the wherewithal to assess which individuals among the unemployed are capable of becoming self‐employed and on what basis that is done. But I would like to hear it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that somebody who has traditionally, historically, been involved in self‐employment would be expected to accept an offer of self‐employment if it was made. Does that answer your question?

—Not quite, because I am not sure what an offer of self‐employment is. Self-employment is where one generates a business or a job for oneself. So I cannot quite see how that can be offered. It seems to me that it is being left to the judgment of somebody in the department to say, `You were self‐employed. Either become self‐employed again or you will lose your benefits.'

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we are at cross‐purposes. If you were a consultant, for example, and you were offered a consultancy and you refused it, that would be the sort of circumstances in which you would not be entitled.

—Thank you. That does help, because that to me is taking a reasonable job which is skilled. I would find it very difficult that a person in those circumstances would not take that on. But, again, I would like to see the guidelines on this because I am concerned—and I have had representations—that this may mean that people who have been in some way or other involved in self‐employment which turned out to be a money loser and left them in financial straits are going to be told, `Either take that self‐employment up again or you will be out.' Taking consultancies is one thing but that is a very tiny component of the potential for self‐employment, so I would like to know what the guidelines are in this matter.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I think the best answer that I could give is that the guidelines will recognise that where somebody has the training to take an opportunity for which they would in fact be self‐employed—and consultancy is an example—they would be expected to take the job. By comparison, at present, because that is deemed to be self-employed and not applying for a job to be an employee, you cannot be precluded from benefits. So it is to clear up the situation which you clearly think needs to be addressed anyway.

—To make that black and white, if I can: this does not apply to self‐generated work. This is a response to an opportunity for work coming from a second source. That is what a consultancy is. I want to make it clear that it does not apply to people who might make things, who are creative or who have been organised in the past in some self‐generated business capacity; that they are not going to be asked to take on that sort of role again and, if they do not, lose their benefits.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Your assumption is correct and I am advised that because this is a growing area of employment—self‐employment in work like consultancies—it does need to be covered by the legislation.
—I would suggest that instead of using that terminology, you would apply it to consultancies and that it is made clear and confined so that people know exactly where they stand.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the word `consultancy' would not be adequate to cope with the situation because there are people in similar circumstances in which you could not adequately describe them as consultants. Nevertheless, the guidelines will be developed to be as specific as it is possible to be in this area—to make it quite clear who is covered.

—My last comment on this is: then we ought to again have those guidelines. I frankly do not trust putting my vote into a situation where I do not know what I am voting for. It worries me greatly, because at the end of the day, this goes into law; we then get guidelines drawn up which I no longer have any say on, and people out there are going to be affected to the extent that they will lose their income if they fall outside the guidelines. They will be cut off from benefits. If we are going to vote on measures, we ought to know what we are voting for. If we do not know what we are voting for, that is encouraging us greatly to vote against it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I recognise that we are still on the same issue. I know that Senator Brown has concerns, but I also have concerns about time. There are other matters which also need our attention. When I came into the chamber after lunch, I made it clear what I was undertaking to the chamber about the guidelines. As far as Senator Harradine is concerned, I will give an indication of the guidelines relating to training.

SPEECH.PARA: Training would be sufficient to address the skill deficiencies of the person. It would be training recognised as meeting the standard within the industry, not training that requires a payment by the employee and training provided by the employer. As I say, I have given a commitment to table the guidelines as finalised in the first week parliament resumes. As that is at least as good an opportunity as the Senate has had to address previous guidelines in a later forum, I hope that it accepts that assurance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understood that, following an eminently suitable proposition by Senator Faulkner, all the votes were going to take place at the end. There are a number of things that I certainly want to get from the government on other matters in this bill. I thought Senator Faulkner had made the eminently reasonable suggestion that we have all the votes at the end of the committee stage.
—We do have a question before the chair, and that is what we have to put.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated before, I really think the suggestion that I put forward is a sensible one. I do not hear anyone in the chamber demur from it. The problem we have now is a procedural one of making it happen. It is not so easy, because Senator Harradine correctly makes the point that many senators want to make contributions on a very significant range of issues. From the perspective of the opposition and all other senators around the chamber, there are important issues in the further budget measures bill which we have not reached.

SPEECH.PARA: What should be achievable is to have any divisions on this bill or the further budget measures bill at 5.52 p.m., when we are required to conclude our consideration of the committee stage of debate on these two bills. That means that not only do we get more time to debate now but also that we can have a series of one minute divisions. I have used the word `sensible'. Senator Harradine used the words `eminently reasonable'. There is general agreement. It is only a matter of making it happen. I have always worked in the Senate on the principle that these things are best done when we all agree by leave and if leave is granted. Otherwise, we will have a very complex procedural debate, which I do not want. I want to make it clear that I do not want to waste time; I do not think anyone does. I suggest, Mr Chairman, that if you are able to accommodate this, we should do it in that fashion.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us at the moment items 3, 4, 6, 7, 9, 11, 13, 14, 17, 18, 20, 21 and 23 of schedule 5. The question is that they stand as printed. They come from sections 6, 7, 8 and 11 of the running sheet. My suggestion is that, when honourable senators have finished considering those items, we move a motion that further consideration of those items be made an order of the day for a later hour of the day. If that is suitable, the committee should advise me when they want that motion to be moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I so move.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I put the question that the bill as amended be agreed to, the committee will be able to consider any of the items in the remainder of the bill. It might be best to go a little in accordance with the running sheet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with you, Mr Chairman, and thank you for the suggestion of how to deal with it. I would like to briefly address the remaining issues of concern to the opposition in schedule 5. That is a sensible way to contain our debate at this stage. The opposition has concern with both part 3 and part 5 of that schedule.

SPEECH.PARA: Part 3 of the schedule extends the penalties for breaches of the activity test to six weeks for the first breach and 13 for the second and subsequent breaches. The activity test regime that Labor introduced when it was in government was a tough one. But, as I indicated very clearly in my speech on the second reading and as was the thrust of my second reading amendment, it was a reciprocal one. It was developed under an arrangement of a reciprocal obligation, where the community undertook to pay income support for those actively seeking work and to provide labour market assistance in employment services which unemployed people need to get back into the work force. In turn, unemployed people were obliged to meet the conditions of the activity test. Penalties were further tightened under the Working Nation job compact, where people were given greater access, variety and training and were guaranteed at least some work experience.

The key issue here is that this government has abandoned the concept of a job compact. It has abandoned the concept of reciprocal obligation. It is in those circumstances that we say that this regime is too harsh. That is why we are proposing amendments to limit breach penalties to the equivalent of just over four weeks non‐payment for a first breach and just over six weeks non‐payment for a second or any subsequent breach.

For the opposition's part, we acknowledge and accept the very strong case that has been put to us by welfare groups and community organisations arguing that all penalties should be imposed in the form of rate reduction rather than in the form of non‐payment. The amendments that we have before the committee reflect that suggestion. We will be moving amendments which ensure that all breaches—be they activity test breaches or administrative breaches—are served by way of a reduction in the rate of payment rather than the alternative non‐payment period.

The opposition propose that payments be reduced by 16 per cent, which is slightly higher than the current withholding rate of 14 per cent. Under this regime, people's payments would be reduced for 26 weeks for a first breach, which is a very long reminder to any individual, and by 39 weeks for a second or any subsequent breach, an even longer reminder. The beauty of this regime is that the capacity for significant savings remains for the government, but it does not cause the same level of hardship on unemployed people in the community. That is of fundamental importance as far as the Labor Party is concerned.

Part 3 also introduces a period of rate reduction instead of non‐payment periods for administrative breaches. We support this measure in principle, as I have indicated before. But we believe that the proposed rate reduction of 25 per cent is too harsh. We have proposed a regime of 16 per cent reduction for 13 weeks rather than a 25 per cent reduction for eight weeks. The same principle applies to those current administrative breaches destined to become activity test breaches under part 4 of schedule 5.

I remind the chamber that we received very compelling evidence from welfare groups, such as the Welfare Rights Network and ACOSS, that people serving long breach penalty periods were really left with very little option in terms of their survival. The options that were presented to us were pretty simple and very stark: beg, borrow or steal. In that spirit the opposition proposes the amendments that stand in our name. By no means and never will we be willing to be placed in a position of accepting any rorting or fraud in the social security system. The Labor Party can honestly say we have a very strong record in government in that regard.

Part 5 of schedule 5 extends the non‐payment period for moving to an area of lower employment prospects from 12 weeks to 26 weeks. We believe that this is an extremely harsh measure on the part of this government. An extremely unfair measure is being proposed. It really does not take account of the whole range of reasons why an unemployed person may seek to move home. We certainly seek to omit that part from the schedule.

I say to the government, again, that they went to the election indicating that they would protect the poor, the needy and the vulnerable in our community. We have heard the government say that since the election time and again. At the end of the day, when you are bringing legislation before the parliament that is about ripping the guts out of the social security safety net—over $1½ billion in this bill alone—the colours of the government are really nailed to the mast.

Yes, we believe in tight, proper fraud control and compliance measures. We are very fair dinkum about that. We will not tolerate rorting of the social security system. We want to see fair measures in place. We will not ever accept the measures that are being proposed by the government, which we believe are absolutely unconscionable, particularly as the government has, as I have indicated, abandoned the concept of a job compact and a reciprocal obligation to unemployed people. I commend the approach of the Labor opposition to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —One struggles to keep up sometimes. Maybe lunch is the problem; I am not sure.
—Was it a good lunch?

—Yes, it was. However, let me address on the running sheet item No. 9, and then the others which may be involved, by speaking to schedule 5 part 3—Green amendments 10 to 52 and ALP amendments 14 to 54. I will give comprehensive attention to those so that I will not need to continually interrupt the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: We are dealing with the activity test and penalty periods. This part of the bill makes a number of changes to both the length and the means of imposing penalty periods on unemployed people who breach their activity test or do not meet the administrative requirements of their payment.

Looking firstly at activity test breaches: the bill will change the penalty period for such breaches to six weeks for a first breach and to 13 weeks for any subsequent breaches. Currently, the penalty for a first breach is between two and six weeks and subsequent breaches attract a penalty of the previous breach period plus six weeks.

The system of penalties proposed in this bill does have the advantage of placing an upper limit of 13 weeks on the length of any single penalty period, whereas at present there is no upper limit. As most people only breach once, however, the proposal has the disadvantage that it will increase the average penalty period unemployed people are faced with from 3.7 weeks to 6.8 weeks.

As the Welfare Rights Centre pointed out at the community affairs inquiry, a six‐week penalty equates to a loss of nearly $1,200 income for the unemployed person and a 13‐week penalty equates to the loss of just over $2,500 for subsequent breaches. Welfare Rights also pointed out that these losses are far greater than the fines imposed for offences such as common assault, assault causing bodily harm, stealing from a person, malicious destruction of property and driving under the influence of alcohol.

People who have such a penalty imposed on them will be thrown into total financial chaos. They will not be able to maintain stable accommodation, they will not be able to keep a car in good running order and will not even be able to meet basic living costs.

I am reminded of the debate we had a couple of days ago in which one of the welfare agencies—probably the most significant one in emergency relief—the Salvation Army, pointed out that they could not see how, even with an additional $24 million, they would be able to meet the cost of $1.8 billion being slashed from the social security budget.
