Since then of course the voice of the Reverend Tim Costello, the Treasurer's brother, has been added to that voice and he has underlined the fact that welfare agencies will simply be unable to meet the effect of what we will do here today if we agree to the government's proposal. So I think we need to underline that.

Ironically and counterproductively, the effect of that financial chaos will be to severely impair their ability—that is, the people who are the objects of these penalty periods—to continue to look for work. Surely that is not the government's intention.

The Democrats simply cannot support allowing the Department of Social Security—the department charged with the responsibility of alleviating poverty, I would have thought—to throw so many people into abject poverty. We will be supporting the Green and ALP amendments which will soften these penalties for activity test breaches.

Turning now to the changes to the administrative breaches, the bill seeks to replace the system of total payment withdrawal for administrative breaches with a system of partial payment withdrawal. In other words, rather than lose their payment entirely for two weeks, the person will have a 25 per cent reduction in their payment for eight weeks. The Democrats support this change and I think we could give the government a tick for introducing it. We believe such a system is also appropriate for activity test breaches and note that the ALP and Green amendments will establish that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —This is pretty tough stuff. It means that some people who breach the activity test could be without income for six months. I ask the minister to correct me if I am wrong. That means some people who will not have the money in the kitty could be without an income in dire circumstances and will be left on the scrap heap.

SPEECH.PARA: I know the minister has said that $20 million‐plus extra will go to charitable organisations to help meet the cost of these people banging on their door but I do not think that is very good social policy. The minister is shaking her head. If that is not the case, maybe she could explain why extra money is going to charitable foundations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did—in the Senate this week.

—What will happen to those people who just do not have the income to make ends meet? The Greens reluctantly agree that there has to be some system to catch up with and make it clear to those people who abuse the system that they cannot do it with impunity—and most Australians would agree with that.

SPEECH.PARA: But to put people in a situation for a long period of time where they simply cannot make ends meet is, let's face it, to ask for an increase in begging on the streets a la America; it is to ask for an increase in petty crime a la broken windows and forced back doors; and it is to certainly ask—and the minister has at least acknowledged this de facto—for bigger queues at the soup kitchens and at the respite houses.

TALK.START.PARA: —No I didn't.

—The minister says she didn't, so she can get up and say `no' to that. The Greens' amendments are a bit more on the side of the people who fall foul of these laws than are the other amendments before the committee. If you look at young people who may be paying $100 a week rent, who are on social security payments but who are found in breach, our 14 per cent deduction in their income would leave them with about $10.70 a day, the Labor Party's 16 per cent would leave them with about $10.25 a day and the government's 25 per cent garnisheeing of their income would leave them with $8 a day. We are getting down to pretty tough stuff.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the government to look at this again. I do not know how many members opposite have found themselves without a quid in their pocket—not just for one day, not just for one week but for six months. You are asking people to start to look at taking some pretty desperate measures. You have got to the point where it is counterproductive. We think that the cost on society is going to be far greater than the savings you think you are going to make out of this.

Let us remember in particular that all these measures are being impelled by the government's own budgetary philosophy. That is where they are coming from. They are not coming from a readjustment for the good of the unemployed or the luckless in our society. It is wrong. You have gone too far.

I hope that the committee will amend these pretty draconian measures being taken against people who are in desperate need of an income, whatever else. Maybe it is a punishment mode that is creeping into this line of social security delivery for defaulters. If it is, the minister ought to think again because it will be counterproductive.

That is why the Greens oppose the government's tack. That is why the Greens have brought forward amendments which are going to leave people with at least some income to make ends meet and not cut them off altogether or not cut so deeply into that income of $8 a day from which they have to feed themselves, clothe themselves, take transport and do all the things that all the rest of us—or at least those of us in this place—simply take for granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —In an effort to expedite the process, perhaps I can now try to respond to everybody at once. I do welcome Senator Woodley's support for the administrative breach reforms. I think it is a step in the right direction. I urge the chamber to support those reforms.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Brown is revisiting a debate that we had the other day. I thought I had made it quite clear in the Senate—I am sorry that he did not recognise this—that I was poorly reported on the issue of welfare agencies and that the government was making additional payments available to welfare agencies as a recognition of the existing problems they are having trying to support people in poverty and in difficult situations. Our extra funding is independent of anything to do with this legislation. There is not a connection between this legislation and then providing money to the welfare organisations. It is a recognition of the need that they are in now. A reassessment of the formula, which is overdue, has been promised as well.

The savings in this measure are very substantially to come from voluntary compliance. Senator Brown has perhaps ignored the fact that we are talking here about the activity test breaching and not the administrative breaches which I just referred to with Senator Woodley. We are talking about the activity test breaching. We are talking about people who deliberately breach the provisions of the legislation. The community does expect the law to be upheld, whatever kind of law it is.

If I can talk now about the ALP and the Greens' amendments on the activity test breach penalties, because there are significant policy and technical difficulties with the proposed amendments. As we have advised the opposition, continuing breaching of the activity test by the unemployed is more than a payment issue. It gets to the broad and the essential qualifications on issues. It is as central as whether someone is still really unemployed and whether they are qualified for any payment. Because if they are employed and they are not declaring their earnings, they are clearly in breach and cannot start to be eligible.

TALK.START.PARA: —If that is a serious technical point, you could bring back a technical bill at a later date.

—I would have been very happy to have found accommodation with you if I had had your amendments early enough. We could have talked you through why there was a technical problem and reached a position on how they could best be addressed, but the time limit was too short. We certainly from the Democrats the courtesy of sufficient time to study their amendments. But you know your amendments came in only yesterday morning for debate yesterday afternoon.
—The debate on this bill only started this morning.
—We started this debate yesterday.
—I am sorry, the committee stage actually started today.

—Do you want me to speed up or not? A very large proportion of activity breaches last year came as a result of breaches of labour market programs. Senator Faulkner was talking about the reciprocal arrangements that were in place between the unemployed person and the society. Those reciprocal arrangements still remain. Whether it is labour market programs as under the previous government or whether it is the reforms to the labour market programs which are coming in with the new government, case management and commitment to activity testing under the new regime will still continue. People will still be expected—in return for the right to access unemployment benefits—to commit themselves to maintaining the requirements of the Social Security Act.

SPEECH.PARA: But the ALP and the Greens' amendments could lead to the situation where an unemployed person chose to take a 16 per cent ongoing cut in payment. Contrary to the second reading amendment from Senator Faulkner yesterday, the amendments demonstrate that they are not serious about the tight activity testing. The rhetoric is there but the follow‐through is not because—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's outrageous.

—It is a fact. You consider it, Senator. Your proposal of 16 per cent would allow unemployed people to lie on the beach and not undertake any job search in return for a small loss of payment. In other words, if people are prepared to take a lower standard of living, 16 per cent lower, they could continue to access unemployment benefits at the expense of their neighbours—indefinitely, one presumes, because they would not be in breach. Some unemployed people—I am not suggesting by any means the majority—may assess this to be reasonable if they do not need to meet any job search requirements. I think the people outside the chamber and the people in the gallery now who are the people paying for the social security system would find abhorrent the prospect of unemployed people being able to reduce their work efforts and still have their income support from the taxpayer.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor is also aware that their amendments have some technical flaws which are quite major. I understand that Senator Faulkner and his office are well aware of that. As I said earlier, I would have been very happy to give more serious consideration to their amendments if the time had been made available for us to work through these together.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your problem? Is it the technical problem or are you just bucketing us?
—No, I am not. Your amendments, for example—
—Make up you mind.
—Would you like me to tell you what some of the problems are with your amendments?
—Just keep reading the script.

—They will not cover voluntary unemployment, unemployment due to misconduct, failure to comply with a newstart activity agreement—the agreement between the unemployed person and the state; surely the failure to comply with a newstart activity agreement is pretty basic to that—or failure to enter into a newstart activity agreement. Those are very serious matters which your amendments do not cover. I have urged your office to give consideration to the fact that your amendments have technical flaws.

SPEECH.PARA: We cannot support those deficient amendments. They would remove penalties for some very clear breaches which I think all of us in this chamber would regard as serious breaches. There would be unforeseen consequences as a result of your amendments which I do not think you would endorse if you really thought about it. They would encourage people to disregard the work test requirements in some instances for the small penalty of loss of payment. They would allow people who willingly and continually disregard the activity test to continue on payment even though they do not meet the basic requirement of looking for work to get any payment.

I would hope that Senator Faulkner would take me at my word on this and would be prepared to withdraw his amendments. If he is prepared to do that, I am willing to offer an alternative to the committee which may be agreeable to all parties. I foreshadow that I would move an option which would provide for a rate reduction for a first breach of activity test and the second and subsequent breach would still be seen as the most serious breach of all. As Senator Brown said earlier—it might have been Senator Woodley—not as many people would move on to a second and subsequent breach. Certainly, people who are repeat breaches of the law should be given more serious treatment by the law.

We would propose that, for a first activity breach, there should be a 20 per cent rate reduction over 25 weeks. That equates to a full reduction of five weeks. For the second and subsequent breach there should be eight weeks of non-payment. I urge the committee to listen seriously to that proposal. I recognise that there is concern around the chamber about people being off all benefits entirely, and I recognised that by changing the payment arrangements for administrative breaches to be a rate reduction. I am concerned, however, that the amendments as they have arrived in the committee from the opposition will mean that there are a whole lot of quite serious breaches which will get through to the keeper which most of us would not endorse at all. I urge consideration of that option.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind senators that there have been some informal suggestions as to the timing arrangements for the handling of these particular schedules. Schedule 5 was to have been completed by 2.45 p.m. However, they are informal arrangements and it is up to senators to determine how they spend that time bearing in mind that the time for debate for this bill concludes at 5.52 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I more than anyone understand the constraints that we have on us because of the informal arrangements. Therefore, I will be very brief. I have accepted Senator Newman's advice about the technical difficulties. I did it by way of an interjection which was acknowledged by the minister when she made that clear previously. As far as I am concerned, the opposition would ensure that if there were such technical difficulties we would deal with any legislation in very short order through the parliamentary processes and that would fix the technical problems.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, Senator Newman's contribution is all wrapped up in the same sort of rhetoric as we are starting to get very used to hearing from her. She equated the opposition's suggestion of a 16 per cent rate reduction to lying on the beach. As I work it out, a 16 per cent rate reduction is about $30. That leaves you living on $130 a week for all the bare essentials of life: rent, food, clothing, utilities and living expenses. I ask Senator Newman: could you do it?

We then had Senator Newman deciding to wax lyrical about the fact that the opposition circulated only yesterday morning amendments for a committee stage debate that started today, but she then had the extraordinary hypocrisy to put another proposition on the table—an amendment that I have not seen circulated in the chamber. No-one has seen it circulated in the chamber, have they, Senator Newman? How dare you be so hypocritical as to accuse others in that way!

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner, I ask you to withdraw the word `hypocrite'. It is unparliamentary.

—I withdraw it but I do make the point that it is extraordinary for a minister to accuse an opposition of giving not enough notice for her and her department. With all the resources of the Department of Social Security and the resources of her office behind her she suggests that 24 hours notice is not enough to look at an opposition amendment and then floats something in the chamber today in the manner that she has.

SPEECH.PARA: Now that you have laid it on the table, Minister, if the opposition amendment goes down, the amendment that you have foreshadowed will certainly be an improvement on the proposals contained within the bill. If the opposition is faced with a choice between the proposals in the bill, proposals that you previously said were ones you could not move away from, and the amendment you have foreshadowed, that amendment is preferable. But do not put words into the opposition's mouth.

This is an opposition that has been fair dinkum about ensuring that we have an appropriate social security safety net in this country. But it has also been fair dinkum about ensuring that we do not have a system that in any way is compromised by allegations of fraud or rorting. We did a lot when we were in government. We have done a lot that has been acknowledged, Senator Newman, sometimes even by people in your own party—and you nod and agree—and not least also by those who are more objective such as Professor Weatherly who has made international comparisons with the fraud and compliance mechanisms in Australia's social security system.

Senator Newman, I notice that since I have been on my feet the galleries have been swelling; the small numbers listening to you have been growing and that is proof positive as far as I am concerned of the level of support in the Australian community for the arguments I am presenting to the committee today. The points I make are substantive. I am not going to stand here and have the Labor Party misrepresented by you and I am not going to be given a lecture about Senate process by you. Given that you have said that you believe you can do a bit better than you did in the bill, if Labor's amendments to schedule 5 go down, that that is a preferred option for the opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will move to schedules 6, 7, 10, 11 and 12.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to schedule 6, very briefly let me say that the Labor Party believes that the measures contained in schedule 6 to tighten industrial action provisions to ensure that where a person is unemployed as a result of industrial action the person will not be eligible for payment for six weeks after the industrial action has ceased are not only absolutely unreasonable but ideologically driven on the part of the government.

SPEECH.PARA: Our concerns are detailed very fully in the minority report that the opposition previously tabled in the parliament. Let me say very clearly so there can be no doubt about it: we believe that this proposal does not take sufficiently into account the new industrial relations regime that has been created by this government through the workplace relations legislation that the Senate gave so much attention to in the recent past. We believe this proposal is unreasonable; we believe it is unworkable; and we believe it is untenable. We state very clearly that this is unduly harsh. For that reason we propose removing schedule 6 from the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to move Democrat amendments 15 to 18 which seek to bring this matter in line—
—Senator Woodley, you do not have to move those amendments. We are considering the bill as a whole and they may be moved at the end.

—I rise on a point of order to assist Senator Woodley and the committee. I hope it is appreciated around the chamber that it is for that reason that I have not formally proposed my amendments. I think that is within the spirit of what we are doing.

—I particularly want to speak to the amendments which are to do with unemployment due to industrial action. The explanatory memorandum states that this schedule of the bill will ensure that where a person is unemployed as a result of industrial action, and that action has ceased, the person may not qualify for unemployment payments for a period of six weeks from the date the action ceased.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of witnesses to the community affairs inquiry stressed that in the current economic climate workers do not normally become involved in industrial action without reasonable cause. We agree with that and as such we believe that this provision should apply only in circumstances where the strike action is in direct breach of an order or direction of an industrial authority. I indicate that if our amendments in this regard are not successful we will be voting against the schedule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens here part company with the Australian Democrats. Again, it gets down to a matter of conscience. What we are going to see inevitably is people deterred from taking what, in their conscience, is legitimate industrial action in an increasingly difficult climate for industrial action created by the workplace relations bill, which was passed through here with the weight of the numbers of the Democrats and the government. Here is back‐door penalisation for people who would stand up for their rights on a matter of conscience or even get involved in industrial action which is in pursuit of a matter of very clear importance to the union or workplace in which they are involved.

SPEECH.PARA: What is done here? They lose their jobs as a result, whether they are at the centre of this action or swept up in it, and a six‐week penalty no‐income clause is being inserted by the Democrats or the government, whichever one you look at. It is wrong. Where is the court of appeal on this? There is none. A $1,000 penalty on‐the‐spot fine because you got involved in industrial action! I think it is pretty tough. I think the Democrats should think again.

The appeal for them to think again about the industrial relations legislation, when it was here with its draconian secondary boycott provisions and substrike provisions, which will leave many people in the Australian workplace subject to summary loss of wages even if they engage in a work to rules campaign over a matter of high principle to them and conscience, is now being backed up by this piece of proposed legislation, which means people who are caught in a strike, involved in a strike or motivating a strike on a matter of importance to them and who will lose their job as a result will suddenly have nowhere to go and no income to get.

`It does not matter what their circumstances are,' say the Democrats and government. Six weeks with nothing. We are talking about breadwinners here. We are talking about people who will not have money in the bank. We are not talking about silvertails; we are talking about people who are living in very tough circumstances and who have just gone through the roller coaster of industrial action over a matter which is important to them.

I think that the Democrats should think again. It does not fit in with what we have heard of Democrat social policy. It is not socially just. I would add to that that many people who get involved in industrial action and lose their jobs as a result do not know that this penalty is waiting for them as well. They will then find out, if this clause gets through, that due to Democrat and coalition legislation, they have a summary $1,000 fine waiting for them in terms of a six‐week wait until they can get some social security.

I support the option of the Greens and Labor on this. Obviously, we are not going to have the numbers at the end of the day. That, again, revisits the day in which the workplace relations legislation went through. It is pretty shameful. I think that the Democrats should think again.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question to the minister in relation to schedule 6, and it goes to the question of stand‐downs. If a worker is working in a workplace where another union has taken industrial action and that worker is stood down as a result of that industrial action—it is not the worker's union involved and the worker himself or herself has not taken the industrial action—which is very common in the industrial relations system, at the end of that period, if that person who was stood down or that group of workers who were stood down lose their jobs, are they regarded as being voluntarily unemployed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —While the minister is seeking an answer I wish to respond to Senator Brown. I really do not want to take up a lot of time, but he did waffle on to a large degree. He asked me to listen to what he was saying and think again. He obviously took no account of what I said.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats' amendment in this case is simply to, in a very narrow area, allow the breach to apply. In all other cases, the Democrats are opposed to the government action. That simply is in the area where in fact a strike is in breach of the umpire's decision. It is only in that case that a penalty period could apply. If the government is not prepared to accept that amendment, of course we will vote against the schedule, as other opposition parties are doing. I just wanted to add that explanation in case the committee or those listening took any account of what Senator Brown was saying, which really misrepresented the position of the Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, as you would expect, I will be opposing this schedule. But I do want to indicate that I would like to commend Senator Woodley and the Australian Democrats for proposing an amendment upon which decisions could be made which would be fair and able to be tested.

SPEECH.PARA: There is some certainty in these particular amendments. Certainly, they are well crafted and they do have a basis in principle that I think the government should see. If the government does not see the merit of these provisions, then they are faced with the inevitable—that the clause will be excised, as indicated by Senator Woodley.

However, I think honourable senators should have a very good look at these proposed amendments. As I read them, it would be fairly unlikely, with people acting in accordance with the industrial relations principles that are accepted all round, that anyone would be penalised.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not be opposing the Australian Democrats' proposed amendments, although, as I have said to some senators privately, we believe that they will be difficult and complex to administer. Having said that, we will do our best to administer them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to schedule 7, the opposition's view is that we do not want to see people left without payments for inordinate or indefinite periods of time, nor do we think it fair that people are left to run down their savings. Further, we are concerned that the replacement of an annual leave waiting period with an income maintenance period will increase rather than reduce the complexity of the administration of the social security system. For those reasons, Labor will be seeking to amend that schedule.

SPEECH.PARA: Our proposed amendments ensure that there would be no retrospectivity; in other words, they will ensure that the measure applies to leave accrued only after 20 August. The proposed amendments also ensure that the income maintenance period is served at the same time as the liquid assets test rather than being consecutive, as is the case now.

With respect to the income maintenance period, the opposition's proposed amendments do three things. Firstly, they cap it at 13 weeks. It is currently uncapped, as I understand it. Secondly, they count money paid for leave accrued only after 20 August, which relates to the retrospectivity issue I spoke about. Thirdly, they ensure that the income maintenance waiting period and liquid assets waiting period can be served concurrently.

PARA.BREAK: For the liquid assets waiting period, our proposed amendments restore the minimum reserve amounts to their current levels. The government is proposing that these reserves be cut in half, which would force people to run down their savings even more. The proposed amendments substitute the fixed dollar amount in the divisor with reference to average weekly earnings. This establishes the principle that people should use up their resources at the rate of average weekly earn ings, as I think occurs with compensation, as an example.

SPEECH.PARA: ALP proposed amendments 72 to 79 restore the liquid assets limits to $10,000 and $5,000 and replace the liquid assets devisor with average weekly earnings. As I have indicated, we do not want to see people left without payment for inordinate or indefinite periods of time. We do not believe that it is fair for people to be forced to run down their savings. Therefore, we will be seeking to restore the current liquid assets limit to $10,000 for couples and $5,000 for singles by omitting the relevant items.

We have indicated that, as a matter of principle, people should use up their savings at the rate of average weekly earnings. I commend the opposition's proposals in relation to this schedule to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —The principle upon which the government is proposing this matter is that when somebody receives a lump sum on termination of employment, or accrued leave, long service leave, et cetera, it is reasonable to expect that person to support himself or herself from the savings as an income replacement before claiming income support from fellow taxpayers. I think I heard Senator Faulkner indicate that that principle was broadly supported.

SPEECH.PARA: However, many people who are retrenched do have families. They have mortgages. They have consumer debts. They might have a credit card bill of several thousands of dollars. When a person receives a lump sum and applies it to clearing such debt, he or she does not have the income replacement amount to live on.

I am seeking from the minister clarification as to a specific statutory authority that, where a person receives a lump sum for unused leave, et cetera, on termination of employment, the waiting period for unemployment benefit or any other social security benefit—not just special benefit but any other social security benefit—should be based on the net amount available, not the gross amount where the gross amount has been reduced by being applied to the reduced pre-existing indebtedness. In other words, why should the worker not be able to clear the debts, for example, and thus have the net income available for the purposes of the application of the waiting period?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Harradine, if a person receives a redundancy payment, that amount is not included in the calculations.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought you said when they were taking a redundancy. I was just, if you like, gratuitously adding that to the information. If somebody is applying for benefits and they have debts as well as liquid assets and savings, they may in fact reduce the amount of their indebtedness, whether it be in terms of a credit card or a mortgage, et cetera, with their liquid assets. Therefore, it is their net worth that is taken into account by the department in assessing their entitlement to benefits.

—I do want to get this absolutely clear. It will be the net amount. That is to say, if a worker applies the income that has been received by way of accrued annual leave, accrued long service leave, et cetera, to redeem a debt, is it or is it not the fact—and this is a very simple yes or no—that it is the net sum that is then taken into account for the purpose of a waiting period for unemployment benefit or in fact for entitlement to any other social security benefit? That is simply what I am asking.
—Nothing in social security is simple, Senator. Just wait a second so I can give you something very precise.

—The Greens oppose this because, if you become unemployed and have fewer than $5,000 in the bank, you cannot get benefits. The government is lowering the level you can have in the bank to $2½ thousand. If you happen to be married, or if you are part of a couple, if you have a partnership, whereas it was $10,000 it becomes $5,000. The clear intent is to remove the money out of the bank before you get unemployment benefits.

BREAK.PARA: Again, this does not take into account the circumstances of the people who are involved. We do know they are likely to have suddenly become unemployed. We do not know what other liabilities they have. It is tough enough that the limits which exist are there already, but they are just being arbitrarily hard.

It would be good to know from the minister—we do not have time, and we would not get a clear answer on this anyway—why it was halved. Why not abolish it altogether? Why go from $5,000 to $2½ thousand? It is because the government is meeting a budgetary target. It is taking money out of people's small savings to meet that target. That is what is happening here.

Again, it is handing $800 million across this year in diesel fuel rebates and tax rebates to a handful of big companies but, at the same time, it has decided there are some little savings in the banks of the people who are struggling. So for those who are suddenly without a job, it is going to take it out of their bank to meet some budgetary requirement that cabinet has decided upon. That is what this move is about. That is why it is wrong. That is why the Greens oppose it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wanted to indicate a couple of things and seek leave to incorporate a couple of speeches so I do not have to hold things up.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows—
Schedule 7
Part 1
Income Maintenance Period
(Democrat amendment 20—oppose the schedule)
This Part seeks to introduce an "income maintenance period".
Under this new waiting period, any annual, long service, maternity and accrued sick leave made to a person when they become unemployed will be treated as income over the period of that leave.

So, if a retrenched person receives 16 weeks worth of leave payments, they'll have a 16‐week Income Maintenance Period and won't be able to claim a Sickness, Newstart, Partner or Parenting Allowance for that period.
Currently, the Department considers only accrued annual leave and there is a maximum waiting period of 4 weeks.

Of great concern to the Democrats was the evidence of the Department presented at the Estimates hearings that in the first year of operation 10% of the 87,000 people who will be effected by this new system will have some of their waiting period waived because they will end up in "financial hardship".

The Department defines a person as in "financial hardship" where they have less than two weeks available funds. As an example, a single person over 21 without dependants is regarded as in hardship if they have less than $320 in liquid assets.
So, what this change will be doing is throwing nearly 10,000 people into absolute poverty.

The need to allow unemployed people to retain some of their savings is heightened by other changes in this Bill which will toughen up activity testing and penalty periods; abolish the Earnings Credit Scheme; and abolish the Employment and Education Entry Payments.
The Democrats will be supporting the ALP amendments to soften the impact of this proposal but I indicate that we will be opposing Schedule 7 in its entirety.
Schedule 7
Part 2
Income Maintenance Period
(Democrat amendment 20—oppose the schedule)
The Bill also seeks to extend the maximum length of the "liquid assets test waiting period".
Under the Government's proposal, a single person with $5,000 in liquid assets will serve the ordinary one week waiting period then a further 5 week liquid assets waiting period.
. . . And a person with $8,500 in liquid assets would serve a 3 month waiting period.
When considering waiting periods, it is important to remember that the average duration of unemployment is currently just under two years during which time people's savings are rapidly eroded.
Welfare agencies report that many of the people who approach them for emergency financial assistance are serving some form of Social Security waiting period.
Again the Democrats will support the ALP amendments to soften the system proposed by the Government but we will be opposing the Part even if these amendments are successful.

TALK.START.PARA: —On schedule 7, I indicate that the Democrats will be supporting the ALP amendments to soften the impact of this proposal, but we will oppose schedule 7 in its entirety. That is part 1 of schedule 7 and relates to the income maintenance period. In relation to part 2 of schedule 7, again, we will support the ALP amendments to try to soften the system proposed by the government, but we will oppose this part in its entirety.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to Senator Harradine. I will try to keep it as clear as I can. In the case of liquid assets, they can be used for debts irrespective of the payment you are claiming and the amounts of your debts. In the case of leave entitlements, they can be used to reduce reasonable debts. If somebody is in hardship a special benefit is available.
—Is paying off a mortgage a reasonable debt?

—Completely paying off your mortgage is not reasonable, but making it so that you can keep your mortgage going is reasonable. I suppose there would be a distinction between a $300,000 mortgage and a $30,000 mortgage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the only way to see things move along a little is if I move to another schedule. I think that might assist the committee. In the spirit of trying to get this going a little, I am proposing to deal with schedules 10 and 11 together.

SPEECH.PARA: I can really make the opposition's case very quickly indeed. We are proposing to omit these schedules from the bill. They are open and shut cases of a breach of an election commitment on the part of the government. In relation to the proposal to restore the earnings credit scheme, the coalition said in their pre‐election policy: `The earnings credit scheme will be retained by a coalition government.' This is nothing more or less than a direct broken coalition promise. It is a betrayal of the Australian people and the electorate. In no way will the Labor Party countenance such an open and shut case of a breach of election commitment.

The same is the case in relation to the employment and education entry payments. The coalition's pre‐election social security policy stated that to assist people to make the transition from being unemployed to work or education, the coalition `will maintain the current employment and education entry payments'. This is absolutely and bare‐facedly a broken promise on the part of this government.

We have indicated absolutely clearly that this is something that we will not tolerate. It obviously falls into Mr Howard's category of non‐core promises—a sort of promise that is made with absolutely no intention on the part of the government to honour it. That is something that the Labor Party will not countenance.

I think these two schedules indicate the level of this government's betrayal in relation to its election commitments. It really did propose to the Australian people that it would take a very different attitude in relation to social security policy. Come the election they dumped it. Come the election they threw the commitments in the waste paper basket. After the election, the promises are not worth the paper they are written on.

This is a disgrace. This is indefensible. The minister should be ashamed of herself for so transparently bringing legislation before this parliament and this chamber that so betrays the commitments that were made to the people before the election campaign. I will be interested to hear your justification of your outrageous behaviour.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling Senator Brown, I remind honourable senators that we are approaching 3.30 p.m. which was the indicative timing for the consideration of schedules 6, 7, 10, 11 and 12. We have completed schedule 10, I understand. I call Senator Brown and ask senators to keep that in mind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal with schedules 10, 11 and 12 quickly. Schedule 10 relates simply to the removal of the earnings credit scheme whereby people who were on social security or pensioners could earn up to $1,050 if single or $2,100 if married from part‐time work before they started to be penalised. It is a great opportunity for people to get outside of the grind of not having a personal income or fulfilment, to do bits of work that would enable them to have a bit of extra pocket money and to be a little more productive as members of society.

SPEECH.PARA: The government comes along, against its own election promises, as Senator Faulkner has said, and is going to clobber it to help its budgetary problems. Then they move on from that to say, `There is this provision of $100 for people who have been unemployed for 12 months or who have been on disability support pensions and so on.' It is a measly $100 to help them with their transition back into work when they find it.

There are considerable costs with getting into work, as we all know, if you are going to be able to do it well. There is a barrier after long-term unemployment with getting into work. The $100 is not a big amount, but the minister through this legislation is going to clobber that altogether.

Then there is the final provision which I do not quite understand, but the minister could enlighten us, I have no doubt. The provision is the one where the government will remove for women over the age pension age eligibility for the grant of a widow allowance and partner allowance respectively.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is ahead of me.
—He is on to 12.
—I am taking 12 here as well now. It has the alarm bells flashing.
—They're not. It's really a very good package.

—I know, but the bells are behind you, Minister. You cannot see them. They are flashing for me. Everything is rosy over there for you. I just wonder which way the widows are looking, so maybe you could explain that to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I asked you a question earlier and I sought advice from the departmental officials with regard to the position of stand‐downs. I think you might have been distracted previously. I appreciate that and it is fine, but this is a very important question. I am just concerned that this group of people may inadvertently fall through the net.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sorry, but this issue actually refers back to schedule 6. It refers to a group of workers who are involuntarily stood down as a result of the action of another group of workers. If they lose their job as a consequence of that industrial action, is that regarded as voluntarily leaving or involuntarily leaving?

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I am sorry I did not answer you before. I remember you did ask that. The answer that I have for you is that members of the same union who have been stood down as a result of the industrial action will be subjected to benefit preclusion, but members of another union will not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate speeches on schedules 10 and 11 and then to indicate what the Democrats will be doing.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—
Schedule 10
Earnings Credit Scheme:
(amendment 21—oppose the schedule)
The Earnings Credit Scheme currently allows unemployed people and pensioners to earn a small amount of income without affecting their Social Security payment.
This scheme is a very valuable one to unemployed people and, in recognition of that, the Coalition's Social Security election policy document specifically stated:
"The Earnings Credit Scheme will be retained by a Coalition Government."
Now the Government has changed its tune and argues that, due to its complexity, the scheme should be abolished.

When the scheme was first extended to allowees the Democrats pleaded with the then Labor Govern ment and the Liberal/National Opposition to support some amendments we were putting up to simplify the scheme.
We always felt this was a marvellous scheme that was going to be hamstrung by its complexity and here we are, just a couple of years later, trying to abolish the scheme for that very reason.
Abolition of the scheme will be a disincentive to people to seek to earn income from outside work and that would be a great shame.

Full-time employment often results from part-time or casual work but with the abolition of the scheme the unemployed will be less likely to take up casual work opportunities that might come their way for fear of losing their payments.
People may very well not understand the mechanics of the scheme but they certainly do realise that it allows them to earn some income from outside work without effecting their payments.
The success of the scheme is evidenced by the level of savings the Government hopes to achieve through its abolition.
The Democrats support the Earnings Credit Scheme and, therefore, will not be supporting this schedule.
Schedule 11
Employment and Education Entry Payments
(amendment 22—oppose the schedule)
This schedule will abolish the Employment and Education Entry Payments.
Through the Employment Entry Payment long-term unemployed people can receive a payment of $100 and pensioners of up to $300 to help meet the costs of taking up a new employment position.
This money is particularly useful to help meet costs such as buying new clothes or equipment which might be needed in a new position.
Similarly, the Education Entry Payment provides up to $200 to assist with some of the up-front costs of entering education including, for example, buying new textbooks or paying student union fees.
In the Coalition's Social Security election document it specifically stated, and I quote:
"To assist people to make the transition from being unemployed to work or education, the Coalition will maintain the current employment and education entry payments."
The Democrats do not believe the Government should be allowed to break this election promise and we will not be supporting this schedule.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats support the earnings credit scheme and therefore will not be supporting schedule 10. In relation to schedule 11, the Democrats do not believe the government should be allowed to break the election promise in relation to employment and education entry payments, and we will not be supporting this schedule either.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Brown asked me about the widow and partner allowance changes. Currently there is no upper age limit on access to widow and partner allowance. I just noticed that Senator Brown is not in the chamber, so I do not suppose there is much point in giving him the answer now. I will wait and give it to him later, if I may.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I make a comment on the same schedule—schedule 12—and by that time Senator Brown might be back. I indicate on behalf of the opposition, as I think the government is aware, that we support a very large part of this schedule. I think these are changes that make administrative sense. We do have serious concerns about the unintended consequences of the measure, particularly for migrant women. It is for that reason that we will be seeking to omit items 19, 26 and 27 of the schedule from the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: By doing this, alternative payments to the special benefit will still be available to women over age pension age who cannot, because of residency conditions, claim the age pension. I think this will protect women who otherwise would fall through the cracks. That is the approach that the opposition is taking, and the minister might care to comment on that in her response. It does not help the minister much because Senator Brown is still not here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw Senator Brown going in the opposite direction as Senator Faulkner spoke, so other senators can have the answer that I have been supplied with by the officials. Currently there is no upper age limit on access to the widow and partner allowance. This is to allow people on these payments to continue receiving payment until they qualify for age pension, at age pension age or later, on residence grounds. This also allows for the widow allowance or partner allowance to be granted to people over age pension age. There is nothing to indicate that this was specifically intended when these allowances were established.

SPEECH.PARA: The measures proposed in the bill currently before the parliament will allow those already receiving these allowances, when they reach age pension age, to transfer to age pension whether or not they meet age pension residency requirements. This will simplify arrangements for older people, and I would have thought we would all endorse that.

Given that the widow allowance and partner allowance are non-activity tested payments made instead of newstart allowance to recognise the labour market disadvantages of these groups, there is no rationale for granting them after age pension age. Indeed, doing so can only be highly discriminatory on the basis of gender and marital status without any reason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate very quickly in relation to schedule 12 that the Democrats will be supporting part 1 of schedule 12. I have been on this campaign in support of the widows allowance and a liberalisation of that for a long time. In terms of part 4 of schedule 12, the Democrats will not support that. In terms of part 5 of schedule 12, the Democrats will be supporting the ALP and the Greens in opposing the relevant items. I seek leave to incorporate speeches on that.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—
Schedule 12
Widows and Partners
- Part 4
(amendment 23—oppose the part)
I would just quickly like to indicate the very strong support of the Democrats for the amendments contained in Part 1 of schedule 12.
This part extends eligibility to the Widow Allowance to those women over 50 years of age, who were widowed, separated or divorced after they turned 40.
The Democrats have been pushing for a relaxation of the qualification criteria on the Widow Allow ance for just on two years now—ever since the payment was first introduced.
We don't see today's amendment as the be-all-and-end-all in regards to assistance to widows but we certainly see it as a great step forward.

This change will assist many of the women who have contacted my office and I pay tribute to those women—particularly Alma Lester and Elly Reddick from Rockhampton—for continuing to lobby for change to the allowance.
It will not assist all the widows who have contacted me, however, and I urge the Government to continue looking at the position of Australia's widows.
I note there is an inquiry being undertaken into the phasing out of the Widow B Pension which will report to the Minister sometime this month and I will be following that carefully.
Turning to Part 4 of this schedule, this part will bring forward the final phase out date of the Widow B Pension by establishing that there will be no new grants of it after the 20th of March 1997.
This is likely to affect around 2,500 women in 1997-98 which is the first full year of implementation.
As I just mentioned, however, there is an inquiry being conducted into the Widow B Pension which I understand will report very shortly.
It seems premature to be speeding up the phase out of the pension when that inquiry has not even reported.
Without the benefit of that inquiry's findings, the Democrats are not inclined to support any moves which would reduce support available to Australia's widows.
Schedule 12
Widows and Partners
- Part 5
(ALP amendment 83—same as Greens 58 & 59)
The Democrats will be supporting the ALP and the Greens on this issue and opposing the relevant items.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address some issues raised in schedule 10 and 11, and I will do that concurrently and as briefly as possible. As I think perhaps most senators would now realise, one of the issues in relation to the earnings credit scheme has been its low take-up rate by the people. Although there are nearly four million customers potentially who could access the scheme, only about three per cent of those actually accessed the earnings credit scheme over a year.

SPEECH.PARA: That is despite the constant endeavours of the department over quite a long period of notification to people on unemployment benefits of the availability of the scheme and what it could mean to them. I say `constant' because they get quarterly newsletters from the department which spell out their entitlement and encourage them to take up the opportunities that are available to them. It has been extremely complex for the department to administer but, more importantly perhaps, it is very complicated for people who are entitled to actually understand what they may be entitled to—even having been told about it. Then only three per cent actually bother to take it up.

The government has sought as far as possible to maintain the spirit of our commitment to protect the more vulnerable. Customers who access the earnings credit scheme are by definition receiving income above the income test free areas. Abolishing the scheme therefore does not affect the most vulnerable customers.

The aim of the scheme is important too. The aim was: to provide an incentive for customers to supplement their social security benefits by undertaking work wherever it was possible. Our research has shown that there is a limited understanding, as I have said. Moreover, the additional incentive to take up work is no longer considered necessary—and this is, to me, one of the most telling arguments of all. In the middle of last year, the previous government introduced new income test arrangements for allowees which included the removal of the 100 per cent withdrawal rate, the abolition of the joint income test and the introduction of a partner income test—which already provide a significant incentive for allowees to take up work opportunities. People who tell you that there is not an incentive in the system are in fact referring to what it was before July last year.

The existing pension income test has a higher free area than allowances and more relaxed arrangements, meaning that customers are better off working, even without access to any earnings credit. So that now applies to both pensioners and those on allowances. The earnings credit scheme advantages those who have a one‐off employment or investment windfall but it provides no ongoing benefit to those with longer‐term employment. I would urge you to consider that.

In addition, I would urge you to consider the importance of the measure in financial terms because it is very costly to administer, as I said. The savings in this area would be: $20.6 million in the first year and $75.8 million, $79.5 and $83 million in subsequent years—making a total of $258.9 million. So although it is a small number of people who have accessed it it has cost us a great deal to administer, out of all proportion, I would suggest, to the benefits which the scheme has produced.

In terms of the employment entry payment and the education entry payment, we have been very careful to make sure that sole parents, who have been the main ones to access the education entry payment, have that right preserved. So pensioners are in fact still able to access the education entry payment, but the employment entry payment and the education entry payment for people on allowances are being removed.

One of the things which senators are perhaps not alert to is the fact that recipients will continue to also have access to the advance facility to assist them to meet any up‐front or employment costs—that is the loans scheme. In total terms, it is more beneficial than the employment and education entry payment. Under the advance scheme, they can get more money than they could under this scheme which is proposed to be abolished.

In addition, there are provisions for funding through DEET under Senator Vanstone's proposals for access to employment to help people take up employment. In both departments there are still opportunities for people to access assistance to take up employment. The savings on the employment entry payment over four years will be $59.4 million and $7.2 million on the education entry payment. So we are talking about substantial contributions to the government's budget task, and I would urge senators to take that into account when they consider these motions.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the minister directly: in relation to the earnings credit scheme and the employment and education entry payments, why did the coalition deceive the electorate in indicating categorically that they would be maintained?

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am prepared to put once again on the record, if you really want to use up more time, that we inherited a $10 billion deficit, a $10 billion that had to be dealt with if this country is actually to get into a state where more people will be able to get jobs. They will not be getting jobs through the money that is handed out through social security; they will be getting jobs through small business, particularly in this country, which has the opportunity to invest and to take people on. They will do that by the nation being seen to have a credible economy and good management of its national accounts. That is the task that was set before us when we came into government, despite the situation we were told aboout during the election.

—I wish to speak to schedule 13. The problem we have with it is that the Greens oppose the government's move to remove the reference to changes in the disability impairment tables. A complicated alternative is being put forward by Senator Allison on behalf of the Australian Democrats. We need to hear about it, as obviously they have the potential numbers to have sway here. We have not had time to analyse it. The Greens are particularly concerned about this section. It affects the income of people with disabilities. It is very important that that not be changed lightly. It will remove money from their pockets. I do not know that the government understands yet what the Australian Democrats alternative is. That said, the Greens are opposed to this move. With that, we can see some benefit in the amendment that the Democrats propose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak to the Australian Democrats amendments Nos 1 to 44. As I said in my speech in the second reading debate, the Democrat amendments to schedule 13 were put together in conjunction with people with a wealth of experience in the area of disabilities. We believe that the adoption of these amendments would greatly improve the legislation and much more closely reflect the real life experiences of people who have disabilities. They address and rectify the following shortfalls in the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The first is the artificially low impairment ratings, which are, without doubt, designed to get as many people as possible off the disability support pension. There is a lack of recognition of the greater effects caused by multiple impairments and an absence of a table to assess chronic pain and fatigue based illnesses. Our amendments also recognise the fact that disability impairment tables are intended to measure a person's work related abilities. Therefore, they should not infringe on an individual's right to choose or reject treatment which they find unsuitable. They also reinstate the tables dealing with musculoskeletal and ear, nose and throat problems.

I draw the Senate's attention to two typographical errors in our amendments. The first is in amendment No. 21 on page 8. In the first paragraph of this amendment, it refers to table 7. That should read table 6. The second is in amendment No. 30 on page 11. The figures 70-70 in the intelligence column should read 70‐79. I apologise for those errors. I commend these amendments to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are considering amendment No. 38 of the running sheet. It is numbered 3 to 44 in Senator Woodley's name.

—The Greens are particularly concerned that the government move is to reduce the number of disabled people on benefits who have a 20 per cent impairment in their ability to get work. It could have a particularly harsh effect on those with acquired brain injury, psychiatric illness or low literacy or language skills. I wonder whether Senator Allison could comment on the amendment she has brought before the committee and the impact the government's move will have on people with such disabilities. Will it cut across what the government is doing and replace it? Will it reduce or increase the number of people with disabilities who have access to social security payments? I would like to know the outcome of the amendment being proposed.

—I will seek advice from my researcher on this. The intention is certainly to reduce the number of people who will be pushed off the disability support pension and on to the unemployment benefit. I will seek advice in a moment to see whether we have done any estimates of the numbers of people in that category.

—I want to know the impact on those categories that I was mentioning, particularly people with acquired brain injury, psychiatric illness and low literacy or language skills. It appears that the government changes will hit those people in particular. I would get some comfort from knowing that the Democrat amendment takes away that impact on those people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to contribute to this matter in the following way. There was a proposal before the previous government that was not a savings measure. It was simply a recognition that the impairment tables needed `finetuning'—I cannot think of another word. Consequences of the impairment tables were not advantageous to people applying for support under the tables and they needed revision.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result, the tables were achieved by careful study by a committee of medical experts in the field of rehabilitation medicine and disabilities. That committee reported to the previous government and the table was neither accepted nor rejected. They just had not got on to doing something about it. When we came into government it was clearly an item that needed to be progressed. It was the normal course of government administration rather than any ideological effort or trying to get disability support people off pensions, as I think one of the senators suggested. I would reject that.

My concern is that the Labor and the Democrat amendments, which inevitably are technical because they relate to an extraordinarily difficult and technical area of our legislation, involve wholesale revision of the proposed tables. They have proved to be virtually impossible to assess properly at such short notice. We could have very unintended consequences, which I do not think anybody in this chamber wants. Certainly, the people with disabilities that we are all most concerned about would be the ones who would suffer from those unintended consequences.

I want to recommend to the committee that we perhaps take a course of action taken by the Labor government in 1986 when Senator Gietzelt was the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and a similar situation arose. He was bringing in a new guide to the assessment of the rates of veterans' pensions, which were based on disability tables as well. There was concern expressed, as concern has been expressed by the parties in the chamber today, about—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not making a speech to Senator Faulkner, are you?
—I am making a pitch to all of you, Senator. It was the outcome in similar circumstances where you do not want to hurt people—
—I thought that would get a reaction from Senator Harradine.

—There was concern then, as there is now, about the impact of something on some of the most vulnerable people, people that we would not want to hurt. As a result, Senator Gietzelt gave an undertaking to the Senate that he would set up a monitoring committee of veterans' organisations and—I think—medical people and report back to the Senate on how the first year or so of the new guide worked in practice. I suggest to the chamber today that that would be a good model for us to follow.

SPEECH.PARA: I would be very, very reluctant to see either the Democrats or the opposition's amendments go through today, because the advice I have had is that we really could make great difficulties for people with disabilities. We just do not know yet what they might be but they could be quite serious. I am very happy and prepared to give a similar undertaking to the chamber to that given by Senator Gietzelt. I would set up a monitoring committee, composed of organisations related to disabled people and also those involved in rehabilitation medicine, to analyse the impairment tables as proposed in the legislation before us. I would undertake to have the government give immediate consideration to a report produced by such a monitoring committee. I would suggest that it would require at least 18 months of analysis of how the tables had worked.

However, I would also suggest to the chamber that we could agree to a sunset clause so that the matter would have to be reconsidered at the end of two years. By that stage we would have the report of the monitoring committee. We would know whether it worked well and whether it should be re‐endorsed or whether it needed more attention. I would rather go down that route than potentially endanger some of the most disabled people in our country. I would be grateful if I could get an indication from other senators about whether they would be prepared to support that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Newman that this is a very difficult issue and complex matter. I accept the point that she makes in that regard. I expect that it would be generally accepted around the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that, as a result of these new impairment tables, people will either lose or not qualify for a disability support pension. There are a couple of areas of particular concern. Some impairments which previously attracted a five or 10 rating now attract a nil rating. The instructions about how the tables are to be used also are of concern—in other words, whether or not a particular disability can be counted under two or more tables. Let me be clear on this. I accept that these are difficult issues and it is important to acknowledge that they are also issues that are generating a lot of concern in the community.

BREAK.PARA: I do not know the reaction that other senators have received, but certainly my office has received a lot of calls on this issue, even as late as nearly midnight last night. You would not expect too many people to expect to find many of us in our offices at that time of night, but people were still ringing about this matter. There is a lot of concern. People really are worried about this schedule.

The Democrats' amendments ameliorate these concerns to some extent. But Senator Newman makes the point to the Senate that in doing so, they also significantly open up the eligibility criteria for the disability support pension. I think that is the point that you make, Senator Newman.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I did not make that point; in fact that is not what I meant. There could well be people disadvantaged—that is the way I put it—by the unforeseen consequences of the amendments of the Democrats or the Labor Party. The worry is that we do not really know.
—I thank Senator Newman for that. I do not want to put words into her mouth but she is indicating she does not know what the consequences of the Democrats' amendments might be.

BREAK.PARA: Obviously, on behalf of the opposition, I am seriously considering our position on the Democrat amendments at the moment, problematic as they might be. It is possible to move amendments on behalf of the opposition to attempt to address or fix these problems. I point out to Senator Newman—and other senators ought to be aware—that no amendments have been circulated by the opposition in the chamber on schedule 13. I obviously would be concerned about any attempt to meddle in this that might have the impact of significantly widening eligibility for DSP.

I note the minister's suggestion that we adopt the approach that Senator Gietzelt took when he was Minister for Veterans' Affairs. And I note that Senator Harradine immediately reacted negatively to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, no, no.
—It is interesting, you know, Senator Harradine, because I immediately reacted positively; that was my first reaction.
—The years mature one's views.

—I am pleased to hear that, Senator Harradine. But the suggestion coming from Senator Newman—let's be serious about it; and I accept that she is, again, faithfully reporting to the Senate what the Gietzelt model is in this respect—is to put these new impairment tables in place and see how they work. Senator Newman is really suggesting that is an appropriate approach.
—For a finite period.

—For a finite period. I wonder, Senator Newman, whether a more sensible approach—if the alternative before us is either the Democrat amendments with possibly a range of unforeseen consequences, and I stress `possibly', or, alternatively, putting these impairment tables in place with the certain knowledge that some of the consequences are very unpalatable—is to withdraw schedule 13 and undertake to consult with others around the chamber on the details of the tables before they are re‐presented to the parliament. And the Senate could acknowledge that it would be reasonable for you to do that quickly and put forward amending legislation in the early part of the next session. That would be a third approach that I think would be a more precautionary approach than the one that you are suggesting.

BREAK.PARA: I hear what you say about the proposed Democrat amendments. I say to the Democrats and Senator Brown, who has a close interest in this issue and has canvassed it already in this debate, that it is difficult in a very constrained committee debate like this to be able to make these sorts of judgments on the run. I do not immediately jump to the conclusion that what the minister is saying to the committee is necessarily correct—not at all. I merely acknowledge that she indicates there are concerns in this regard.

In this circumstance neither of the two options—one going with impairment tables with possible unforeseen consequences or, secondly, adopting a model of putting new impairment tables in place, which we know will have negative consequences—attract me greatly, I must say, Minister. So, in the spirit of providing suggestions on this particular schedule, which seems to be the way we have conducted the debate on schedule 13, that is a proposal that I would put on the table.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —It is our preference, of course, to go with the tables and the amendments that we have put. We feel we have spent a good deal of time talking with disability advocacy groups and we have explored these amendments thoroughly with those groups. I would like to know what degree of consultation the government had before amending the tables in the way that they have.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have to say that I believe there is no greater risk. In fact, the aim of these amendments was to substantially reduce the risk, as you put it, to people who are on a disability support pension. It is your bill which proposes to take 34,000 people off the disability support pension. Our amendments will certainly go nowhere near that in risking the disability support pension to those with a disability. So I support Senator Faulkner's suggestion that we maintain the status quo and then go through a process whereby we can look at perhaps the government's amendments and our own to see what the impact of those will be on those with a disability.

I would also be interested to hear from the minister—I know she indicates there has been insufficient time to look at the Democrats' amendments—what group of people would be more at risk from our amendments than from the government's own changes to the impairment tables. I think we need to hear that. But if there is doubt, my suggestion would be that we return to the current arrangement. There should then be a period of review so that there is time for those advocacy groups and various other people who are interested in this subject to thoroughly explore the matter, to identify those who are rorting the system and to identify those who really ought to be on newstart. But so far we have seen no evidence from the government that there is a so-called saving to be made.

I would argue that there is not anything particularly outrageous or risky in the Democrats' amendments. As I say again, we have had a thorough working through of this document with those groups. They are much less harsh than the government's proposals and they take into account multiple impairments. That is one of the key features of our amendments. For instance, they allow a rating of 10 per cent or 10 per cent to be added where there are two minor impairments. We feel this is very important in looking at the ability of a person to work as a whole person and not just as someone with a particular disability or set of disabilities. We are talking here about ability to enter the work force.

I would again say that the chamber should reject the government's proposals in this respect. I would be very happy to stay with the status quo and to refer this matter to perhaps a committee that can have a more thorough look both at our amendments and at the government's.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —For time's sake, could I help to bring this issue to a close by saying that I will support the suggestion of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner). But before I sit down, can I make it clear that there has been a lot of time since the budget came down for reaction from people over this issue. I have received myself very few representations and the same with the department.

SPEECH.PARA: Can I also clear up something else: I think it was Senator Allison who said that 34,000 people were affected by the tables. That is not true. It is only 2,000 people. The higher figure refers to medical reviews of former invalid pensioners; in other words, people who have not been medically reviewed for a number of years and who may not longer be eligible for a payment on medical grounds. So it is not as substantial as Senator Allison thought, if that was causing suspicion as to what the government was doing by introducing these impairment tables.

I said at the beginning it was not designed as a savings measure, it was a natural progression of the work that was under way by the previous government when there was a change of government. I would prefer that, rather than endangering tables—which have had at least two years in the working up by medical people working with the department and consulting themselves—we leave the existing ones intact and have the opportunity for further consultation with all the parties in the Senate so that we do not introduce something with unforeseen consequences.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we are moving towards that position except that I would like to have it more than a working party with other components of the Senate. I think the earlier idea that the minister had of putting this back to the community groups or effectively establishing a review made up of representatives from the community, which I congratulate the Democrats for having done posthaste after the announcement of this, is the right way to go.

SPEECH.PARA: I have that feeling that we will come a decision very similar to the one that Senator Allison has put before the chamber today. I would ask the minister to confirm her offer that she will establish a review panel made up of representatives from the community groups. I think that would be much more instructive than having representations of the components of the committee involved in a review process.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The monitoring committee that I was referring to was in relation to the new impairment tables if they become part of the legislation. In practice, even the best recommended tables—such as these or any others—can be found over time and usage to have a problem with them. Having that monitoring committee is not an unreasonable way to go. But what you are suggesting now, I presume, is not the monitoring committee that I was suggesting but something similar in the sense of an opportunity to have further consultation with interested parties before they come back in separate legislation to the Senate.
—With a review of the existing tables and how they might be improved.

—Well, the review of the existing tables was done two or three years ago. It would be simply repeating that process. I do not really think that has great virtue. But having a close look at what people believe would be the situation with the new impairment tables does have benefit. I am happy to endorse that direction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob
