TALK.START.PARA: —On amendment 14, the Greens are concerned that the government move limits the payment of child disability allowance in that it cuts the ability to claim on that allowance from 12 months to three months before a claim is made. I did speak with the minister about this when she gave us the opportunity of discussing the whole panoply of amendments a week or two ago.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem is that people who find themselves with a disabled child very often do not get around to making the claim for assistance. Under existing circumstances, they can make a claim up to 12 months retrospectively to catch up. They have been very busy looking after a disabled child. They may have been to and from hospital. They may have had home help. They may have been arranging a whole range of supports for themselves and for that child. The whole family may be involved.

These are very often the exact circumstances which lead to people to think last of how to get some monetary support. With this measure, the government is saying, `Look, if you weren't watching, if you didn't know this support was available when your problems began 12 months ago, too bad. You can only claim back three months.' It is not a good way to go. The Greens do not support it. It is not going to alter the fact that a disabled child has been getting costly aid through their parents or carers. That cost is not going to disappear simply because we make an amendment here in this committee.

This really is a case of chopping a very important and valid benefit. No-one could dispute this benefit. It is a case of cutting that benefit to help meet the budget imperative of the government. This is not a case of trying to catch people who are doing the wrong thing. This is a case of trying to take away a benefit from people because they simply did not apply for it at the right time. They were distracted by the life circumstance they were in with a disabled child.

I think the committee should think very carefully about the move the government has made to say, `You can go back three months and claim on that, but you can't go back 12 months. Sure your child was disabled, sure there were costs there and sure you'll need the money now for the ongoing ability to deal with this situation, but too bad. You didn't know about it. You can't have it.' It is not a very social logic, and we oppose it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate a speech on schedule 14, and indicate that the Democrats will also oppose the schedule.
—Senator Woodley has sought leave to incorporate a speech on schedule 14.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: NEWMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —God bless you, Senator.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
Schedule 14
Limit arrears of payment of Child Disability Allowance
(Democrat amendment 24—oppose the schedule)
Child Disability Allowance is $72.60 per fortnight paid to a person caring for a disabled child.
While arrears of only 3 months are available for most social security payments, at present, a family can receive up to 12 months back‐payment of Child Disability Allowance.

This concession has been provided as it often takes a substantial period of time for families to clearly determine that their child has a disability—that is, in obtaining accurate diagnoses—and then for them to become aware of the payments.

Further, as ACRID pointed out to the Community Affairs Committee, ". . . there is also quite a long delay before people come to grips with the fact that they have a child with a disability and identify themselves in that particular way."
It was revealed in the estimates hearings that around 75% of new grants of Child Disability Allowance are eligible for arrears of more than 3 months.
Clearly then, there is a need to continue the extended arrears and, as such, the Democrats will be opposing the schedule.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure God is more likely to bless Senator Woodley, being a man of the cloth, than he is likely to bless me; nevertheless, I will be very brief. The opposition will be opposing this measure by seeking to omit the schedule from the bill. We believe this is unacceptably harsh because it really does fail to recognise the hardship which can be suffered by the parents of children with disabilities. Those disabilities could take over three months to diagnose. That is one possible concern. Another concern is that it could take more than three months to establish the required pattern of extra care or attention. It is for these reasons that the opposition strongly opposes schedule 14.
—Also, it very often takes more than three months for the parents to come to terms with the matter.
—That's right. They have to grieve for the loss of the perfect child.

—Senator West, who is very much experienced in the area of care and nursing and so on, indicates there is an amount of grieving involved, and people may not be up to making the claim. As I understand it, in any event, 75 per cent of the claims are made after a period of three months. I just indicate my opposition to the matter. I thought we had got on to this subject before Senator Newman's response to Senator Faulkner's eminently reasonable suggestion was clarified—at least in my mind. Does that mean that the minister will withdraw the impairment tables?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. Very briefly—I know about the time—I do not believe it is a harsh measure. If this had been the situation when the allowance was first introduced, you might have been able to describe a limitation on the period in those terms. This payment has now been around for quite a long time. It appears—it is advertised, if you like—in the guide to family payments which 1.8 million families in Australia get each year and, in addition, on the birth of a new child. Doctors are regularly advised of the payment. Com munity nurses and paediatricians are also well aware of it now, whereas it was a new payment some time ago. Therefore, the availability of being able to take it back to a year means that people do not hurry to do it.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the only payment in the entire social security area which has arrears of more than three months. In fact, most payments have no right to arrears. In the family area, there are payments with three months arrears and we were moving to put this payment into the same bracket as existing ones. I do not know whether there is any indication from the committee that it would be prepared to consider an in‐between amount of time. Now that the payment is well‐established and is known widely through the medical profession, through community nursing and also through many families, with it regularly being brought to their attention, and given the justification and the need for 12 months arrears—in other words, that families do not get to know about it for quite a long time—I would have thought it was not an unreasonable proposition to bring it into line with other payments.
Schedule 15.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I foreshadow that I will be moving opposition amendment 85 in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: (85) Schedule 15, page 167 (after line 10), after item 1, insert:

PARA.TAB: After "Act," insert "but subject to subsection (3A),".
Insert:

TAB.EMPHASIS: Compensation part of a lump sum for age pension

SPEECH.PARA: (3A) For the purposes of Part 2.2 of Chapter 2, the compensation part of a lump sum compensation payment is:

TAB.TAB: (a) if there is a relevant judgment—only that component of a lump sum compensation payment that is specified in the relevant judgment as being for economic loss; or
(b) in all other cases—0% of the lump sum compensation payment.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend the motion to the Senate. We accept the argument put by the government that compensation payments should affect age pension entitlements in the same way that compensation payments affect other social security payments.

We are concerned that situations might arise where an aged pensioner receives a compensation payment which does not specify what component of the payment, if any, is for economic loss and that in those circumstances some proportion of the total payment may be assumed to be for economic loss. For this reason we have formulated amendments to prevent a 50 per cent assumption where there is no judgment.

In relation to amendments Nos 86 to 91 standing in the name of the opposition, we will be opposing this part of the schedule to restore the divisor for calculating the lump sum compensation preclusion period to average weekly earnings. Pensioners and allowees affected by this measure will otherwise be subject to much longer periods without payment, forcing them to use up their compensation at a much lower rate before they are eligible for financial assistance or for continued assistance. Our amendments are written in a way that retains the beneficial provision for partners included in the schedule.

PARA.BREAK: Opposition amendment No. 92 applies in relation to schedule 20. Labor supports measures which encourage social security recipients to maximise the return on their resources but this measure relies on pensioners and allowees being able to access safe accounts which pay interest at the deemed rate. In the current climate where interest rates have been officially cut but where the minister must again consider whether or not to cut the deeming rates, this concession on the first $2,000 for a single person or $4,000 for a couple is especially critical to pensioners and allowees. Under half of all financial institutions make these available. Not all are available to all pensioners and allowees. Very few currently offer the deemed rate of interest on small deposit accounts of the below threshold rate. The measure relies on financial institu tions moving to provide accounts which pay the deeming rate on these accounts.

SPEECH.PARA: There is little evidence that the financial institutions will do this. That is the truth of the matter. Some regional banks have recently moved in exactly the opposite direction, from paying five per cent on amounts under $2,000 to paying one per cent. There are an estimated 721,000 pensioners, about 600,000 from DSS and the remainder in the Department of Veterans' Affairs, and around 60,000 allowees who will be affected. I commend this amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —In terms of schedule 15, part 1, the Democrats will be supporting the ALP amendment. If that amendment is unsuccessful we will oppose that part of the schedule. The proposal on compensation in schedule 15, part 2 will make the situation worse. The Democrats therefore will support the ALP amendments. If those amendments are unsuccessful we will be opposing that part. I seek leave to have two speeches on that incorporated in the Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
Schedule 15
Compensation
Part 1
(ALP amendment 85)
This part will extend the compensation recovery provisions to age pensioners.
The Democrats believe the application of the so‐called "50% rule" already disadvantages many compensation recipients and would not like to see its application extended.
This is particularly so for Age Pensioners who are likely to only receive very small components of their compensation payments for economic loss.
The Democrats will be supporting the ALP amendment on this Part and, if that amendment is unsuccessful, will be opposing the Part.
Schedule 15
Compensation
Part 2
(ALP amendments 86 to 91—same as Green amendments 63 to 67)
This provision will increase the period of time injured people will be precluded from social security payments.
Currently, DSS assumes that 50% of any lump sum compensation payment which contains an economic loss component—no matter how small that component is—is for loss of income.
DSS then divides this 50% figure by the `all persons average weekly earnings' figure of around $560.00 to obtain the number of weeks a person will be precluded from income support payments.
As of March next year, rather than using `all persons AWE', the Department will divide the 50% figure by the single pension cut‐out figure, which is currently $397 a week.
The effect of this of course will be significantly longer preclusion periods for people who have been injured at work or in a car accident.
The "50% rule" already disadvantages many people by forcing them to live off moneys awarded to cover, for example, past and future medical expenses or for pain and suffering.
This proposal will greatly exacerbate that and the Democrats will therefore be supporting the ALP (or Green???) amendments and, if those amendments are unsuccessful, we will be opposing the part.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are going to support the government on schedule 20. This schedule of the bill will apply the lower deeming rate of four per cent to the first $2,000 to $4,000 of savings held in bank deposits by singles and couples. I want to put it clearly on the record that these changes will not affect those people who have only small balances in the bank, due to the operation of the income free areas on social security payments. The original figures were that the people to be affected were allowees with over $30,000 in financial assets, single pensioners with more than $45,000 in financial assets and pensioner couples with more than $78,000 in financial assets. Those figures may now have increased to $52,000 and around $90,000 as a result of the recent review of the deeming rates.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a good deal of confusion over the impact of this measure so I say again that it will not affect those allowees or pensioners who have only low or even modest amounts of financial assets. Importantly for those people affected by this change, losses may be recouped by adjusting their investments and consolidating their accounts into the deeming accounts currently available from the various banks. The latest information available shows that the big four banks, as well as 116 other financial institutions, offer deeming accounts which mostly match the government's deeming rates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, in respect of the receipt of compensation payments for injury, for example, the compensation will consist of both economic and non‐economic losses. I do not know of—perhaps the minister may be able to inform the committee—any court order dissecting the elements of compensation lump sum into loss of income and other income which requires Social Security to assume that 50 per cent of the lump sum is compensation for the loss of income and excludes a person from entitlement for a waiting period based on that assumed 50 per cent; that is, in the act.

SPEECH.PARA: But I do not know of any court order which would, in general, give rise to that sort of dissection—50 per cent for loss of income. The government advises that, where there is evidence applied by the applicant as to the component of that lump sum, the department has a discretion which is reviewable by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal to take an apportionment other than 50 per cent of the loss of income component.

What I want to ask the minister is this: what authority is there in the Social Security Act for the department to take a figure other than 50 per cent as representing the loss of income component of a compensation lump sum? Is any departmental decision reviewable in that particular respect? Really, what is the legislative basis—I have not had a chance to go through it—for the department to take a figure other than the 50 per cent?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine would be aware that the 50 per cent rule was developed by the former Labor government in a response to lawyers who were circumventing the compensation recovery provisions. In fact, 50 per cent, Senator Harradine, I understand, is applied where there has been a settlement. Where there has been a court order, the department uses the amount described in the court order for economic loss.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the specifics of the last part of your contribution, I am informed that section 118(4) gives a discretion to disregard an amount of compensation in the special circumstances of the case. As is currently the case, where the economic loss component of a lump sum compensation payment is less than 50 per cent, section 118(4) may be used to reduce the compensation part of the lump sum from 50 per cent to the actual amount of the economic loss.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that to reduce the economic loss?
—Yes.
—Understood. Thank you.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I just ask the minister what was the reference in the act to the discretion she was talking about.
—It was section 118(4).
—Are there any other queries on 15 and 20? We will now move on to schedules 21 and 22, items 47 to 49.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —On our informal running sheet, if you like, we are dealing now with schedules 21 and 22. Of course, in relation to schedule 21, the relevant opposition amendments are 93 to 97. They are about preventing the Department of Social Security from making all overpayments into recoverable debts.

SPEECH.PARA: Unrecoverable debts, in most cases, arise where a customer is overpaid due to an administrative error of the DSS. This applies whether or not the person realised that they were being overpaid. A debt may be identified quite a long while, possibly even years, after the overpayment. But this measure would force customers to repay money that they did not realise they owed.

PARA.BREAK: It is for that reason that we oppose part 1 which gives effect to automatic rate reduc tions where a person complies with a requirement to notify being classed as debt and therefore recoverable. This would otherwise allow the department to act not promptly and still recover any overpayment arising from this lack of promptness.

SPEECH.PARA: We will be opposing part 2 which gives effect to new provisions which would make any overpayment arising for reasons not codified in other sections of the act—in other words, foul‐ups from the department—a debt which is recoverable. We agree to part 3 which consolidates the overseas application of debt recovery provisions and methods of debt recovery. We oppose part 4 which is the removal of compulsion for the secretary to waive debts which arise solely as a result of administrative error. We will oppose items 99, 100, 101, 104 and 105 of part 5 which codify the circumstances in which a debt can be written off by the secretary because no discretion is provided.

I would like to make what I think is a really critical point about this: the department itself requires people to notify it of relevant changes in circumstances within 14 days, and people are penalised if they do not meet that deadline. At the very least, I think the same standard should be expected of the department.

The government's proposals effectively allow DSS staff to take as long as they like to put changes into the system. That is a double standard. There is one standard for, as the minister likes to say, the poor, the needy and the vulnerable in the community, and one standard for the department. That is not acceptable to the opposition.

I also want to address opposition amendment 98, which relates to schedule 22. The opposition's approach is to seek to omit the schedule, to restore arrangements for the pension advance scheme. The number of advances and the amount of money involved in each advance would be reduced as a result of this measure.

The scheme has been very successful in helping JSA and NSA recipients participate in activities to help them find employment, and also in helping pensioners meet their living and capital expenses or those of a family member. To restrict the advances would restrict the activities that would lead to the advances being repaid.

There is no evidence that this system is being abused. I would be interested to hear if the minister has any. The only justification for this measure that I am aware of is administrative simplicity. In simple terms, this is a measure for the minister, or for the Department of Social Security; it is not a measure for the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to indicate with respect to schedule 21 that the Australian Democrats will be supporting the ALP amendment which allows some small sections of schedule 21 to stand. At least, that is my understanding. I will get an indication from Senator Faulkner on that in a minute. However, we will oppose all other parts of the schedule 21.

SPEECH.PARA: The government's intention with schedule 21 is to allow the Department of Social Security to recover overpayments made as a result of administrative error. Those overpayments, where they are received in good faith by the customer, are not recoverable by the department. The risk with the proposal before us, however, is that it will remove any imperative on the department to be timely in processing information provided by the client as it can always go back and reclaim the money.

Because the income testing rules are so confusing, many people would not know what their correct entitlement should be. The Democrats believe that, in circumstances where people have received money in good faith, it would be grossly unjust to allow the department to turn around in six months or even 12 months time and try to recover those overpayments. The person has done everything required of them, and the department is solely to blame.

Given the level of savings that the government hopes to achieve from this measure, the Democrats are keen to see if some compromise could be reached. In preliminary discussions with the minister's office, we were not able to agree on such a system. I put on the record the Democrats' willingness to consider an alternative proposal which the government might wish to put to us in the future on this issue.

As Senator Faulkner pointed out, clients have to notify the department within two weeks of the overpayment. It does not seem just for the department then to say that it can take as long as it likes to recover money, the payment of which was its fault. I seek an indication from Senator Faulkner that he is opposing most of schedule 21, apart from those items he has signalled as amendments to schedule 21. If that is the case, we would support his amendments. However, I stress that the bottom line for the Democrats is that the imperative must remain for the department to be efficient in dealing with these matters.

In relation to schedule 22, the advanced payment scheme, the proposed amendments will modify the operation of that scheme for pensioners and the unemployed. There will be some tightening of the scheme by setting the maximum amount available at $500 and by limiting the number of advances to one in any 12‐month period.

It is expected that these changes will improve recovery of advances by the department. At the same time the scheme will be liberalised through the removal of the requirement that people access advanced payments only for certain permitted purposes. Removal of this restriction will allow, for example, an unemployed person to use the money to purchase a fridge or to pay a rental bond. The Democrats will be supporting this schedule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Woodley that there must be a certain responsibility on the department. If a person notifies the department that their circumstances have changed and therefore the benefits they can get have changed, and if they do that again and again but the department still sends the wrong amount, it is a bit rich, whatever the person's circumstances further down the line, that they can be held responsible for paying back the money. There should be some limit. No one expects the public purse to bear the cost of tens of thousands or hundreds of thousands of dollars in the exceptional circumstances where a benefit is paid and the recipient has only a marginal excuse keeping it. We would like the present situation to pertain but we support the ALP's proposed amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: I just want to go back one step and also say that, as with the Labor Party, we will be aiming to keep the limits on the deeming rate as far as pensioners' accounts are concerned. Taxing pensioners for small amounts of income that they did not get on money they have in the bank is what this is about. If there is $2,000 in the bank and the bank is paying less interest than what the government deems the interest ought to be, the pensioner gets taxed not on the amount of interest they are paid but on the higher interest that is nominated by the government. So we have this extraordinary situation where people on low incomes very often are paying tax on money they did not receive.

I know there are some complicated components to this but, again, I think the government ought to be legislating to bring the banks into order, not the pensioners. If this matter is going to be fixed up good and proper, let us have the government telling the banks what interest they should be paying, if necessary, instead of leaving it to their good offices and, where they do not pay the interest, penalising pensioners for income they did not get, particularly on $2,000 in the bank, for goodness sake. Let us cut another $2 a fortnight out of a pensioner's income!
Senator Newman interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —`It's not right,' says the minister.
—You haven't got it right. It maximises their income for them. They get more. They get to keep more.
—They get more if the banks do the right thing.
—And they do. Every time there has been a change of arrangements, they have. This will push them into doing the right thing again.
—You legislate on the banks.
—That is not the way to go.

—No, it is not a way to go! Of course, it is not because the banks have a power that the pensioners do not have. That is the problem. I think you will find that there are exceptions to the rule and that pensioners do lose out on this. If that is the case, you can legislate on the pensioners' income but not on the banks, because they are untouchable as far as this neck of the woods is concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wanted to respond very briefly to Senator Brown. Three years ago most of the banks in Australia were paying pensioners one per cent. The introduction by the previous government of bank deeming and then extended bank deeming has seen a dramatic improvement in the way banks have treated pensioners. We are continuing that. We believe that the previous government's route was a correct one. We supported it then. We are now moving to make sure that right down to the last dollar pensioners have the opportunity to get a decent return on their money.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of financial institutions are already paying the deeming rates right down to the last dollar. We are introducing this measure to encourage those who are still paying only one per cent on those smaller amounts—the ones under $4,000. I welcome the fact that the Democrats understand the measure and have seen that it is a beneficial one for maximising pensioners' income, because above the deeming rate they get to keep it without it having any impact on their pension.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there no pensioner who has ever paid a penny on income they did not receive?
—I don't understand you.

—That is what it is about. You yourself are saying that there are some institutions who are still paying low interest rates and that the banks in the main have fallen into line because otherwise the pensioners will change where they put their deposits. But there is no compulsion on banks to ensure that they are paying interest at a rate at which the pensioner is going to be taxed. That is the problem with this clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand the problem the government has in respect of this matter. I understand it is a very substantial amount, but that is a reflection on the efficiency of the department to a certain extent. Nevertheless, in this day and age of computers and what have you, there are inadvertent overpayments. I would have thought it obvious that all overpayments, by definition, must be inadvertent.

SPEECH.PARA: The government can say, `If banks overpay, they can recover debts.' But that is not quite the same when we are talking about the government and government servants. Let us take the principle where people rely on a ruling of the taxation commissioner. Having made full and true disclosure of the fact, they cannot be assessed to their detriment even if the commissioner's ruling is wrong at law.

I know that we are in a different ball game here than is the Commissioner of Taxation but, nevertheless, I do take the point that was made by one of the honourable senators—I do not know who it was. Where, for example, the department has been notified by a beneficiary that there has been an overpayment and within the two‐week period that beneficiary has made the declaration of a change of circumstances and still the payments in respect of the old circumstances continue and the next payment comes along and that person goes back and says that they have advised them of their change of circumstances, surely that is a matter that should be taken into consideration by the department.

Overall, I understand and acknowledge that there is a problem. I do not agree with the government in respect of the 13 weeks. That is absolutely out of the question. There is a two‐week period for notifying a change of circumstances, and I suppose under those circumstances you are looking at maybe four weeks in addition to that time. Should there be some problems in respect of overpayments, I suppose I can understand the need for the department to protect revenue.

I make the point clearly to the committee that I think the minister should give an assurance to the committee that the term `hardship' will not be defined as extenuating circumstances to the extent that it means that the result will affect the recipient. There should be a rather liberal interpretation of the term `hardship' in respect of the recovery of debts due to an administrative error.

I can see a problem if there was a computer error. If 100,000 recipients were each paid $10 a week extra for maybe five weeks then, my goodness, there is probably an argument to say that under those circumstances repayment should be claimed. I certainly would not go along with 13 weeks. I want a quite definite assurance from the minister with respect to the interpretation of the word `hardship' and a guarantee that the department's administrative systems attend to this problem fairly rapidly. As I understand it, the figure is something like $300 million. Could the minister advise the committee of that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, the advice I have is that this item covers an amount of approximately $265 million. It is, as you say, a substantial sum. I recognise your concerns about the length of time in which it is proposed that the department could come back to reclaim debt. If I could get support for a proposal to take it back to six weeks I would be prepared to do that. There are technical problems with the department being able to guarantee that they can take action within the first four weeks, but within the first six weeks is possible. I think it also has the advantage of keeping pressure on officials to make sure that they keep these matters under review all the time.

SPEECH.PARA: One of things that I do think is perhaps appreciated by some senators is that—and I raised it the other day in this place—you have the opportunity to make the whole question of inadequate administration much more transparent. Currently, a lot of these overpayments and debts are not quantified to the extent that they are available to, say, the estimates committees, the Public Accounts Committee or the Auditor‐General. They are not identified specifically. This measure will make it much clearer to all concerned as to how well the department is administering this area of its responsibility. For that reason, I think it is a move in the right direction.

As far as individuals and hardship is concerned, there is a general rule that all overpayments should be repaid according to the recipient's capacity to pay. As far as people who cannot afford to pay are concerned, the department will not take action against a person who cannot afford to pay. If they could not pay by way of lump sum, which for most people is difficult, but they could repay by reasonable instalments without any penalty or interest, then they would be expected to do so.

There is also protection for customers provided in the write‐off provisions of the act. They have been preserved in the government's amendments. If customers have no capacity to repay their debt, recovery action can be suspended indefinitely by the writing off of the debt under the act. This gives the Commonwealth the ability to resume recovery in the future if the person's financial circumstances improve.

In addition, in cases where there are other special circumstances that would make recovery unjust or unreasonable there is scope to waive recovery of the debt altogether. One of the issues that might properly be considered in this regard is the period over which the administrative error occurred. The decision maker is thus able to consider the totality of the circumstances in deciding whether recovery is warranted.

Do not forget also that customers who are dissatisfied with the decision about the recovery of their debt still retain access to the range of internal and external review and appeal mechanisms and they also have access and recourse to the Commonwealth Ombudsman. I would hope that those statements might deal with some of Senator Harradine's concerns as to the ability of people to pay and the hardship situation that they might find themselves in.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to talk about those review procedures and I will give a particular example. A customer has advised the department of his change of circumstances but, nevertheless, the department takes no notice and keeps paying the customer a particular amount, which is an overpayment. The customer goes back the next day and advises the department, but the department again pays that overpayment the next fortnight. Would those review procedures enable the department to decide that repayments under those circumstances are not reasonable, because the department had been given a reasonable opportunity by the customer to rectify the overpayment?

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I respond to Senator Harradine by saying that, by limiting the time for the department to act to six weeks, you put the customers who have done the right thing in the position of being able to retain whatever they have been paid beyond that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to move the amendment that stands in my name to insert a new schedule, schedule 22A. I will try to be brief because I know that the committee wants to move on.
—What is it about?

—This amendment is about maintaining pensions to at least 25 per cent of all male total average weekly earnings. I am hoping that this will be non-controversial and accepted around the chamber by all.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a lot of concern about the report of the National Commission of Audit to the government in June 1996. The key recommendation of that National Commission of Audit report was that the government should review its policy for adjustments of pensions and benefits. Options available for future pension increases include:
If an average weekly earnings benchmark is still to be employed, consideration be given to median total average weekly earnings being used as a better measure of community standards.
And:
If an average measure is to be used then total average weekly earnings, AWE, be used in place of MTAWE.

This recommendation of the National Commission of Audit caused enormous concern around the community, particularly taking into account the fact that the National Commission of Audit was a creature of the Howard government. I do note that on 26 November 1995 the then Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was very quick to publish a press release headed `Pension Guarantee', which said:

It is clear and absolute Coalition policy both to index pensions on a twice yearly basis in accordance with the Consumer Price Index and as well maintain their value at 25 percent of average weekly earnings.
Senator Newman, in response to a question without notice on 25 June 1996 and quoting a press release of hers, said:
The government has ruled out fixing pensions by any different formula. The government maintains its commitment to pensions being determined at 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings.
To be fair to Senator Newman, in her second reading speech on this bill, she also said:

. . . we can keep our commitment to maintain pension payments at 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings; and we have listened to the welfare sector and sought to introduce some of their suggestions for reform.
It would be appropriate for me to acknowledge that those statements have been made either in the parliament or by the vehicle of press release by both Senator Newman and Mr Howard.

It is the opposition's intention today to amend this social security legislation that is before the Senate so as to cement in legislation the 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings benchmark for pensions. If the recommendation of the National Commission of Audit were to be accepted, it would effectively take millions and millions of dollars out of the pockets of pensioners.

We need to ensure that the current benchmark that Labor has been committed to, literally for generations, is secure. The way to do that is to pass this amendment and have it enshrined in the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Budget and Other Measures) Bill which is before the Senate today.

By making this very important amendment, the Labor opposition might be able to ensure that this is one pre-election promise that the Howard government keeps. I am hopeful that this amendment will gain unanimous support in the chamber and, if it does, this opposition initiative very clearly will put the minds of hundreds of thousands of Australian pensioners at rest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has only just seen this amendment. It seeks to legislate for 25 per cent of average weekly earnings on pensions, as the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) has said. We agree with the policy and, as I have said on a number of occasions in the Senate, we actually provided for the money to honour that commitment in the forward estimates at the last budget.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, unfortunately—and Senator Faulkner, I am sure, is not aware of this—there are significant errors, I am advised, with the legislation which has been drafted for the opposition. I have a piece of paper here, which would try to tell you what the problems are. If you wanted to come and read it, you would be welcome. It is not something that many of us would gain much from if I tried to read it into the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you be willing to table a copy of it, Minister?
—Yes, we could. I am not trying to put you down; I am just trying to suggest that it was done in a great hurry.
—I would ordinarily suggest it be incorporated. It appears to be in handwriting and therefore I am suggesting that you table it.

—I do not think there is any problem with that, but I do not think you will be very much better informed as a result of that. There are points (a) (b) and (c) on a page entitled `Problems with new section 1206D'. It starts off in (a) to say that there is already a section 1206D in the act—it happens to deal with rent assistance. Then it goes on to (b), which says that this should refer to the maximum basic rate of pension, not a member of a couple rate. There is more on that.

BREAK.PARA: Then there is an item (c), which talks of the definition of the maximum basic rate. I have not had time to read it all carefully myself. The conclusion from the advisers is:
Accordingly, this amendment does not work. The maximum basic rate of pension is actually worked out under the relevant rate calculator.
Accordingly, the definition of "maximum basic rate of pension" should refer to "amounts worked out under point 1064‐B1 (as indexed)".
So I am trying to help you in terms of the advice which has just come to me because, as you know, you have just given me the amendment.

Having said all that and in the light of that, I now have advice from the Prime Minister's office which I would commend to the committee. The Prime Minister's office has advised `that early in the next session as a matter of urgency this government will bring forward an amendment to legislate the 25 per cent average weekly earning commitment. The government is committed to keeping the age pension and recognises that it has flow‐ons to other pensions'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the light of the advice that Senator Newman has, I am pleased to receive that response from the Prime Minister. It would be churlish to persist if there is a technical problem with the amendment that has been drafted. For the opposition, of course, the jury is always out on these matters and it remains to be seen, but Senator Newman has some hastily scrawled handwritten advice suggesting that that is the case. The Prime Minister's office has responded in that way. I do not know what authority the Prime Minister's office has. In a sense, I think the Prime Minister perhaps has a little more authority than his own office.

SPEECH.PARA: If Senator Newman would be willing to give me an undertaking that the government will bring back a proposed amendment to the Social Security Act early in the next session to enshrine the principle that I am arguing for in legislation—and I think that is what she is in effect saying to the committee—then I would accept that commitment, if she was willing to give it in that form.

BREAK.PARA: What I am interested in doing here is ensuring that this is enshrined in legislation; that we do put at rest the minds of, as I have said, literally hundreds of thousands of Australians pensioners who have been very concerned about the report of the National Commission of Audit, which of course was something generated from the government.

If Senator Newman is willing to give a commitment in that form, I believe that ought to satisfy the committee. At this stage it would satisfy me and I am delighted that this opposition initiative has brought that response. I would seek that commitment from you, Senator Newman. If I get it, I would be more than happy in that circumstance to not proceed with the amendment that stands in my name. I look forward to the early introduction in the next session of such legislation, which, of course, given that this is our initiative, would receive speedy passage from the opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats would have been inclined to support the amendment but I think the minister has given us a better proposition. Can I just ask the minister to confirm that it is 25 per cent of all male total average weekly earnings?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I confirm that it is 25 per cent of total average male weekly earnings. I also feel obliged to point out that it is because the money has been allowed for in the forward estimates that we are able to give the undertaking and we are prepared and happy to legislate accordingly. Until this year and this budget, forward estimates had never carried any commitment or any ability to honour a commitment to pensioners in this form. Therefore, previous governments have never been in a position to actually legislate. Because this government has provided for the 25 per cent of total average male weekly earnings, we are ready, willing and very happy to introduce the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Prime Minister's office speaks, I would have thought it nearly as good as a minister's commitment. But you have my commitment as well. I look forward to it. It would probably be able to go through in a lunchtime, as I am sure that it would not be opposed by any members of this chamber. I welcome the support that the opposition has shown for the government's action this year, which will make this legislation possible. We all recognise that this is a very important element in giving people on pensions the certainty and confidence that the value of their pensions will be maintained.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are waiting for the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) to table that interesting document. I would appreciate it if she did that. I reject the spin that Senator Newman made in her last contribution. I am pleased that the government has responded to the opposition's initiative in this way. Any such bill is worthy of speedy passage through both houses of parliament. We are also very interested in putting at rest the concerns of many pensioners in this country that were raised as a result of the National Commission of Audit report. In that circumstance, I am happy to accept the commitment given by Senator Newman on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). I ask her to formally table the document from which she was reading.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —As soon as I have a photocopy made of what was originally a scribbled document done in the chamber a few minutes ago, I will be happy to table it. I add the proviso that it was done with great haste in the chamber. The officials feel that their pride is somewhat attached to the perfection of the advice.
—That's why I suggested that it not be incorporated.
—Yes. It will be tabled. On that understanding, I am happy to. It will be done in a minute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I return to schedule 5 in part 3, which deals with the penalties issue. I have a great deal of difficulty with the suggestion by the government on this matter. I know that there needs to be some deterrent for people who may deliberately seek to rort the system. There is agreement that there should be some sort of penalty and deterrent for those who are rorting the system.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the first breach, the government's proposal is on the outer limit of what might be acceptable. As I read it, the opposition and the government are fairly close on, for example, administrative breaches. At present, I do not agree with the government on the second and subsequent breaches. These sorts of things should not be done on the run.

If we could get a general understanding of the ballpark figures involved—the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) might come up with some further suggestions—we might be able to look at them over the break and come back to that matter in the first week when we return here. We can then deal with it in a non-controversial way. I cannot see myself voting for the government proposition as it is at present, but I see that there is a need for some further discussion on this matter. I do not want to hold up the committee at this time. All I am suggesting is that the minister withdraw the proposition and have discussions with Senator Faulkner, Senator Woodley, Senator Brown, me and other interested senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine appears to be correct. There is a willingness around the chamber that the issue of the breaches be looked at again. The government is in a difficult position. It does not believe that the opposition's amendments are satisfactory. We would be prepared to find alternative positions if we had an undertaking that we would move to a position where the disincentive to disobey the rules could be maintained. We are concerned that in some of the opposition's proposals there is the potential for some people to make a reduction in income under the consequent lifestyle change a reasonably attractive proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: We would like to find mutual agreement on this, but I am at a loss as to how we might reach that in the circumstances we find ourselves in today. Unless there is some suggestion from other parties here as to how we might achieve a common goal, we would be obliged to vote against the opposition's amendments. Having said that, I do want to emphasise that we are not adverse to finding a position which will suit both sides of the chamber.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly appreciate Senator Harradine's contribution and I hear what the minister is saying. Senator Harradine and Senator Newman, it would seem to me that this could only be achieved if the minister withdrew the relevant parts of schedule 5, which would be part 3 and some of part 4. That would be correct, would it not, Minister?
—Yes, I understand that is correct.

—Thank you, Minister. That would seem to be the only way that the matter could be progressed. I am interested to hear the views of Senator Brown and Senator Woodley, who have also made contributions in relation to this schedule 5. Obviously, it is important. We are running very short of time. On that basis, perhaps the matter could be progressed but that would be, I suspect, the bottom line. Otherwise, I think what Senator Harradine proposes, which is not without merit, would be unachievable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was expecting that some other senators were going to contribute. If they are not, I will respond as best I can to the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposition is for the first activity breach to be 20 per cent reduction over 25 weeks and a second breach to result in eight weeks non‐payment—an administrative breach of either the government or the ALP position. There are technical flaws with the ALP amendments, as I have said before. There are also, as I have highlighted, policy difficulties. In those circumstances we have difficulty endorsing the proposals from the ALP.

BREAK.PARA: If the government was prepared to withdraw its amendments, would the Democrats and the ALP also be willing to withdraw their amendments on the basis that we would try to achieve common ground? We would leave the existing system in place, in other words, until such time as we can find common ground to try to achieve the direction which Senator Harradine has flagged. I think we all recognise it is a responsible way to go. We have all had consultations with welfare groups who are suggesting that the current system can be improved on. We have suggested one way. Other parties in this chamber have suggested other ways. Senator Harradine is right in saying that it looks as if we do want to achieve an outcome but the time is too short today.

Would the Democrats and the Labor Party be prepared to withdraw their amendments on the basis that the government withdraws that part—in other words, we leave the situation as it is now on the basis that we would be coming back as speedily as we could next year with a proposal for which we would try to get joint endorsement. Would that be a proposition? Does anybody have a comment to add to that contribution?

TALK.START.PARA: —So what you are proposing, Minister, is that the current situation would obtain until you came back with an agreed set of amendments?

—Yes. I guess essentially that would have to be it. I would hope that there may be some opportunity for the administrative breaches to go ahead straight away because they are substantially an improvement, as you have acknowledged, Senator, on the existing system.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —It has taken a long time—about seven hours. But the last point that Senator Newman makes is probably a pretty reasonable one, at last. Senator Harradine nods, Senator Woodley nods, Senator Brown nods. You are getting a bit closer now, Senator Newman. It has taken a long while, but you are getting a bit closer.
—You seem to be qualifying what you were wanting.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was wanting to raise this other thing. I would have thought that we would all agree that it would be a shame not to put a beneficial measure in straightaway if we could. There are administrative breaches and there are activity breaches. I do not think there seems to be the same problem with the administrative breaches because that is making a more beneficial regime for people than there is with the activity breaches. It is in the activity breach area that we need to find something. Am I wrong?
—You've got it.
—Right. We will save time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I think you need to withdraw those parts of schedule 5 that relate to activity breaches and keep those parts that relate to administrative breaches.

—I agree with that. In respect of the activity breaches, there is nothing to prevent and everything to suggest the government should liaise to see what comes out of any further discussions on that matter. SPEECH.PARA: The Labor opposition has circulated some five amendments to the further budget and other measures bill. The first four amendments I would like to say a few words about. The fifth amendment, which deals with rental assistance, my esteemed colleague Senator Faulkner will deal with.

The four amendments relate to the proposed deeming of earnings on superannuation for a person who reaches the age of 55 and the subsequent adjustment down of their various social security benefits such as unemployment and disability pension, depending on the level of their superannuation asset. I spoke extensively on this in the second reading debate. This matter has been examined by the esteemed Select Committee on Superannuation chaired by my esteemed Tasmanian colleague Senator John Watson who, I should say, is not a member of the Labor opposition; he is a Liberal chair of that committee.

The intention of the four amendments is to ensure that a person who has $250,000 in superannuation assets is not affected by deeming their superannuation. So people who have more than $250,000 in superannuation assets would be affected by the government's proposals. The second principle of our four amendments is to ensure that a person who has made an investment after 20 August is affected by the measure. So superannuation accrued after that date and where it reaches $250,000 is deemed—as the government is suggesting.

I just want to make a few comments about why we have picked a figure of $250,000. I know the minister has argued that this is too high a figure and that we should treat asset classes consistently when a person reaches the age of 55. Labor believes that superannuation is a different type of asset class. It is long-term investment for a person's retirement when they reach the age of 60 and beyond.

It was certainly understood by the Australian people—up until this measure was announced on budget night—that superannuation is a long-term investment. We have actively encouraged investment in superannuation. Certainly the 67,000 people who will be affected by this measure believed that—up until budget night.

The reason we have chosen that figure of $250,000 is that—if $250,000 is converted into an annuity or pension income stream when a person reaches 60 or whatever age they choose to take that income—if a person went to purchase an annuity or a pension for $250,000 at today's market interest rates, it would earn you $6,500 to $7,000 in an income stream. That would roughly equate to some $16,000 or $17,000, depending on the annuity or the pension you could buy. That is not a lot of money. We believe that that is an appropriate cut-off figure.

The other point about ensuring that superannuation money accrued after 20 August is taken into account is that there is a significant element of retrospectivity in what the government is proposing. People were encouraged into superannuation by both the current government and Labor over a long period of time—I think since about 1951 when the then Menzies government introduced a range of tax incentives for superannuation. That has been understood up until 20 August, budget night this year. We do not see why people should have to unravel their retirement plans. Therefore, we regard the measure as retrospective in its effect. We believe this measure should take effect for superannuation investment accrued after 20 August, budget night.

They are the reasons for the Labor opposition's four amendments. There has been extensive debate on this issue in the media, in the select committee hearings and in the debates on the second reading. The government's measure announced in the budget was certainly not referred to in the coalition's election manifesto when it went to the people in March this year. Therefore, this is a blatant breach of election commitments given to the Australian people.

The people that will be hit the hardest by this measure—those who have less than $250,000 in superannuation—are people who gave evidence to the committee. I give as examples an electrician, a bank clerk and a railway worker who have retired at the age of 55. The ones who will be hit the hardest are elderly people who reach the age of 55, who are unemployed and who find it very difficult to obtain a job. We have a range of questions that we would like to have asked you, Minister, but I understand the time constraints so I will keep my comments to that at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously the Democrats, because these amendments have been moved in both names—the opposition and the Democrats—endorse what Senator Sherry has said. I am terribly tempted to launch into a speech but I seek leave to incorporate my remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
Schedule 1
Superannuation assets for older people
Currently, assets held in superannuation and roll‐over funds are exempt from the means tests on most Social Security payments.
The Government is seeking to remove this exemption for those people aged between 55 years and Age Pension age once they have been on an income support payment for nine months.
Budget papers show that as a result of this, 54,000 people will have their Social Security payments reduced and 12,900 will lose their payment entirely.

The Government argues that this move is justified on the grounds that these people should be `expected to use their superannuation savings for self‐provision before calling on the Government for income support'.
The Australian Democrats will not be supporting this change.
(As Senator Allison has said . . . )
We believe it is poor policy.
We believe it is inequitable in its impact.
And we believe it is breach of the undertaking the Coalition gave prior to the election that there would be stability and security in our superannuation system.

If implemented, this measure would force people, many of whom are disabled or are involuntarily unemployed, to use up their assets as a time when the government should be encouraging them to maintain those assets for retirement.

The Minister has argued previously that people will not be required to eat into their superannuation. To sustain this argument you need to draw what I would see as a totally artificial distinction between a person's superannuation capital and the interest that accrues on that.

In reality, people simply look at the total amount they have in superannuation as their superannuation savings and, if the affected people want to maintain their current lifestyle, they will have no option but to draw down on those funds.

Figures released at the Estimates hearings showed that, for example, a single 58 year old on a Mature Age Allowance with $150,000 in superannuation will be $81,478 worse off by the time they reach Age Pension age if this change proceeds.
While $150,000 may sound like a lot of money we need to remember that these are the funds that people were hoping would support them through‐out 20 or 30 years of retirement.
Ironically, having been forced to draw on that money for up to ten years, those people—who previously might have been totally self‐sufficient in retirement—may then qualify for an Age Pension.

The other point I would take issue with the Minister on is her recent statements that superannuation assets are no different to other assets and should, therefore, be treated no differently to things like shares or investment properties.
It seems to me that this view totally ignores the multi‐party acceptance over the past few years that superannuation assets are indeed different to other assets.
What we are talking about is sacrificed income that people have put away, with Government encouragement, to help provide for themselves in their retirement.
. . . And I stress the point that the Government have encouraged people to invest in superannuation.

That encouragement has been provided through concessional taxation treatment because it is snot only in the individual's best interest to invest in superannuation but also, from the view of national savings and relieving the pressure on our Age Pension system, in the Government's best interests.
It is these factors which set superannuation apart from assets such as shares and investment properties and it is these factors which the Minister seems unable, or unwilling, to acknowledge.

A further point that needs to be made is that at the inquiry held by the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation we heard that the Government has not undertaken any long‐term modelling on the effect of this change.
It seems clear that to a large degree there is a false economy here—people being denied a payment, to give the Government savings now, who'll then receive a higher payment further down the track.

Finally, to date, I have not seen any detail on just how people are expected to access the interest the Minister says they can live on. Superannuation funds are not going to be making fortnightly interest payments to assist people to top up their income support payment.

In addition to that, you have the situation where, to access their superannuation in accordance with the requirements of the Superannuation Industry Regulations, these people would have to provide their super fund with a statutory declaration saying they no longer intended to work.
At the same time, however, to receive a Newstart Allowance they'd have to be submitting forms to the Department of Social Security each fortnight saying `yes I am actively seeking work'.
In other words, these people will be put in a position where they are forced to lie on their Statutory Declarations and to my knowledge the Minister has not yet shed any light on this inconsistency.

The Democrats believe that, while there may be some justification for limiting the access to Social Security payments of those with large amounts of superannuation, those with low or modest levels simply must be quarantined from this change.

We would agree with the majority report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation when it emphasised that superannuation should not just be seen as another form of saving and investment and we would endorse the recommendations of that Committee.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one concern in relation to the superannuation proposals about which I think I can set people's minds at rest, and that is the question whether people can access their superannuation or not. Some people have difficulty when they go and ask their fund to release the superannuation. They can then go to the Insurance and Superannuation Commission for permission and, where they can demonstrate hardship and that they need to access the money, they will get it.

BREAK.PARA: But there are still circumstances in which some people cannot access their superannuation. Where that happens, I have the discretion to ensure that they are exempted from the provisions. I urge the chamber to consider this very seriously. It is treating all savings alike. Despite what Senator Sherry said, there are a number of other savings that are, in fact, long-term ones.

I can think of nothing more compelling than the investment which many people in Australia put into their small business. It may not be the same small business that they started out their working life in but they roll over their capital into one small business after another. They do this with the view that it will be their nest egg for retirement. I would suggest that that, too, is a long-term investment for retirement income. But, as far as the confirmation goes, it is very important to understand that, where somebody genuinely cannot access their superannuation, I have the power to exempt them from the provisions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to very briefly deal with schedule 2 of the bill. I know Senator West and others want to make important contributions on this. I will be as quick as I possibly can.

SPEECH.PARA: This schedule cuts the maximum rate of rent assistance by a third for singles living in shared accommodation. We oppose this measure—we have said so since the budget—by seeking to omit this schedule from the bill. The coalition went to the election with a promise about rent assistance. Let me remind the committee what it was:
The coalition recognises the vital role of the payment of rent assistance in reducing after housing poverty. A coalition government is committed to maintaining the real value of rent assistance.

This schedule cuts rent assistance paid to single people in shared accommodation. About 80,000 people will be affected, and it will cut that rate of rent assistance by a third. It is a clear broken promise on the part of this government.

PARA.BREAK: As we said in our minority report on this legislation, it is inequitable and it reduces the incomes of some 80,000 of the poorest Australians. It restricts the housing choices avail able to people whose choices are already very limited. It introduces new complexities, new inequities, into the social security system. It is a measure that we cannot contemplate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
Schedule 2
Reduce Rent Assistance for singles

From July next year, the maximum amount of Rent Assistance available to single people who share accommodation will be cut by one third from $73.80 a fortnight to $49.20 a fortnight—a reduction of $24.60.
The Government justifies this on the grounds that "single people who share accommodation can achieve cheaper housing costs than single people living alone".

As result of this change, around 80,000 people lose up to $25 a fortnight. Most of those affected will be unemployed people but a significant number of Age and Disability Support Pensioneers will also be disadvantaged.
There are a number of points that need to be made in setting out our opposition to this proposal.
Firstly, people, particularly young people, are often forced to share accommodation because the level of their unemployment allowance is below the poverty line.

The biggest economy of scale these people reap is cheaper rent and, because they pay less rent, they receive less Rent Assistance. Thus, the current system already takes account of economies of scale.

Secondly, while people may achieve economies of scale other than rental costs by sharing accommodation, reducing Rent Assistance to account for these savings would not be appropriate as, in the Department's own words, "rent assistance is not intended to meet non‐housing costs".
Thirdly, if, as a result of this change, unemployed people move to a cheaper area they may end up losing their social security payment of 6 months.
Typically, the cheaper areas to live are those on the outskirts of town or in regional areas and are usually those with lower employment prospects.
So people may be caught in the unenviable position of being trapped into payhing an extra $25 a fortnight rent for risk of losing their payments for 6 months.

Fourthly (as Senator Allison has said) there are may Disability Support Pensioners who, as part of the process of de‐institutionalisation, have been placed in group housing. If this change goes through, any of those disabled people who share a major area of accommodation—such as a bathroom, bedroom or kitchen—will have their Rent Assistance slashed.
Finally, as if that wasn't enough, I'd draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the Coalition's pre‐election Social Security policy document specifically stated, and I quote:

PARA.TAB: The Coalition recognises the vital role of [rent assistance] in reducing after housing poverty. A Coalition Government is committed to maintaining the real value of rent assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats will not be supporting the government's attempts to break this election promise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an answer to this. Young people who are squashed and who do not have any money in their pockets will get further money taken out of their pockets. They should get a hargan saw, run it down the centre of the house, get a pile of fibro from the local tip, nail that down the centre and make sure that they stay either side—these are people who are sharing accommodation and who will have it cut. The people who end up with the toilet on their side might go and find a bucket so that the people on the other side can have a toilet on their side as well. Those who have the kitchen might go find a potbelly stove, or an apricot box as a table, and set up a kitchen on the other side of the divide for those who missed out on the kitchen. That way you will keep your allowance; that way you do not get it cut.

SPEECH.PARA: What an absurd situation. People who are sharing a house suddenly will have money taken out of their pockets when they are already on the breadline. This amendment stinks. It will cause huge problems. It is bringing in millions of dollars for the government, but it will cut to ribbons the meagre income that a lot of people in this country have. I oppose it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also to amend this piece of legislation. I do note that there is a government amendment around to exclude also people on disability support pensions and carer pensions from being subject to this. All I can say is that I have had a win. But it has taken me three months—Senator Woodley has been a lot of help—and a lot of hard work.
—Thanks to you, Senator West.

—Nothing in any of the estimates answers or any of the other answers that we have had gave any indication that the minister was looking at this. It still leaves me with the group that I have been concerned about, that is, mainly elderly or low income people and people with psychiatric or other disabilities living in grotty, absolutely filthy, foul little tenement boarding/lodging houses in the inner cities, particularly in Sydney.

SPEECH.PARA: I know they are titled boarding and lodging houses, but I think the minister needs to very carefully look at the definition of boarding and lodging. As I said in the debate on the second reading, the only thing in the cupboards there and the only thing served up on the tables in those places is cockroaches. They are appalling. They are atrocious. If you look in the Sydney papers, you will see that the cost of most of those places for a single room with share bath and share kitchen facilities is in excess of $85. It is usually in excess of $100.

These people will be considered to be sharing. They are people who can stay there because these are places that do not require bonds or references. This will give you some idea of the standards they have. People are being forced into these and will be forced into worse conditions than this.
