I commend that amendment to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, as I recognised earlier, I do say that is great. However, I still have major concerns with the issue. To say that singles are getting more than couples is a bit trivial. Couples have the advantage that they can live and rent a one‐bedroom unit, apartment or facility without running the risk two singles would if they were renting a one‐bedroom place. The couple will not have Social Security coming in to check what the sleeping accommodation is. With singles, if two of them happen to be sharing a one‐bedroom place, Social Security will be in to check that they are in single beds, so they are up for a great deal more invasion of privacy.

SPEECH.PARA: Minister, I have a question. I think there is an unintended consequence of this amendment. I will go back to my grotty tenement place where we have the shared bathroom and shared kitchen. I ask you: is it now not true that, as a result of this amendment that you are going to move, you could have in one room someone on a disability support pension, perhaps with a psychiatric disability or some other sort of disability, sharing the kitchen and bathroom with somebody who is in receipt of an old age pension and who lives in the next room? That person who is in receipt of the old age pension will get a reduction in rent assistance. The person on the disability support pension will not get any reduction in their rent assistance, but the old age pensioner, the widow pensioner or any other of those sorts of beneficiaries, is going to cop a reduction in their rent assistance.

Usually the people living in these situations are single, elderly women. Maybe they are widowed or maybe they have been single and never worked in an occupation that has enabled them to have superannuation and they are totally dependent on the flat basic rate of the old age pension. They will suffer a cut in their rent assistance while the person on the disability support pension who is living in the room next door, sharing the same facilities, will not have their rent assistance cut. Is that not an anomaly? Is that not discrimination against that old age pensioner?

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Temporary Chair—
—Don't rescue her. I want an answer from her.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Sorry, Senator. I thought it was a rhetorical question. If there is discrimination involved in the government's amendment, Senator, I would suggest it is active discrimination to advantage people who are especially disadvantaged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —We have not got an answer to that. Senator West, I was not moving to rescue the minister. I do have a point of view to put here as well. This situation has occurred during the day, unfortunately. As I see it, there has been some government awakening to its responsibility to the people who will be hurt by this amendment, but that leaves a range of people in shared accommodation greatly disadvantaged. Everything I said earlier remains, as far as young people, in particular, but also a whole range of people in our community who are living in shared accommodation are concerned. Very often, those are the people in greatest need.

SPEECH.PARA: Because people are sharing accommodation their rent assistance will be cut by a third. That might not mean very much to people in this chamber but a cut of $24 or $25 out of their fortnightly income will have a huge impact on those people.

The nasty thing about this measure, as with so many measures we have discussed today, is that it is designed to meet the government's budgetary requirements. It is not to meet a social purpose; it is not to get around fraud or some sort of loophole. It is designed simply to take money out of poor people's pockets, out of the pockets of the vulnerable, to meet a government need to give rebates to corporations which have been able to lobby this government more effectively than people who have been living in pretty hard circumstances in shared accommodation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —While we are waiting for Senator Harradine, I draw the attention of the chamber to a further amendment which has been distributed by the government in relation to the impairment tables, which the government foreshadowed earlier it would withdraw.

—The minister was talking about discriminating in favour of people on the disadvantaged support pension. I have no problem with giving them every assistance possible. The thing that concerns me is that anyone who has to live solely on a benefit has no discretionary funds. Every cent of their income is expended. I think we are being frightfully cruel to out old age pensioners and widows if we subject them to that sort of treatment. It is not fair to them and it should not be allowed to happen to them. I would be very upset if it were my parents it was happening to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —As the minister and Senator West would know, I have been involved for many years with people with disabilities. A great deal of concern has been expressed because people have gone out of institutions and into homes—many of them group homes—under a carer, and this measure would have affected them. I acknowledge what the minister has done in respect to that particular matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I come now to the matter of superannuation. I ask for an assurance from the government that a person still working, and hence unable to gain access to their superannuation, would have superannuation treated as an inaccessible asset. Some persons aged 55 to 65 are into early retirement but others are still seeking work.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can give that assurance without qualification.

—I have a further question on rent assistance. Would it not be true that someone on a disability support pension and receiving rent assistance who turned 60 or 65, depending on their gender, and went on to an old age pension will actually suffer a cut in their pension because their rent assistance would be dropped?

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to Senator West's question is no, because those persons would stay on the disability support pension.
—Forever? They could stay on the disability support pension for the rest of their lives, until they turned 100?
—The advice I have from the officials is that, provided they continue to meet the disability criteria, they can stay on the disability support pension.
—How many disability support pensioners are there over the eligible age for receipt of the old age pension?
—I cannot provide that information tonight.
—Perhaps that could go on notice.
—Yes.

—I need to express my view about the proposed legislation in regard to superannuation. I am inclined not to vote for the proposal by the opposition and the Australia Democrats. The government has a point. Time does not enable me to elaborate greatly but I ask this question: why should someone with a house, plus $180,000, plus $250,000 in superannuation be regarded as eligible for welfare? That is a matter which, in the two minutes left, the minister might be able to explain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Because the 67,000 people who will be affected by this measure are people who were encouraged 10, 20 and 30 years ago to put their money into superannuation believing that they would not be required to access it, in part or in whole, prior to the age of 60 to 65, and because many of them have actually entered into financial agreements whereby they will collect an annuity or pension when they reach the age of 60, they will now have to unravel these agreements in order to access some form of income from their superannuation to offset the loss in income from disability or unemployment benefit. In unravelling those agreements, they may have to pay a fee or a charge. They will have less income when they reach the age of 60 or 65, having been told by Labor and Liberal governments—not just told but actively encouraged—to put money into superannuation for their retirement.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other point I would make is that Senator Newman talks about different asset classes in superannuation. If we followed her principle, we would be deeming an income on a person's house when they reached the age of 55. I think that would be totally unacceptable.
Progress reported.

DEBATE.TITLE: WORKPLACE RELATIONS AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 December, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor opposition has circulated eight amendments in the chamber. I should indicate that we are not proceeding with amendments 5 and 6 to the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). I may make some further comments over the next hour, but I do know my colleagues from Victoria, Senator Collins and Senator Cooney, certainly have a deep interest in industrial relations—
—And real expertise.

—And real expertise, that is right, Senator Faulkner, unlike the government. Being Victorian senators, they have an obvious interest in a piece of legislation that transfers at least in part the Victorian industrial relations system into the federal jurisdiction. I might make some further comments, but I will be leaving the bulk of those comments on behalf of Labor to Senator Collins and Senator Cooney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). I think I should recount a story I recounted to somebody recently about the kind of situation the Senate finds itself in. I used the term `squirrel handshake' and the person concerned said to me, `What on earth is a squirrel handshake?' and I said, `A squirrel handshake is like the situation the Victorian legislature has the Senate in over this bill—namely, that it is referring something to us which we want, but it is referring it to us in a manner which makes it very difficult for us to amend.' He said, `Yes, I understand that, but what does a squirrel handshake mean?' and I said, `It's an old sporting term from my part of the world which refers to someone squeezing your nuts.' That may not be all that parliamentary, but it is very explicit about the situation we have.

SPEECH.PARA: The question for this Senate is: do we accept or reject the referral? On balance, we think we should, so do the unions and, incidentally, so do Labor and the Democrats. This bill's giving legislative effect to the reference of Victoria's IR powers to the Commonwealth is not quite a mouse, but it is not quite a lion either. Hopefully in time the two governments will advance to a complete system.

At the time of the announcement, we were told by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), by Minister Reith and by Premier Kennett that this was a historic achievement, unprecedented in 96 years of Commonwealth government, and a massive change of massive benefit to workers and employers alike in Victoria. That is a little hyperbolic, but it is certainly the first time we have been faced under the constitution with a unitary system for a state and the Commonwealth on industrial relations, or at least the progress towards one.

PARA.BREAK: However, when the Victorian state legislation was tabled, a different reality emerged. True, Victoria has proceeded to refer industrial relations matters to the Commonwealth, but not all of them. We welcome the referrals that have occurred, and we welcome the fact that the Victorians have finally accepted the reality and benefits of the federal system. But those matters that have been referred are qualified. The reference is, unfortunately, subject to overriding Victorian legislation at any time and can be withdrawn by the Vic torian cabinet at any time, in which case we will return to the situation that pertained prior.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Industrial Relations Commission will not enjoy the power invested by every state commission of making comprehensive common law awards. Its power over Victorian public servants, particularly the between 10,000 and 11,000 police, is severely curtailed. Indeed, it is difficult to fully see just what altogether Victoria is ceding with respect to its own employees. True, we do know it is ceding unfair dismissal powers but that was only under the threat of the Democrats and the Senate dragging them into the federal jurisdiction with the external affairs power anyway.

It should be pointed out that, courtesy of the fast‐track mechanism placed in the industrial relations acts by the ALP and the Democrats in 1992, the vast bulk, at least three‐quarters, of Victorian workers have already exited the Victorian system for the Commonwealth. The last group of Victorian public servants finally achieved their first federal award yesterday. Each constitutional challenge by the Victorians was rejected by the High Court allowing justice for Victorian workers but at the expense of millions of dollars of workers' and taxpayers' funds wasted in futile litigation.

This bill is of benefit to the Commonwealth figure of between 100,000 and 200,000 workers left in the Victorian system and the Victorian figure of up to 400,000. Take your pick, it is certainly not more than one‐quarter of Victorian workers. It will allow easier access to federal awards, to certified agreements and to Australian workplace agreements. It will provide access to protected industrial action for workers on collective agreements at the conclusion of their agreements, for workers on individual agreements when the agreements are deemed to end in three years, and for all other workers immediately.

It will preserve the minimum underpinning conditions of the Victorian industrial relations system, but with the AIRC taking over the role of setting minimum wages. It will ensure that no new employment agreements can be entered into under the Victorian system. All new agreements will have to be vetted by the commission or the Employment Advocate as certified agreements or Australian workplace agreements.

Victorian workers will not any more have to contrive an interstate dispute to access the federal award making powers. However, unions will still need to log employers because the Victorians would not cede common rule powers. They will still need to show that the making of an award is in the public interest and where there is a bona fide employment agreement in place, which has the support of both employers and employees, the commission will not be able to proceed to make an award to override the agreement unless it would not be contrary to the public interest.

In the committee stage, I will be moving an amendment to exclude the operation of section 111AAA where agreements are not bona fide—that is, where agreements were not genuinely made; for example, where agreements were made under coercion or duress. Given that the Victorian employment agreements were not vetted and given the parlous state of the Victorian labour market over the past four years, evidence at the Senate inquiry into the Workplace Relations Bill was that many employment agreements were able to be forced on employees and with them substandard working conditions.

The Democrats do not believe, and obviously because they will support our amendment, neither does the government, that such employment agreements—in other words, those which are not bona fide—should be recognised as adequate for the purposes of section 111AAA. We will be moving to ensure that workers subject to such employment agreements have prompt access to awards. I also note that the commission retains its powers under section 111(1D) to make interim awards for such employees quickly.

The Democrats are also concerned about two other aspects of the bill. Firstly, we are concerned that the transitional arrangements for associations recognised in the Victorian system could become a back door means for associations to avoid the registration requirement of the federal system. We wish to ensure that important protections, such as the conveniently belong rule in section 189, apply fully to those organisations and that transitional recognition arrangements end after one or two years. I ask the minister to address this issue in the drafting of regulations and to ensure that the ACTU, employer groups and the major parties concerned are consulted.

The Democrats are further concerned that section 493(2) will allow regulations to proscribe state laws of Victoria which can override federal awards. The Victorian state reference legislation already sets down what are in our view far too many situations where they can override federal awards and we would be most concerned about a large number of other laws being proscribed in federal law in addition. I seek an assurance from the minister that this power would be used sparingly to preserve to the greatest degree possible the integrity of the federal award system when dealing with those workers who are not presently within it. With these comments, I wish to indicate that the Democrats will be supporting the government's bill and we will be supporting the government's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Jeff Kennett was pleased with the Commonwealth's industrial relations bill. This bill gives effect to the announcement by the Victorian and Commonwealth governments on 11 November 1996 with respect to the partial referral of Victoria's industrial relations powers to the Commonwealth using section 51 (xxxvii) of the federal constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: As indicated in the Bills Digest this referral will allow Commonwealth industrial laws to apply to people and activities which would otherwise be outside the scope of its constitutional powers. It should also be noted that the scope of the bill is largely determined by the matters conferred on the Commonwealth by the Victorian parliament in the Commonwealth Powers (Industrial Relations) Act 1996.

At the outset, I would like to repeat the concerns I outlined when the motion to exempt this bill from the cut‐off motion was debated. That concern relates to the undue haste with which this legislation has been pushed through this parliament. The reality is that this bill, which represents one of the most important constitutional changes in the industrial relations arena this century, could have been debated in February next year. It is important in this context to note that the proposed intergovernmental agreement between the Commonwealth and the Victorian governments in relation to this issue will not be finalised until early next year. Why then are we debating this bill in a limited time frame on the last day of sitting for 1996.

Whilst I am pleased that the bill was referred to the Senate Economics Committee for a quick examination, the fact remains that many of the people who made submissions to the committee were forced to throw together their ideas at extremely short notice and with very little information. I am sure that many of the implications of the bill will not become apparent until next year. By that time, it will be too late.

I support the minority report of Senators Sherry and Cook but I believe that, if the ALP amendments are not passed, the bill will not be supportable. I will not discuss the amendments in detail at this point, but I feel that on balance the protections inherent in these amendments will improve the bill sufficiently to enable me to support it. Without them, this bill has too many grey areas, and I feel it would be inappropriate to support such a bill largely on trust.

Yes, to a certain extent we have been caught between a rock and a hard place, but it is a bit like being forced to change your clothes in a cupboard. There was always another alternative, and that alternative was to wait until February and deal with this properly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some comments I would also like to make on behalf of the Labor Party during the second reading debate of the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996. This is indeed a unique piece of legislation and, at this late stage of the sittings, I appreciate Senator Murray's humour in referring to it as a `squirrel handshake'. Carrying that analogy a bit further, I feel less constrained than my colleague in that I cannot have certain things squeezed.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been pointed out, the bill is a mechanism by which the Commonwealth receives a referral from the state of Victoria. I am perhaps familiar with this type of behaviour from the Premier of Victoria. I was somewhat amused in the hearings of the committee when we became apprised of the fact that Victoria and the Commonwealth were preparing to enter into an intergovernmental agreement to underpin this legislation, but the agreement itself had not yet been finalised and certainly could not be made available to us the very people considering the legislation.

When I posed a question in those hearings as to how we were to consider what potential amendments might be appropriate, the response was that I was proposing a double hypothetical. I pointed out to the department official at the time that half of that hypothetical was actually the government's, and perhaps that is the major criticism in relation to this bill. It is extremely hypothetical and we have many concerns with respect to it.

We will be moving several amendments in relation to those concerns but, at this stage, I would like to highlight the main concern. Our central criticism of the reference and of the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) as a whole is that, contrary to the rhetoric of the Victorian government in particular and also the federal government, it does not represent a giant leap forward towards a single system of industrial relations. To the contrary, the effect of the reference and of the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) is to graft on to the federal industrial relations system the existing Victorian industrial relations system. In effect, the principal features of the Victorian system are continued under the auspices of the Commonwealth legislation.

I dread to think when it was accepted that there were several complexities with the Workplace Relations Act, but it was claimed by the government that this bill was solving several problems. I dread to think what act we might ultimately end up with if other states were also to agree under this sort of environment to refer their powers as well.

The major concerns we have—and I will deal further with them in the amendments as we deal with them—are all of the exclusions. The problems with this bill are not only the way in which Victoria has been accommodated into the federal act and the compromises that have been made to that effect but also the several areas of exclusion and the results consequent to those. I will deal further with those issues as we move on.

To conclude, it is our view that the reference as a whole and the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) as a whole are in many ways a disappointing second best outcome. Nevertheless, we acknowledge that the reference and the bill may provide advantages to some workers while not disadvantaging any others—although there have been some questions raised to that effect by the Victorian police. For these reasons, our present inclination is to vote in support of the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), subject of course to seeking support for the amendments that we will proceed with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with all that has been said so far in relation to the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996, but I will add a few thoughts of my own. These powers have been referred, as have other powers in the past, to the Commonwealth from Victoria under section 51(xxxvii) of the constitution—the states can give and the states can take away. That does lead, as has been already suggested, to uncertainty.

SPEECH.PARA: I would ask the relevant government senator, when replying to our speeches during the committee stage, to tell us what guarantees, if any, the state of Victoria has given to leave these powers with the Commonwealth at least in the foreseeable future so that the Commonwealth can proceed with its legislation and be assured that that legislation will be stable for some years to come.

I also wish to raise an issue that really has to do with Victoria but, since the Commonwealth is taking on these powers, it has some responsibility to see that what has been left behind in Victoria has been attended to in a proper way. There are two points I would like to raise and perhaps receive an answer to during the committee stage.

The first point is in relation to the Employee Relations Commission of Victoria and what is going to happen to it. Is the same thing going to happen to that as happened to the Accident Compensation Commission, which I think would be most unfortunate? In other words, are the personnel on that body going to be attended to? Is there any intention, for example, to appoint the people presently on the Employee Relations Commission of Victoria to the federal body? It may be that the federal body will have additional powers and responsibilities which will mean they will need further people on it.

In any event, I want to raise as a big issue for us as the Commonwealth—and of course it relates to Victoria directly but it also relates to the Commonwealth takeover of these powers—what is going to happen with the Employee Relations Commission of Victoria.

The other point I want to have clarified is what is happening with the proceedings that are currently under way with the State Public Services Federation. The battles that that union has had over the years with the state are going to have the outcome that they would have had, had these powers not been referred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to Senator Cooney's specific request, I think it would be better to deal with those matters at the committee stage. Then, if I do not thoroughly answer each one of those points, he will be able to get up again and make sure that I do.

SPEECH.PARA: A lot of the debate about this quite historic legislation over the days and weeks since the agreement was announced by the Victorian and Australian governments has been in relation to how significant this referral is. People who have been—to say it kindly—cynical about the significance of this referral have tried to downplay the size and effect of the referral.

BREAK.PARA: I do ask in a rhetorical way that people who seek to downplay the significance of a referral of this type should do two things. Firstly, they should look at the debates on the arbitration and conciliation sections of the Commonwealth constitution that took place when the federation of Australia was formed nearly 100 years ago. They should look at the debate that took place among the founding fathers in relation to these powers and observe how careful they were to create a balance of power between the states and the Commonwealth in relation to industrial relations matters.

Secondly, I challenge people who would seek to downplay the significance of this—what I would regard as—historical agreement and referral to find anywhere else in Australian federal history a referral of such a significant power from one of the significant states of the Australian federation to the Commonwealth parliament. As much as you may seek, for good political reasons on the other side, to downplay the significance of this referral, it will go down in history as a significant event in the development of Australia's constitutional history. I thank all senators for their contributions to the debate and look forward to considering this bill further in committee. I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, item 3, page 6 (lines 18 to 24), omit subsection 2.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —The effect of opposition amendment No. 1 is to provide that Victorian laws do not prevail over awards or orders of the federal commission pertaining to employees in the Victorian public sector.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment points out, as I have indicated earlier, that in some ways this reference of powers from Victoria is a joke. Under the current bill, the Victorian government is not only in the position to revoke its reference of powers but it is also in the position, were it to choose, in relation to the Victorian public sector, to simply make legislation to override what might be a federal ruling of the commission.

That is the position that obtains under this bill: in relation to Victorian employees in the public sector, the Victoria government can at any time rule to override a determination. There is simply no justification for discriminating against public sector employees in this regard. It is not the situation that prevails with regard to private sector employees. We submit, in supporting this amendment, that it should not provide such in relation to public sector employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that I will support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will briefly describe why the coalition will be asking the Senate not to support the opposition amendment. Senator Murray referred to this matter briefly in his second reading contribution. The minority report of the committee that looked into this matter last week also in places accepted the view that the Commonwealth parliament should deal with the referral on the basis on which it was made.

SPEECH.PARA: Although proposed section 493(2) is not required by the state referral legislation, it is one of the bases on which Victoria agreed to include the state public sector within the referral. The provision is not unprecedented. Section 121 of the Workplace Relations Act does not allow the AIRC to exercise jurisdiction over Commonwealth or territorial public sector employment in a way that is inconsistent with prescribed Commonwealth or territory laws. Similarly, state industrial laws typically make similar provision. Any public sector law prescribed under proposed section 493 will only prevail over an award or order made under the extended jurisdiction. It will also be specified in a regulation which can be disallowed by the Senate. I will respond to Senator Murray's specific point. There should be no fear of any sweeping use of this power, as we do not expect Victoria to seek its wide use.

TALK.START.PARA: —In that context, how much power has the Victorian government got over its state public service, given the litigation that has been occurring between the State Public Services Federation and the government over the last few years, in any event? Arising from this is two points. First, how much room is there left if the state wants to exercise power over its public service, given that litigation? Second, of the power that it has, how much of it has it ceded to the Commonwealth and on what sort of time basis? How long has it ceded it for?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —On the first point, this legislation will not affect matters that are the subject of interstate disputes. The litigation you are referring to, and most of the litigation that has taken place, takes place under that provision, so that will not be affected. Secondly, they are shared powers. We expect and hope that they continue indefinitely. Clearly—this answers one of the questions you asked in the second reading debate—they can always take the power back.

SPEECH.PARA: It also answers one of Jacinta Collins's questions raised in the second reading debate about the intergovernmental agreement. The Commonwealth and the Victorian government would make it a matter of that sort of agreement. It needs to be a side agreement. If, for example, a future Brumby government in Victoria decided that they wanted to take the power back, there would be in place a government to government agreement which said that in the circumstances that may occur. There would be certain notice provisions and agreements between the governments as to how that might take place. We hope that this will stay in place for a long time, even though we cannot force it because of the work of our founding fathers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to clear up whether any consideration has been given by the Commonwealth to the Employee Relations Commission of Victoria. Has there been any agreement or discussion between the Commonwealth and the state about that body and the people who are presently on it?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to Senator Cooney's question, as I am advised, is that no decisions have to my knowledge yet been taken about what use will be made of the ERCV members in the future. Similarly, no decisions have been made about the Commonwealth tribunal's resources.

—I would like to further clarify this issue, especially given that there was some question originally about the haste with which we might be moving with this legislation. It is now obvious that it is moving with fairly extreme haste. I presume that the intergovernmental agreement that will be underpinning this legislation may also be dealing with some of the issues that Senator Cooney has raised. I do not think it is unreasonable to ask the parliamentary secretary at this stage when we can expect to see the terms of the intergovernmental agreement that is meant to underpin this legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, we do not believe that the intergovernmental agreement underpins this. The legislation that has been passed and proclaimed by the Victorian parliament and this legislation, which hopefully will be passed and proclaimed shortly, are the underpinnings of it. Victoria and the Commonwealth will make an intergovernmental agreement about the referral of powers. The agreement cannot modify or deviate from what is put in place by our two parliaments. The agreement will address operational issues, such consultation about legislation or a notice of any intention to change or withdraw from the referral, as I said in response to Senator Cooney's question. There has been no indication that the Victorian government or parliament proposes to withdraw any referral; it is quite the reverse. Constitutionally, it is a matter for the state to decide. The intergovernmental agreement will be pro gressed. I am told, very quietly and softly, that that will occur over the next few weeks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the parliamentary secretary for that response. The `very quietly and silently' issue is one that I think it is appropriate that we address at this stage. In the committee dealing with this legislation we unfortunately had no minister present. It was left up to very brave departmental officials to attempt to deal with this issue. We should have on the record the circumstances in which the parliamentary secretary was put on this issue as well. However, in committee we were given the clear impression that this intergovernmental agreement was proposed to underpin arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cooney has raised some quite valid questions in relation to this legislation. Obviously of relevance is the future functioning of the Victorian Employee Relations Commission. Other circumstances which have been raised at this stage are of equal relevance. I understand that some of the concerns that have been raised about registered organisations may well be satisfied and may well be part of such an agreement. But these are all things of which we are unaware. A matter of great concern too are statements to the effect that certain things may be dealt with in regulations. This is extremely unsatisfactory. I revisit the comment in my second reading statement that this is obviously a second‐best outcome.

As I indicated earlier, we will be proceeding with our amendments on the basis that we do not believe that some intergovernmental agreement which is unclear and not before us should be the basis on which not to move with amendments. Obviously some arrangements are being made outside the actual terms of reference in relation to the referral of these powers. We believe it is appropriate to deal with some of our issues in that environment, particularly when we are not privy to even the draft terms of discussions which very quietly might become available in a couple of weeks. I ponder what is going to occur in Victoria when this comes into effect early in the new year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a couple of comments about this intergovernmental agreement. Mr Chairman, you have had lengthy experience in the Senate. Senator Cooney chairs the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, and I think you were a member of the committee at some stage—
—At one time I was chairman.

—We have here a piece of legislation referring state powers to the federal jurisdiction. In principle, we now have no opposition to that concept. We have an intergovernmental agreement that refers to that transfer and some quite vital issues. It is not uncommon to have an intergovernmental agreement in dealing with these types of transfers of state powers to the federal jurisdiction. The point is we did not know about this intergovernmental agreement till the committee met. It was during the course of questioning that it came to light that there was this intergovernmental agreement. The intergovernmental agreement is still secret.

SPEECH.PARA: Maybe we should call this legislation the Christmas tree legislation—there is a little present under the Christmas tree, an intergovernmental agreement that we are going to unwrap on Christmas Day and as a result the Victorian workers are going to discover they are all better off.

There is a serious issue of principle here. I recall my brief time on the Scrutiny of Bills Committee where this type of principle was scrutinised and criticised. An intergovernmental agreement certainly has some effect on the legislation we are considering and yet this agreement is secret. Here we are today being asked to pass legislation with this secret agreement still wrapped up in a package under the Christmas tree somewhere. That just seems to me to be a very bad principle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Merry Christmas from Jeff.

—Yes, Merry Christmas from Jeff in his Christmas suit. I am sure he would do anything for publicity in Victoria. Senator Cooney, as Chair of this Scrutiny of Bills Committee, I hope you would look at this issue in principle—the issue of secret intergovernmental agreements not being made public until after the legislation is passed. That is a regrettable principle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to that. I cannot believe that Senator Sherry is entirely serious about this because he has been in government. Senator Cooney will recall one of the very first committee hearings I ever went to. The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs did an inquiry for about three hours one night into the new Corporations Law, which was a significant constitutional achievement in terms of getting the states to cooperate in that area—an area for which I now have responsibility, as the circles go round in politics.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sherry, Senator Jacinta Collins and Senator Cooney—indeed all honourable senators—should know that there is another case of a law put in place by agreements of the state parliaments and the Commonwealth parliament in relation to their powers over certain matters. That is a legislative structure which envisages an agreement between those governments. In other words, it requires an agreement to make that legislation work. That agreement that does not underpin that legislation but actually helps make that legislation work—it makes the Corporations Law work—was contemplated by that legislative scheme. This intergovernmental agreement is also contemplated by this scheme. It is not a secret agreement. It is a typical administrative structure where governments bring into place a new scheme—

TALK.START.PARA: —You have been watching Yes, Minister too much.
—I have not seen it for weeks, Senator Sherry. It is a normal administrative instrument that puts into place how each government will deal over matters such as consultation.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the Corporations Law, I did not hear Senator Cooney either as chairman of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee or as chairman of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs complain that the Corporations Law agreement was not in place before that legislation came into this parliament. Indeed, Senator Cooney may not be surprised to learn that that agreement has yet to be signed by all of the jurisdictions who are part of it. That was not a secret conspiracy of an agreement that was going to be stuck under the Christmas tree and nor is this one. This one will be negotiated in the proper way. It is to put into place the administrative arrangements to make this referral work and those sorts of instruments are quite normal when these things occur.

I am advised—I am happy to be flogged at the stake of the Senate next year if it does not happen—that this will not be a secret document; that it will actually be public. It is not even a document at this moment, so it cannot really be secret. It will be finished in the next few weeks. When it is all finished, we will look forward to its coming out from under the Christmas tree so Senator Sherry can see the present we have for him and the rest of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the parliamentary secretary actually makes the right point because regulations do follow legislation, normally. My understanding is that regulations, under no circumstances, can undermine the legislation itself; they have to follow it. There are occasions the Senate has seen where regulations or agreements have preceded legislation. Competition policy was one such thing which was agreed between the states and the then Labor government and then sent to the Senate to tick off—in another squirrel grip experience, probably.

SPEECH.PARA: The real issue here is that the opposition—to build on the metaphor or simile or certainly the amusement you gave me about your present under the Christmas tree analogy—fear that there is a bomb in the present. That reflects a fundamental distrust that Labor and working people have of both governments and it is something you, the government, have to deal with. I will put my faith in you and not support the Labor amendment, but I would hate to be disappointed and discover it is a bomb and not a teddy bear because you will lose me for many years to come. I hope that you will fulfil the promise of your remarks and that your regulations will indeed abide not only by the letter but by the spirit of the referral and the agreement.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —The effect of these amendments is to provide that common law contracts of employment entered into in future in Victoria must comply with both the Victorian statutory minima and the federal no disadvantage test. This concern is perhaps one of the greatest in relation to this bill.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the major concerns—and this example highlights it—is that under this bill some future employees that fall under such contracts will only have to meet the Victorian statutory minima. So, in effect, there are people that are left behind from this supposed new unitary system. In an attempt to accommodate Mr Kennett with his Christmas present, we have left these people out. This amendment seeks to rectify that problem by ensuring—and I highlight in particular for some future employees not currently under any type of employment arrangement—that those future employees will have to meet the federal minima.

We are very concerned that common law contracts of employment are to continue under the agreement between the government and Victoria; nevertheless, we accept it. But we find it very difficult to accept that these contracts should only be underpinned by these Victorian statutory minima. Those minima are woefully inadequate. They do not protect enough terms and conditions of employment and, where they do, the protection is inadequate.

We do not think that this parliament should be party to continuing these inadequate minimum conditions in perpetuity, at least for new contracts in the future. At least for people such as prospective employees, the Victorian minima are totally inadequate—and it highlights a serious flaw with this bill.

Not only that; the simple truth is that if this reference of powers is to create a true, single system of industrial relations in Victoria, surely the same minima should underpin employment contracts, be it a certified agreement, an AWA or a common law contract of employment. That is the principle applied by the Workplace Relations Act and that is what should be applied in this bill. This amendment ensures that in this respect there is consistency. If the no disadvantage test is good enough for employees on AWAs and certified agreements, it should be good enough for employees on other types of employment contracts, in particular, prospective employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) will be supporting these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to what Senator Jacinta Collins said, the no disadvantage test has been specifically designed to ensure that formal agreements under the Workplace Relations Act do not result in any overall loss of entitlements for employees. However, it would be inappropriate to extend a test which was designed for a particular statutory purpose to all contracts of employment. Apart from any other consideration, it would be unrealistic to expect public authorities to assess all contracts against such a test.

SPEECH.PARA: Another important point to make is that no other jurisdiction provides such a requirement for common law contracts. When I say `no other jurisdiction', I specifically refer to the New South Wales legislation where, of course, we have a Labor government. If Senator Collins feels as strongly as she clearly does about the issue, it would be well worth her making the suggestion to the Hon. Jeff Shaw, the Minister for Industrial Relations in that state, recommending that the New South Wales government include such a provision.

Could I also, Mr Temporary Chairman, because time is very short and this debate will conclude in only five or six minutes, make a short statement in relation to a matter that is not directly related to the amendment that is before you. It is something I wanted to put on the record which I failed to do previously.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no problem, as long as we have enough time to incorporate our comments and move our amendments.

—Yes, this will only take one minute. It relates to the transitional registration periods of two years proposed under the bill relating to recognised associations. It is intended to allow existing recognised associations to be given under the new arrangements similar rights to those which they now have under the Victorian Employee Relations Act 1992. This will be provided for under the regulations. Those associations which choose to be transitionally registered will be able to seek to have a relevant minimum wage adjusted or to enforce a continuing employment agreement or minimum condition applying to their members under these new provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: The regulations will, however, not give such associations the standing of registered organisations for other purposes under the Workplace Relations Act. For example, the regulations will not provide for them to become parties in their own right to awards or certified agreements. Similarly, they will not have to meet the obligations of fully registered organisations, such as the financial accounting or election requirements.

BREAK.PARA: During the transitional period, the former recognised associations will be able to decide whether or not they wish to become fully registered under the WR act. If they decide to seek that status, they will have to meet the ordinary requirements for registration. There will be no alteration to the `conveniently belong' provisions. This does not apply, of course, to any former recognised organisation which is already a federally registered organisation or a branch of one. The government will consult the ACTU and the ACCI about the content of the regulations through the National Labour Consultative Council processes.

I have often accused my father of having a convenient memory. It seems this government has convenient consistency. It uses the consistency argument when it is obviously to its advantage.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me point out one major area of inconsistency that is being brought in with this legislation. What does not come with this legislation into the Commonwealth arena is the ability to make common rule awards. So there are going to be many more employers that are going to be subject to these types of employment agreements. You can't have your cake and eat it too. If you want to use the consistency argument, why are we not treating Victorian employees consistent with those which are in the federal arena through other means? The lack of an ability to make a common rule award is going to leave many of these Victorian employees in the position where they may come under Commonwealth contracts and, of course, they are going to face the much lower Victorian minimum test.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am getting a bit nervous with the passing of time. I want to be sure that, first, my amendment will be put within the period and, second, that I can incorporate such remarks as I have on the various amendments.

WORKPLACE RELATIONS BILL—LABOR AMENDMENTS
ALP No.2:

The Democrats will oppose this amendment. This amendment seeks to include a new and worrying level of complexity into the industrial relations system. To give an example, in an award free area, one employer might offer an employee $40,000 p.a. for a 40 hour week. But they would be prevented from doing that unless they came to the AIRC and got that offer of employment ticked off as fitting the no disadvantage test. In every State of Australia, common law contracts are not affected like this. If there is an award in place, the common law contract cannot override the award, and that will also be the case in Victoria. But, this goes much further than that. The Democrats approach in it's amendment of seeking to ensure that access to the award system is enhanced we naturally think is a better alternative. I might also note that no new employment contracts under the Victorian system will be permissible—if employers want a formal document lodged with an industrial authority, they will need to pursue an AWA.

The Democrats have some sympathy for what the ALP is trying to do here, but I think these amendments will create unnecessary complexity in the system. I might also add that the three year rule applies only to negotiated agreements—employees under deemed agreements will have immediate access to protected action.

TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

On behalf of Senator Jacinta Collins, I seek leave to incorporate her remarks on remaining amendments in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
SPEAKING POINTS FOR ALP AMENDMENTS TO WORKPLACE RELATIONS BILL (No. 2)
Oppostition (3) (4)
This amendment addresses what we see as an inconsistency in this Bill and in its relationship with the Workplace Relations Act.

The Bill provides that a party on an existing individual employment contract cannot engage in protected industrial action until at least 3 years after the commencement of the Bill. The practical terms this means that for this 3 year period parties do not have the capacity to engage in industrial action to force entry to the Federal industrial relations system.

The problem we have with this provision is the insertion of a 3 year period after the commencement of the Bill. Where an employment contract has been on foot for some time prior to commencement of the Bill (anything up to 4 years) this means that protected action may not be available for anything up to 7 years of the life of the contract.
This is clearly inconsistent with the Workplace Relations Act that provides a 3 year maximum period without the right to protected action.

Our initial reaction to this problem was to recommend a 3 year period after commencement of the employment contract, whenever that might be. However, before the Committee Mr Stewart‐Crompton pointed out that many employment contracts in Victoria do not have a certain start date.
Clearly this must be taken into account. In our view it can be.
We therefore seek to amend section 523 of this Bill to the following effect.
Where the start of the employment contract is known to parties should not be entitled to engage in protected industrial action during the period of 3 years after the start of the contract.

Where the start date of the employment contract is not known, the start date should be deemed to be 3 years prior to the date of commencement of this Bill, and the parties should not be entitled to engage in protected industrial action during the period of 3 years after this deemed start date.
Opposition (7)

The effect of this amendment is to provide quick access to the Federal award system where the subject‐matter of the dispute is a matter excluded from the Victorian reference of powers to the Commonwealth.
We are concerned that the reference of powers by Victoria to the Commonwealth is too restricted, and may exclude some important terms and conditions of employment.

Examples might include entry standards or qualifications to teach in Victorian Government schools; discipline of Victorian public servants by means of fines or demotion; procedures for making Victorian Government school teachers redundant. It also includes all terms and conditions of Victorian employees at the higher managerial levels in the public sector or in essential services or industries.
In practical terms, the effect of this restricted reference is that the Commission does not acquire jurisdiction to make awards in relation to these matters under the Victorian reference.
We can't amend the Bill to provide that the Commonwealth does acquire that jurisdiction.
What we can do is to provide that, where the Commission otherwise has jurisdiction to make awards about these matters, the parties can gain quick access to that jurisdiction.
That is the effect of this amendment.
