DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1996NATIONAL HEALTH (BUDGET MEASURES) AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 November and 31 October, on motions by Senator Campbell:

PARA.EMPHASIS: That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating two health bills. The Health Insurance Amendment Bill (No. 2) proposes to require medical graduates to complete postgraduate education in order to gain access to Medicare benefits. It is also to allow regulations to be made to reduce the Medicare benefit payable where multiple services are rendered and to increase the maximum amount a patient may be required to contribute towards certain medical procedures.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly on this bill when we get to the committee stage I have a number of questions to raise and issues to pursue with the parliamentary secretary in relation to how the provider numbers issue is going to benefit rural areas. I am still not totally convinced that the moves the government says will happen will be the case.

BREAK.PARA: The second bill is the National Health (Budget Measures) Amendment Bill 1996, the purpose of which is to increase patient contributions under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, restrict access to subsidised drugs to Australian residents and a restricted range of members of overseas missions, and make minor changes to the indexation of various patient contributions. This slugs those who are in receipt of benefits and health cards and who, until this bill is passed, are paying $2.75 per prescription and, after it is passed, will be paying $3.25. This increase in co‐payment for the first time is not associated with any associated increase in pension rate. So many pensioners will be worse off financially to the tune of 50c per prescription.

We know from the previous bills that we have been debating on social security that the government is committed to maintaining pensions at 25 per cent of male average weekly earnings but we can see that pensions are at a greater rate than that. This bill is going to cause people on pensions to have a reduction in their disposable incomes. This is an issue that I think is of great concern particularly to elderly people because, as I said earlier, people who live on age pensions and benefits do not have any significant amount of disposable income. They do not have discretionary spending.

The income they get is totally disposed of in the sheer, simple things of living; in covering their accommodation costs, their food and clothing. They do not have discretionary funding and this is of very great concern to those concerned about aged people. In the previous debate I raised the issue of people on old age pensions who could well be suffering a reduction in their rent assistance as well, so they are really being slugged on several different sides. The government is to be condemned for that. The opposition will be moving some amendments and I urge people to support them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I begin my speech on the second reading of the health bills, I indicate that three hours debate has been allocated for this bill. We might informally allocate one hour to the second reading, an hour and a half to the committee stage of the Health Insurance Amendment Bill (No. 2) and only half an hour to the budget measures. If there is agreement from the government on that, they might want to indicate that when they proceed on the second reading.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a cognate debate on two bills which, on the face of it, have no relationship—but there is a unifying theme. These bills are in keeping with the general philosophy of this government; that is, to slug those who are the most vulnerable in our community, to reduce services to those who most need it and to charge those who have the least resources. This government has abandoned the Australian philosophy of a fair go. It is making major cuts to health in Australia. This Howard government does not believe that health care should be universal; it believes it should be provided only to those who can afford to pay for it. The principle that is in danger of being undermined in the current debate about health care and by the approach this government is taking in its budget and other measures is the principle of the universal provision of and universal access to health care.

This budget and associated bills such as health insurance No. 2 have cut over $2 billion from expenditure on health care, most of which was used to offset the introduction of the private health insurance rebate. This has had very little impact on the quality or the extent of health care in Australia and the health care available to Australian citizens. This is in the face of evidence of premium rises that mean the rebate will have no impact on the cost of health insurance and will not make private health insurance more affordable for families.

This is what the community receives in exchange for massive cuts in federally funded medical services and reduction in the money given to public hospitals. All that this will do is to ensure that hospitals have no capacity to deliver the quality of service that, to date, they have been able to offer.

The result of this reduction will mean longer waiting lists in the case of elective surgery and a very serious threat to the quality of care in the case of emergency and other medical services. It may also mean that individuals, in fact, have to pay more, because a lot of services which the hospitals to date have been able to provide in‐house—physiotherapy, occupational therapy and social work—may not be able to continue to be provided. Patients may have to seek these services privately outside of a hospital.

The opposition has major difficulties with both these bills for three reasons, and they are quite simple: firstly, they are unfair; secondly, they have the effect of reducing the quality of health services provided; and, thirdly, they impact most heavily on the people who are least well off. The Labor opposition is opposed to the Health Insurance Amendment Bill (No. 2) and is opposed to three measures in the National Health (Budget Measures) Amendment Bill which increases co‐payments on pharmaceuticals. I will deal with the Health Insurance Amendment Bill (No. 2) first.

The opposition believes that this bill will have unfair and retrospective effect on current medical students and interns. We are concerned that it may aggravate the shortage of doctors in rural areas and severely restrict the options of medical students and interns who are seeking to postpone their postgraduate training or undertake that training part time.

The opposition also does not support the increase in the maximum permissible gap for out of hospital medical services from $30.20 to $50. We do not support this change because patients who receive services of unusual length or complexity will face very high out‐of‐pocket costs. We do not believe that this situation is remedied by the Medical Benefits Advisory Commission's discretionary power to award higher fees for services of unusual length and complexity.

In dealing with the work force issues, the opposition understands the necessity of managing the medical work force and, in particular, of managing access to Medicare to ensure that the Australian people get the best value they can for the money they provide to Medicare. The opposition also understands the need to ensure that those practising in medicine are of a good standard and that they are provided with appropriate training.

BREAK.PARA: In recent years it was the Labor government who took decisions aimed at limiting the number of overseas trained doctors coming to Australia and who worked with the medical profession to improve the standing of general practice and develop a system of postgraduate training for general practitioners.

The problem is that this legislation does not solve the problems and, at the same time, the legislation is unfair and its retrospective nature is adversely affecting the careers of medical students—those people who are already in the system. In fact, the Parents and Friends Supporting Medical Students said in their submission:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Current medical students and interns will be denied their rightful expectation, under training requirements existing at the commencement of their training, of eligibility for a Medicare provider number at the end of their internship year.

That is, people who started their courses some six or seven years ago who are now completing their internship year are retrospectively affected so that the situation they relied upon when making their decision no longer exists.

BREAK.PARA: This problem is exacerbated by the fact that this bill was not introduced in the parliament until some four days before its date of effect, which is 1 November this year. In fact, we are debating this bill well over a month after it is to come into effect. The government has indicated that if it is unable to secure passage of the bill, or if it does, anyone who has received a Medicare provider number between 1 November and the passing of the bill will have that provider number retrospectively taken from them.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't be serious about that, Belinda.

—I will take your interjection because that was evidence provided to us by the secretary to the department in the committee. If you do not agree with that view, then I suggest you take it up with the secretary to the department.

BREAK.PARA: A major problem of the provision of medical services is still the maldistribution of doctors and the shortages in rural areas in both hospitals and in general practice. This legislation, as I said, will not resolve that problem.

I am particularly concerned about Dr Wooldridge's proposal which may also have an adverse effect on the provision of medical services in rural areas and on the options available to young doctors, particularly women, who do not wish to proceed immediately from their intern year to full‐time training. I am also of the view that the agreement reached between the government and the Australian Democrats, though designed at least by the Democrats to overcome this problem, may in fact make it worse, but I will explore this issue further in the committee stage.

The National Rural Health Network said in its submission that `the proposed restrictions on provider numbers will discourage junior doctors and medical students who are considering practising in rural areas', and that is really the crux of it. Several of the submissions and a number of witnesses, particularly women, have expressed their concern about the practical difficulties in getting a deferred or part-time training place and also that training arrangements are inflexible and do not allow for a variety of lifestyle choices and the demands of a family. Concern has been raised about these issues, but I do not wish to canvass them further, because we will have the opportunity in committee to deal with them much more adequately.

The second part of the Health Insurance Amendment Bill (No. 2) is the maximum permissible gap being increased from $30.20 to $50. The opposition also does not support the intention of this bill to increase Medicare's maximum possible gap. This measure effectively reduces the Medicare rebate for out of hospital services with a value in excess of $202. This measure represents a fundamental breach of the coalition's election promise to maintain Medicare in its entirety. It is a regressive measure through which the government intends to raise $60 million from a group of people whose only distinguishing characteristic is that they require high cost medical treatment. The sorts of people who will be utilising these sorts of services will often be the chronically ill and the elderly.

I will now briefly deal with the National Health (Budget Measures) Amendment Bill. This bill is also in keeping with the general philosophy of this government; that is, to slug those who are the most vulnerable. The National Health (Budget Measures) Amendment Bill contains three changes to the pharmaceutical scheme that makes Australians worse off. It increases the cost to pensioners, it increases the cost to families and it changes the indexation rules so that co-payments increase more than they would have without this change to the indexation provisions.

The opposition believes that this bill breaches two of the government's major promises. The Prime Minister promised—and I quote in case anyone has forgotten—`to maintain the real value of pensions and other social security benefits'.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Further, this government promised to help the battlers. What could be more damaging to both pensioners and the battlers than to have the cost of medicines increased?

BREAK.PARA: The bill is decreasing the expenditure on pharmaceutical benefits by the sum of $540 million. Do you know what that means? It goes into the government's coffers and it comes out of the pockets of families and pensioners.

I am particularly concerned about the effect on pensioners. The co-payment has been increased from $2.70 to $3.20. Many people might argue that an increase of 50c is not very much and that it does not really matter. But, for a pensioner on a severely limited income, 50c can mean a great deal. The National Seniors Association said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: We are concerned that there is a danger that age pensioners will be put in a position where they cannot afford a script and they may well go without it.

This was reinforced by a number of other witnesses. It is made worse by the fact that the link between the pensioners co-payment and the safety net and its connection to the pensioners allowance that is paid has now been broken. In fact, for the elderly who use a large number of prescriptions, they will be much worse off.

BREAK.PARA: When the Labor Party originally introduced a co-payment for pensioners, they were very careful about the way they did it. They introduced a pharmaceutical allowance for pensioners, which was paid at the same time as their social security benefits, so that a pensioner would not be worse off. But this is a principle that this government has not seen fit to continue. The National Seniors Association, in giving evidence to the committee, also said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Commonwealth seniors health card provides scripts at the concessional rate, but they will now be losing the hearing aid service and the dental service. So they are not only having an increase in the cost of pharmaceuticals, but they are also losing those two benefits.

That essentially sums it all up for me. The effect of these bills—combined with effects of the budget generally in health and other areas—means that, if you are not doing very well in Australia at the moment, then you will be worse off as a result of the decisions of this government.

BREAK.PARA: As a result, we will be opposing Health Insurance Amendment Bill (No. 2) in its entirety and in the National Health Budget Measures Amendment Bill we will be opposing three measures which relate to the increase in the co-payment. However, we will be supporting the fourth measure which relates to pharmaceutical benefits not being available for non-residents and foreign nationals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a speech here written by Senator Eggleston who, unfortunately, had to leave this afternoon. I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
MEDICARE PROVIDER CODE ISSUE
Health Insurance Amendment Bill No. 2.
National Health (Budget Measures) Amendment Bill 1996

I must say that there has been more of unnecessary concern whipped up over the issue of restricting Medicare provider code numbers for Medical General Practitioners to those who have undertaken the recognised training program than on almost any other matter I can think of.
The impression has been given that the Government proposal is something new and radically different from what has actually been happening in practice for the last 5 or 6 years.
The impression has been given that the Government is unfairly targeting young doctors eager to go out and work in the community by imposing unfair restrictions on them.
The impression has been given that young doctors will not be able to find jobs.
Of course none of these impressions are true and one must ask what the real agenda is of those who are deliberately whipping up the anxieties of medical students and junior doctors on these matters.
I believe there is a need for some objective assessment of the facts of this matter. Initially I would like to deal with the need for Gps to be adequately trained.

In the good old days of 30 to 40 years ago or more, once a person had finished a medical course and done a year to two as a resident in a public hospital they were regarded as being well enough trained to go and set up a medical practice. The doctors of those days were universal generalists who delivered babies, took out appendixes, tonsils and gall bladders as well as giving anaesthetics and then went back to their surgeries where they consulted all day and in the evenings and overnight did house calls, or at least that was what the doctors did in my home town when I was a little boy in the 1950s.

In those days if you wanted to be a specialist surgeon the usual pathway was to go to England and do your primary Fellowship exams, spend a couple of years in a British Hospital, pass your final Fellowship and then come home and set up practice.
But this is not the case any more.

Over the last 20 or so years there has been both a great expansion in the body of medical knowledge as well as a great explosion in medical technology. Public expectations of doctors and the standard of service they should provide have also risen.
As a result of this in the contemporary world 4 or 5 years of extra post‐ graduate training is required for all medical specialities and that includes General Practice Medicine.
It has been accepted around the world that General Practice or primary care medicine requires special training, just as much as does becoming a brain surgeon or cardiologist.

People entering General Practice Medicine need to have training relevant to the work they will do. This includes extra training in such areas as psychiatry, paediatrics, obstetrics, accident and emergency medicine and dermatology, etc. and then to have their knowledge tested to ensure that they have reached a sufficient level of competency.

Quite apart from testing that their knowledge base is adequate in these days of high levels of medical litigation it is important that doctors should be able to demonstrate that they have undertaken a formal period of training and passed qualifying exams before entering practice.

Most importantly however, a trained GP is more discriminating in ordering the use of laboratory tests and imaging procedures such as Xrays, Ultrasounds, CTScans, and in some cases no doubt MRI scanning.
Madam President it has been said that the most expensive piece of technology in the modern world is the ball point pen in the hand of a medical practitioner.
The explanation of this comment is that with a stroke of his or her pen a doctor can order a whole range of tests and imaging all of which are expensive and mostly paid for out of the public purse.
The properly trained GP works to a diagnostic plan and is prudent in the use of tests which is not only good medicine but costs the public purse a lot less.

I am sure we all know of doctors who order a battery of tests and xrays on every patient, but the truth of the matter is that such doctors are poor practitioners who are usually covering their lack of knowledge and competency by ordering many tests in the hope that something will show up.

GP training programs have been in place for some time in countries which we like to compare ourselves with, such as Canada and the UK. The Commonwealth has been steadily moving to bring Australian GP standards into line with other countries since the early 1990's when the Vocational Register was introduced. It was widely publicised that from 1 January 1995 entry to the Vocational Register would only be by holding the FRACGP, so that there was about 5 years notice of the fact that after January 1995 entry to unrestricted General Practice would require that the RACGP training program should have been successfully completed. That is to say these facts were well known to the medical students who will graduate this year from early years of their courses.
So what is the actual situation with respect to young medical graduates today?

The reality is that virtually no young doctors go out into unrestricted General Practice after completing their first year internship. Instead, according to a survey done by the Epidemiology Unit of the ANU in 1995, and which I have previously had incorporated in Hansard , on average Gps have spent an extra 3.6 years in extra hospital training before entering General Practice.
In addition, most young doctors who have wanted to be Gps prior to 1 January 1995, sought to enter the Vocational Register, and to do the FRACGP exams.
So Madam President, most young doctors are undertaking around 4 years postgraduate training and sitting the FRACGP to confirm their standards.

In reality then, the proposals put forward by the Health Minister to require all doctors entering General Practice to undertake the RACGP training program really do no more than formalise the situation as it actually is in practice.

The fact is most young doctors are doing the training anyway. All these proposals do is formalise the requirement of all persons who wish to enter General Practice Medicine to complete the training requirements to gain entry to the Vocational Register.

The option of a doctor who has dropped out of a heart surgery program to become a GP simply by virtue of his holding a medical qualification has gone—and so it should have. General Practice should not become a waste paper basket for doctors who fail to succeed in other fields of medicine.

Perhaps the most important point to make is that in the modern world medicine should be regarded as a 12 year course—6 years as an unpaid undergraduate and 6 years as a paid graduate trainee before a doctor can set up in private practice in any field of medicine and be authorised to receive payments through the Medicare system.

Another vital point which needs to be made is that it is only doctors who plan to enter private practice who need provider codes. Salaried doctors of whom there are an increasing number working in many fields of medicine, do not need provider numbers.
This is an important point to make.

The focus of the public discussion of this matter has been on provider numbers which are required for private practice but of course there are a wide variety of career prospects for doctors in salaried positions. Such options, apart from salaried clinical jobs, include careers in medical administration, public health, occupational and industrial medicine, community health, aviation medicine to mention but a few. Fee for service private practice is far from the only employment prospect for young doctors.

In any case notwithstanding all the claims to the contrary, the Minister has made it clear that there will be more than enough jobs for the 1,200 medical graduates Australia produces annually, as has already been set out by him elsewhere.

As a Member of the Senate Community Affairs Committee which reported on this issue to the Senate, I am very pleased that a component of the revised package for this Bill is provision for a Medical Training Review Committee to oversee post‐graduate medical training, not only of Gps, but also of specialists.

This was a recommendation of the Government Members of the Committee, and arose from concern when it became apparent that there was no central register of medical training posts, the location of such posts or the percentage take up of such posts.
The inclusion of this provision in the legislation in my view may do more to improve post‐graduate medical education in Australia over the long term than is realised today I suspect.

In conclusion Madam President, I want to place on record my strong support for the general thrust of the Health Minister's plan to ensure that Gps in Australia do have adequate training before being permitted to enter unrestricted practice. I am sure these measures will not only be in the best long term interests of GP medicine, but more importantly of the Australian public who will reap the benefit of being cared for by better trained doctors.
Coming as I do from the North of Western Australia, I also applaud the aspects of these measures which will mean that better medical services can be provided in rural and remote Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will begin by looking at the Health Insurance Amendment Bill (No. 2) and then, if time permits, go on to the National Health (Budget Measures) Amendment Bill. I do want to begin with the one that looks at the government's decision to restrict eligibility for Medicare provider numbers to doctors because of the considerable interest that this has generated amongst a number of young doctors. Also, it is probably an issue about which there has been more than the unusual amount of misinformation spread.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats support the basic premise of this legislation. We believe that medical graduates wishing to enter general practice should undertake additional training. Beginning with our agreement with the decision of the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) to do that, we then had to begin looking at the best way to implement it because that is where the problems lie.

PARA.BREAK: We accept the argument and we indeed accept the evidence that undergraduate medical education does not prepare graduates for unsupervised general practice. We also note that it is not only medical graduates that face some additional training. The law is one area that comes to mind. Lawyers have to under take additional training before they become barristers and solicitors. So it is not unusual that, after finishing a period at university and indeed at TAFE, some additional on-the-job training is required.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very aware of the concerns expressed by some doctors that the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners should not be given exclusive rights over GP training. I am aware of the many criticisms. Indeed, I have spent considerable time discussing this with a range of doctors and people interested in medical training. I am aware of the concerns that general practice training is becoming more and more like specialist training and is beginning to pick up some of the worst trends that we have experienced here in this country with specialist training. I will say more about that in a minute.

I believe both general practice and specialist training should be opened up. We have dealt with that in some of the discussions with government and in some of the package that we have negotiated. But I do not believe the minister could simply have opted at this point in time to leave the college out of this legislation altogether, although I know that is what some doctors wanted to see. Indeed, it is the issue that has been raised with me again today. It is certainly something that we are aware of and will begin to deal with.

It is important to note that this bill actually provides for an alternative. If you look through the bill, you will find the words `the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners or a body specified in the regulations'. So there is already a possibility and a legislative option that that may indeed be where we head. So the potential is there, and we can in the future be looking at putting a range of different bodies in that general practice training role.

I would also like to point out at this point in time that the government is about to commence a review of general practice training which will look at alternative training pathways, something that has been on the agenda certainly very publicly since the late 1980s. As part of the Democrats' negotiations with the minister, the new medical training review panel will be given a specific brief to look at complaints about training, complaints about access to training, who is actually allowed in where and how many people are allowed in. This review panel will advise the minister on issues related to alternative training pathways. So there is movement on this issue, something I want to stress again for those young doctors who are concerned about what is happening.

I must say that I believe the minister does have a genuine interest in addressing some of these long-term problems. Medical training is not an easy area in which to tread and to begin to make some changes, as many former Labor health ministers have no doubt found. There are some very powerful vested interest groups out there, all involved in defending their own patch, defending their own turf, digging trenches, defending the barricades the minute anyone looks like stepping in their general direction.

I think they have to face that change is inevitable. I say to those colleges out there which replied to the questions from the department about what part-time training was on offer with, `None, none, none, none, none, none at the moment,' that things will change. They will have to get used to it. They will also have to get used to the fact that women should not be excluded, as they have been in the past, from a range of training opportunities.

From the time that the provider number restriction was announced, the Democrats have said, `We do not have a problem with the concept.' We have said that we do not believe that access to Medicare provider numbers is an automatic right. It is a privilege. It is a privilege bestowed by the Australian taxpayers. It is a privilege which attracts a significant amount of taxpayers' funds and, as such, I believe that we are entitled to place conditions upon the receipt of those funds.

The Democrats also accept the benefits to the overall health system of having medical graduates fill vacancies and training places in some of the less popular, less glamorous disciplines rather than using their Medicare provider number option to simply move out undertrained into areas where there is already an oversupply of general practitioners. We support the government's stated desire of addressing in this way some of the maldistribution problems, but we do wish to state here that we still have a long way to go in seriously tackling many of the rural and remote issues when it comes to maldistribution.

So basically the Democrats believe this bill is on the right track and it is for that reason we sat down and began negotiations with the government. We were concerned about what was the impact of the provider number restrictions on medical graduates, on those who have recently graduated, in particular those who are going to graduate over the next three years. We felt the government's data was less than satisfactory and that, until more accurate data becomes available, the minister's assertion that there are more than enough training places to go around could not be relied upon. But, in saying that, I note that some of the extreme suggestions of 300 or 400 places short was not proven before us during the committee hearings.

It is not only the government that is concerned about where and to what disciplines graduates are moving. The RACGP, in a letter to all senators, also claimed that adequate work and training places are available for junior doctors. But, they said:

In disciplines and places which are unpopular, these posts are either unoccupied or filled by doctors on temporary visas doing work our own graduates will not do. As long as they have access to a provider number, they can make a living practising triage and referral medicine without further training, in major cities.

So while this assertion sounds reasonable, and it seems on evidence before the committee and anecdotal evidence that it certainly is supported, it is once again difficult to verify in the absence of accurate data the availability of work and training places. So, on the basis of the evidence presented to the committee, and after discussions with various colleges, we believe there probably will be some shortages.

This is where we set out with our negotiations with the government to try to put in place those 200 extra places a year. We were not successful in negotiating the full 200 places, but we do have a backstop position of some 250 over three years, and I will say more about that in a moment.

The Democrats set out to get the government to put that safety net in place and to have it there for at least three years to ensure every medical graduate has either a training place or a job. We now have that safety net and I really find it a bit astonishing to hear the responses of some of the graduates today and, indeed, to find that we still have a Labor Party which is going to oppose this bill. After all, how many other graduates in other disciplines have guaranteed opportunities?

As a result of a couple of phone calls and speaking to a few people today, I want to stress that the training these young doctors will go into is well paid. We are not talking about four or more years of unpaid training. The average salary around Australia for an inturn—that is, someone who is in the last year—is $35,000 plus overtime. The average salary for junior RMOs—that is, they are trained and out there in the public hospitals—is $50,000 plus overtime. Depending on the contracts, a lot more than that can often be offered.

Many work those incredibly ridiculous hours, and we have had figures suggested to us as high as $75,000 depending on what ridiculous hours the doctors have to work. This is one of the issues that we hope will actually be addressed as part of our package when the government sits down with the state governments to look at what is happening in our public hospitals. I really have great problems with doctors who are saying they do not want a $35,000 a year job.

Again, I point out that there are thousands of people coming out of universities fully qualified, many with honours degrees and higher, who have no chance this year of getting a job in their chosen profession and will indeed be driving taxis. I think we have some 800,000 people on unemployment benefits. I think that perhaps a few graduates need to think about that.

I would like to quickly go through the safety net that the Democrats have won from the government and just briefly mention 10 of the initiatives. Firstly, there is the 250 additional GP training places which will be made available over the next three years in rural and regional areas. These places are the bottom line of the safety net. If a junior doctor cannot obtain a training place or a salaried medical position after 12 months on the register of opportunity, the government will make a new rural GP training place available to that doctor.

Some doctors are arguing that they do not want to be conscripted into this. No-one is telling them that is anything like conscription. They are not being forced to go. It is simply one of the options. We are looking, in return for that offer, at the government asking that they stay on and practice in a rural area—something that many teachers have in past had to do, me included, and something that many people in the public sector are required to do. I know the police force in many states requires a time of country service. Indeed, moving to the country is something our defence forces are more than used to—in some instances, I would say unfortunately because some of them seem to move an excessive number of times.

Basically, if we have a doctor in a rural area who cannot find anything else and is happy to do so, then they will have to stay on in a rural area. If they turn that down as well, then they are still free to go out and find themselves a medical job or indeed to move on and perhaps find something in the non‐medical work force. That is their choice. It is the choice that other graduates and other people have to make every day.

Secondly, there will be a formal process to oversee the take up of medical training places. I will move amendments later in this debate to set up a medical training review panel to identify the number, type and location of the training places, identify the number of interns and RMOs available for placement and report to the minister for health on the numbers, if any, of training vacancies—where they are and what they are in—and to look at the applicants and to actually identify those that are genuinely unable to find places. The report of that panel will be tabled in parliament for all of us to see.

Thirdly, there will be a register of opportunity to match new graduates with vacant hospital positions. Junior doctors will be able to join a register of opportunity and that will match them up formally letting them know where places are and making offers to them. As I said, if a doctor stays on that register for 12 months, then the offer of a country GP place will be made.

Fourthly, there is a sunset clause in the reforms. The legislation will cease to operate on 31 December 2001 unless its operation is formally extended by this parliament. This will compel the government to justify the success of this measure before it is extended. It is a good opportunity for all of us to have a very good look at exactly what has been happening.

Fifthly, there is a mid‐term review of the effects of the provider number restriction to be tabled in parliament. The minister will be required by the legislation to report to the parliament by 30 June 1999 on the impacts of provider number restrictions and the take up of additional places as well as the current state of postgraduate medical training. As part of the review, the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare will monitor the impact of the legislation on the delivery of services, the quality of services and, in particular, on the cost of health services to make sure that this legislation does not have the impact suggested to us that in some cases it may force up the cost of some general practice services.

Sixthly, there will be an extension of time in which GP training can be completed from four years to six years. This is particularly important for those young doctors who want to take time off to perhaps travel or for family responsibilities. GP training previously had been limited to four years. You had to get it over and done with or you were out. I stress here that part‐time training will have no limit on it. We are talking about full‐time training. You actually take one or two years out if you so wish.

Seventhly, there is a commitment to consult with the specialist colleges on promoting fairness and transparency in their selection processes and reporting the results of those consultations to the parliament. This is something I have been working on in my time in this place as health spokesperson for the Democrats and I am very pleased to see that at last it is beginning to happen.

Eighthly, there is a commitment to discuss with the deans of medical schools additional increases in rural experience. I realise that they have already made a significant breakthrough recently, but we are still asking them yet again to look twice and three times for extra opportunities for their students to have rural and regional experience during the actual time that they are at university.

Ninthly, there is a commitment to develop in conjunction with the states by the end of 1997 a package of reforms for RMOs and other salaried medical positions. This is something I do not think those doctors out there protesting have read. I am still getting phone calls from people complaining that doctors are going to be pushed into dead end jobs in the public hospital system. Part of the package is actually at last sitting down and looking at career pathways for salaried medical positions.

Tenthly, there is a fresh commitment to develop alternative medical training pathways through the review of GP training and by giving the new medical training review panel the roles of dealing with complaints about training and training access and advising the minister on issues relating to alternative training pathways.

In short, I believe this package makes this legislation fairer, much more accountable to us and at the same time creates the potential for getting 250 more doctors into regional and rural Australia. We will be debating these two bills separately in committee so I ask that my speech on the National Health (Budget Measures) Amendment Bill 1996 be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
National Health (Budget Measures) Amendment Bill 1996
Second reading speech

The Australian Democrats are opposed to the central provisions of this legislation—those measures contained in Schedule 1 of the bill which seek to increase the cost of pharmaceuticals for both concessional beneficiaries and general patients under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
The Democrats have a long record of opposition to increased charges in this area.
In 1990 we opposed the introduction of a PBS co-payment for pensioners and concessional beneficiaries by the previous Labor Government.
In 1993, we opposed the ending—also by the Labor Government—of access to free pharmaceuticals beyond the safety net for general patients.
In 1995, we opposed the increases in the safety net threshold for general patients—also an initiative by the previous Labor Government.

That's three times in five years the Labor Government moved to increase pharmaceutical costs. So I have some sympathy with the Coalition Government when it calls the Opposition's approach to this current increase "opportunistic".

When it was a Labor Government hiking the prescription charge for pensioners up from nothing to $2.70 over five years, that was "a price signal". When it's a Coalition Government wanting a 50 cent increase, that's suddenly "unfair" (to use the Shadow Minister's word).

At least the Democrats have been consistent in our opposition to what is really a failure by both the previous Labor Government and the current Coalition Government look beyond the demand side of the equation when it comes to reining in costs under the PBS.

When governments look around to find budget savings, the PBS co-payments and safety net thresholds are always the first cabs off the rank. No-one wants to get serious about wider reform of the PBS. No-one wants to look to the longer term. No-one wants to talk about what sorts of outcomes in pharmaceutical use are desirable. It is obviously much easier to simply ratchet up the safety net thresholds and the co-payments than it is to tackle some of the more entrenched problems within the PBS.

The Democrats have been saying for years that Commonwealth outlays under the PBS can and should be reduced. However, we believe attempts to reduce outlays should focus on the supply side of the scheme, rather than on measures which achieve nothing other than shifting the costs back onto those consumers who can least afford to bear them.

It is interesting that, despite these measures, Commonwealth expenditure under the PBS continues to rise. What is more, the trend in PBS utilisation by concessional beneficiaries also continues to move upwards (despite a drop in demand following the introduction of the co-payment in 1990).

These trends suggest that `price signals' and co-payments will ultimately fail to deliver the sorts of long-term savings understandably sought by the Government. They also suggest that the real causes of growth in the PBS may lie on the supply side of the scheme and be driven, not by patients, but by doctors and pharmaceutical companies.

For some time now, most recently in our dissenting report to the Senate Community Affairs Committee's examination of this legislation, the Democrats have been saying that the Commonwealth Government needs to look at full range of factors influencing grow in PBS outlays.
Factors which include:
the role of doctors (particularly general practitioners) in the dispensing of drugs;
the role of pharmacists;
the role of promotional advertising within the pharmaceutical industry;
the high volume—and growth in volume—of certain pharmaceuticals routinely prescribed under the PBS which are also available over the counter (including paracetamol and aspirin);
a general lack of consumer awareness about pharmaceuticals and limited access to independent medications information;
limited specialised medical knowledge about geriatric prescribing and alternative forms of therapy; and
a general imbalance in health policies, which continue to emphasise remedial therapies instead of preventive health services.
In the Democrats' view, these are areas which the Commonwealth needs to address instead of—year after year, government after government—simply throwing in the "too-hard" basket.

We believe there are much bigger savings to be made by exploring some of these factors. That is the reason the Democrats' dissenting report on this legislation urges the Government to take three actions over the next twelve months—and I would very much like to hear the Minister's responses to these recommendations some time during this debate.

Our first recommendation is that the Government convene a national PBS summit involving all PBS stakeholders with a view to moving towards a National Medicines (or Pharmaceuticals) Policy and obtaining agreement on measures designed to reduce Commonwealth PBS outlays.

I think such a summit is long overdue. I know the Minister sits down on a fairly regular basis with some of the key players and I know these issues are discussed at Ministerial level with the States. But the obvious benefit of a summit is that it would bring all players together and enable a full canvassing of concerns about the PBS.

It would also provide an opportunity to look at possible savings not in the isolation of a Budgetary context, but in conjunction with desirable outcomes in the consumption and prescribing of pharmaceuticals.

The Democrats' second recommendation is that the Government, in conjunction with the Royal Australian College of GPs and the AMA, establish two pilot projects designed to change GP prescribing practices.
We have called these suggested projects the Second (or Lifestyle) Script project and the Pharmaceutical Budgetholding project.

The Second Script project would encourage GPs to use two prescription pads: their usual pharmaceutical script and a `lifestyle' script. The lifestyle script is designed to encourage patients, where appropriate, to change lifestyle habits which are damaging to their health.

It is also designed to encourage GPs to look beyond medication when treating their patients and to consider making specific "lifestyle prescriptions" as an alternative to prescribing pharmaceuticals. Examples of `lifestyle prescriptions' include: reducing caffeine or alcohol intake, getting more exercise (such as walking for a specific amount of time or distance each day), changing dietary habits, stress reduction and relaxation practices, and so on.

The Pharmaceutical Budgetholding project would provide GPs with a specific allocation of PBS funds from which they would meet their practices prescription needs over a set period of time. It is designed to encourage GPs to pay less attention to pharmaceutical industry advertising, to take some personal responsibility for the costs of their prescribing practices, to consider less costly medication options and to explore alternatives beyond the prescribing of pharmaceuticals.

I am not saying either of these projects is the solution to problems with the PBS. But I believe they are the type of project we should be looking at if we are serious about getting GPs to look closely and critically at their own prescribing practices.

The Democrats' final suggestion is that the Government act on the recommendation contained in the Electronic Prescribing and Medicines Information Consultancy that the Department of Health and Family Services "establish a primary goal of introducing a basic Clinical Workbench to 50 per cent of Australian Office-based Practices (where the prescriber predominantly works from one location) within two years".

The Electronic Prescribing and Medicines Information Consultancy report is the result of a 1995 study carried out by the IBM Consulting Group into "the optimal use of technology in the support of Electronic Prescribing and the provision of electronic medicines information".

The Final Report of that study makes very interesting reading. It makes the observation that Australia presently lags behind the rest of the advanced world in the use of computers to support clinical practice. The study found that "the combination of Computer Assisted Medication Management and Electronic Prescribing has the potential to improve the quality of health care service delivery significantly and to reduce the number of acute hospital bed days consumed due to medication error".

But, aside from those positive health outcomes, it also found that the implementation of such measures could save the Government around $145 million per annum from the national health budget. Through networking and access to additional information, such measures also offer the potential to further reduce PBS outlays by promoting alternative prescribing practices.

In short, we are talking about potentially very big savings here—and it is these sorts of measures which offer the Government the possibility of reining-in PBS outlays over the medium to long term, rather than plugging along with so-called `price signals' in an area in which demand is essentially inelastic and largely unrelated to price.
The measures in this Bill do bite hard. They do hit pensioners and they do hit—yet again—families where one or more member has a chronic illness or a disability.

We know all the arguments about the Budget bottom line—but the Democrats stand by our position that, with more than $11 billion worth of Budget measures already passed, deficit reduction is well under control. We do not see why pensioners and people with a disability or illness should have to pay the costs of even faster deficit reduction.
Surely we are entitled to make a decision—as a nation—that we will opt for a slightly slower deficit reduction program rather than making these people pay more for their pharmaceuticals .

We are—I believe—even more entitled to make that decision when this Government (like its predecessor) continues to refuse to look to the supply side of the PBS to generate the savings it says it needs.

Finally, the Democrats will support the other two measures contained in this Bill: the changes to indexation rules for the PBS co-payments and the restricting of pharmaceutical benefits to Australian citizens, permanent residents and visitors to Australia from countries with which we have reciprocal health care agreements.

The new indexation rules mean that instead of indexing the co-payments for inflation by rounding down to the nearest 10 cents, the co-payments will now be rounded `to the nearest multiple of 10 cents'—that is rounded up or down. This is a formula which is in wide usage. It is the same formula which is currently used in the Social Security Act. As such, the co-payment will rise or fall along with the pension, for example and that seems to us to be a consistent and acceptable approach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens oppose the legislation and oppose the deal between the Democrats and the government in reaction to the government's decision, quite arbitrarily, to restrict the doctor provider numbers and therefore to prohibit at least some graduates from getting a job in the profession in the way they expected when they entered medical school. The problem with the arrangement that the Democrats have made is that the government now has the numbers to put that arrangement into effect tonight in this legislation. Senator Lees has said that the arrangement is not well understood and she is getting calls from people who do not understand the deal that has been made.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the problems is that the people who are being affected are worried for their futures and they feel locked out. The people whose livelihoods will be determined by the vote that will be carried tonight by the combined Democrat-government numbers do not feel that they have had a chance to get across their concerns about the opportunities closed by this legislation. The closure of those opportunities is the result of the amendments that will be passed through here tonight because of the joint Democrat‐government deal.

The reaction from medical students and resident medical officers has been very strong indeed. It took them 24 hours to analyse the arrangement that had been negotiated with the government by the Democrats. They feel they have been sold out. They are their words, not mine. They think the arrangement is, to quote an AMA spokesperson, `ludicrous and unworkable'. This may sound ungratifying to the government and to the Democrats. But that is because there are still some amongst the ranks of trainee doctors in this country who are not going to be able to find a job at the end of the day because of this deal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—The parliamentary secretary opposite interjects. But he interjected before this deal was struck saying exactly the same thing. No matter what the plan is, he is consistent in saying rubbish to the young doctors out there.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a decision of the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge). I will tell the Senate why he has come to this decision. It is not for the good of the doctors in training; it is not for the good of the resident medical officers; it is not for the good of rural practice in this country; it is not for the good of potential patients—and there are 18 million of us; it is to service the need of this government to meet a budget target, its so-called black hole. It is to gain some hundreds of millions of dollars in `saved revenue' so-called by pulling the purse strings on the delivery of medical care in this country.

To achieve this saved revenue, they have had to cut across the career path of many medical students and RMOs in Australia. The Democrats have been able to ameliorate that but, in doing so, they have also given assent to the underlying philosophy that some doctors' jobs are going to be sacrificed to meet this government's budget aspirations. That is where we end up.

I have been through medical school, through the RMO years and into general practice and I know the difficulties that medical trainees face, as the minister does. I know the hard work and the application required just to get there and I know everything that is forgone. The legislative ability of the minister to cut people out of their rightful place of a job in their profession at the end of the day is abhorrent. It is going to be enormously injurious to those trainee doctors who do not make it. I know the minister is going to get up and say, `They'll all be given a job if they really want one.' That is standard government philosophy applied to everybody in Australia. But it is not the reality for those people—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is nonsense.

—That is nonsense, says Senator Abetz. But there is nobody who purveys that sort of idea in our community more than he does. It might be pointed out to him that it is disorderly to interject from the wrong seat.
—I am on whip's duty.
—Order! If we have fewer interjections and if the speaker would address the chair, we might get on better.

—The offer that has been made to those people, who are facing the alternative of being cut out of a job altogether, is a draft of four years into a rural practice with a requirement for some of them at least that they stay on for another number of years—potentially up to 17 years—in rural practice. Having come from the country and thinking of no better job than being a rural practitioner, that is fine for me.
—Blacktown.

—No, I went to high school in Blacktown, briefly. I spent most of my early years in rural New South Wales and I practised medicine in rural Tasmania as well. It is not acceptable for those opposite, in the interests of a fiscal imperative, to say to other people, `You must leave your family, you must leave your neighbourhood, you must leave the environment you have worked for and go and work where we tell you or have no job.'

SPEECH.PARA: That is the outcome of this arrangement. That is what is facing hundreds of young doctors in the future in this country. It is totally unfair; it will lead to totally unnecessary hardship; and, at the end of the day, it will deprive the country of the available allocation of doctors who could be working in the medical service for the wider populace.

I will conclude by referring to the college system which Senator Lees spoke about. It is high time there was an independent arbiter on medical training and the direction the medical job placements will go in this country. The colleges, like the old guilds, have a vested interest. The Royal Australian College of General Practitioners did not exist when I graduated but it has gone through the ranks to become one of the most powerful and self-interested organisations in the country. No doubt it is in both the college's interest and the interests of its established members to restrict the numbers of other people going into its ranks.

You do not have to be Einstein to know that it is going to be to the benefit—both financially and career wise—of those doctors who have already made it, to squeeze out those who have not. That is what is happening with this legislation. Those doctors who have made it will be okay; those who have not made it will be left to the vagaries of a new system, where they have to compete with each other and accept a whole new bundle of conditions which did not exist when they entered medical school, or get no job at all at the end of the day.

We can do better than that. We ought to be working through incentives to ensure that medical expertise is available in rural areas around this country. We ought to be ensuring—at a baseline though—that everybody who goes into our medical schools, who gives up their lives to get through the long training that is required, who takes a lot of money out of the public purse in doing so, is placed in a job in the profession where they are happy, they are productive and they are contributing to society in the way they intended to when they entered medical school. This legislation is the first removal of the plank in that ideal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation is quite unfair. It is retrospective in a couple of respects. The first is that it denies a reasonable expectation for those people who have begun a course, who are now halfway through a course or who have finished a course. They began that course with the reasonable expectation that, at the end of carrying out certain studies, they would be entitled to treat patients and those patients would be entitled to recover fees under the Medicare provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: That has been changed at a late hour. Those people who have recently graduated and those people who are now doing internships have been sacrificed—I use the word advisedly—for fiscal purposes. If this was all about merit, then there might be some justification. But it is not about merit. That is quite clear from the proposed section 19CC which states:
A medical practitioner, or a person acting on behalf of the medical practitioner, is guilty of an offence . . .

What offence is such a person going to be guilty of? For bad treatment because he or she treats a patient when he or she is not as qualified as this particular piece of legislation would like to see him or her qualified? No, it is not that. The only reason he or she can be penalised is that, before he or she rendered a service, he or she did not take such steps as are reasonable in all the circumstances to inform the other person that a Medicare benefit would not be paid.

I just ask the minister: why is it all right for a doctor to treat a patient, to give all sorts of treatment and that is not punishable, but it is punishable if they fail to tell the person that that person cannot recover a Medicare benefit?

TALK.START.PARA: —You are the one who wanted patients to know how much they were up for.
—That is your legislation. That is the legislation that the Democrats support.

SPEECH.PARA: The cut-off date is simply an arbitrary date of 1 November. There seems to be no rhyme nor reason why 1 November 1996 should be plucked out of the air as a means of rendering people unable to claim Medicare benefits because a particular doctor has treated them.

I could have understood it if you said, `We're going to have a system which puts doctors to the test and anybody who is not now worthy of being a doctor will no longer be able to practise.' But that is not what you have said. You have said, `Anybody who is a doctor already, anybody who has got up the ladder already, can practise for as long as he or she likes.' That is not the point. The amount of merit they have in their service does not matter. All that matters is when you qualified. That is the only thing that matters in this scheme. This legislation is not about merit; it is about when a particular person happened to go through a course. That is why it is safe to say that these are budgetary measures and nothing else. That is the first thing. It throws the burden of fiscal management on the particularly vulnerable—the young students who have studied for years with a particular belief which was well justified—at the last minute because the government wants to save money. The government is entitled to save money. But what should not be done is to heap upon the shoulders of these young students the proposition that they are making the sacrifice because people want them to be better doctors. It is not about that at all; it is about saving money.

Another illustration is the discussion we have had about people going to rural areas. Following on from what Senator Lees was putting, the proposition would seem to be that more doctors should go to the rural areas and that this is an incentive for them to do that. Indeed, it cannot be denied that there is a pressure on them to do that. If that is so, I ask the minister: isn't that conscription within the meaning of the law, within the meaning of what the High Court has said?

The parliamentary secretary shakes his head, but I think he will find, if he checks, that the issue of whether or not this is conscription is to be decided according to the facts and not according to law as written. I think he will find that is right. The sort of language that is being used in the speeches so far from the Democrats in particular indicates that this is, at least in part, about sending people to the country. That is a good thing, but I think you might have some problems with the constitution.

The last thing I want to talk about is the professionalism of medicine. This is an act which attacks the idea of the medical profession because it takes the regulation that controls the profession out of the profession's hands and puts it into the hands of the government. If the parliamentary secretary to the minister doubts that, I invite him to look at the various subsections, including schedule 1, items 1, 2, 4, 6, 7 and various parts of 10, and give comments. I think that will do for the moment.

The proposition I want to put to you is that the qualifications that people are obliged to obtain, and their ability to go on in their profession or otherwise, depend not on what their peers say—not on what the colleges say—but on what is set out in the regulations. The regulations are made by the Governor‐General, which means the government. The way the regulations are going to be used under this legislation will mean that the government rather than the profession will be running medicine from now on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Denman, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have my speech on the second reading incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
In speaking to this bill I would like to first speak about the Gap Issue.
This measure will increase the maximum gap between the Schedule fee and the Medicare rebate for any out‐of‐hospital services to $50.00 (indexed annually).
As my colleagues stated in the report on this bill this is a fundamental breach of the coalition's election promise to "maintain Medicare in its entirety".
This measure challenges the objectives of Medicare. As we know Medicare provides one of the fairest systems in the world with more than 2 million Australians being protected.

This measure, like the attack on the unemployed under the Social Security Budget Bills is an attack on a vulnerable group whose only distinguishing characteristic in this case is that they require high‐cost medical treatment done outside the hospital.
People for example who are suffering from chronic diseases such as cancer or coronary artery disease will be candidates for an increase in fees.

There was some discussion in the hearing into this Bill about the safety net. An interesting point was raised in acknowledging that the safety net remains—that there would be many chronically ill patients who in this category will end up requiring investigations each year for a couple or few years. In those cases where they are not bulk billed, they will be faced with the impost of $271 out of pockets each year as a direct result of this measure.
This is treatment that these people cannot avoid such as CT scans, nuclear medicine procedures and angiography.
As the Royal Australasian College of Radiologists said and I quote:
"Many of these patients are old, very ill, and some of them have multiple examinations."
At no stage was this "gap issue" measure discussed with these patients or consumer groups let alone the doctors.

The Royal Australasian College of Radiologists feel rightly betrayed. They had cooperated fully with the Minister and Department to produce a comprehensive package addressing the growth in diagnostic imaging expenditure under Medicare. Then with no inkling provided during that period of cooperation this measure was introduced.
It is no wonder they oppose it. It is no wonder also that the trusting relationship between radiologists and physicians and the Department has been damaged.
We therefore oppose those parts of the Bill which give effect to the increase in the maximum permissible gap payment.
As to the work force issues of provider numbers and post graduate numbers.
It is the retrospectivity of this measure that so upsets me.
Current medical students and interns rightly in my view, expected a number of important constants to remain in place for the duration of their study and training when they embarked on their careers.
One of the most important constants would be what would happen to them when they completed their internship.
To cause that constant to be varied is sacrilege.
As Doctors‐in‐Training stated in their submission and I quote:

"Many of this year's graduates, and latter year medical students have based their plans for their future around the assumption that all career options previously available would still be present on completion of their intern year".
It is a disgrace in my view that these students have to bare the brunt of this measure when other options are available which could be phased in over a longer period.
Another important issue is what now holds for the future for female graduates and women doctors in training and the availability of training places because of this Bill.
I cannot agree with the Chairman of the Community Affairs Legislation Community Affairs Committee, Senator Sue Knowles when she stated in her Media Release and I quote:
". . . fairness and gender equity in post‐graduate training have always been of concern but are not directly related to this measure".
I believe that statement to be a cop out and a little rich when you take into account the retrospectivity of this measure.
Again as Doctors‐in‐Training said:

". . . this legislation not only disregards principles of natural justice, it is particularly discriminatory against female graduates, who will be forced into full‐time public hospital employment for an undefined period into the future."
If that is not a direct consequence of this legislation then I don't know what is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods, Sen Bob

TALKER.NAME: Senator WOODS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —What opportunism and hypocrisy from the Labor Party in approaching a very sensible bill which introduces a lot of very sensible measures which will preserve Medicare, something I thought the Labor Party pretended to be in support of.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me just address some of the issues raised by Senator Neal. Let me point out a few things about the Labor Party and its approach to the pharmaceutical benefits system. Senator Neal is complaining that we are `slashing' and forcing those who cannot afford it to pay enormous amounts of salaries. Under Labor, from 1983 to 1996, the general payments in pharmaceutical benefits co‐payments increased by 420 per cent. The concessional payments in the same period increased by 74 per cent. In 1986, you had a one‐off increase of $5. In 1990, you had a one‐off increase of $4. This is all separate from the indexation linkages. The average yearly increase in patient charges under you was 17.75 per cent. How can you actually stand there with a straight face and pretend that you really care about this?

Let me just run quickly through what this will do. The small amendments in terms of the increase in co‐payments mean for general beneficiaries, who have an average of 1.6 prescriptions a year, that the average extra cost per person per year will be $4.24. You are sitting there with your crocodile tears and bleeding hearts trying to pretend that this is really going to break the bank of those poor people. For goodness sake, wake up to real life. Look at the people who you are claiming are really going to be up against it because of this measure. The average use per concession card holder is 17 scripts a year. The average cost therefore will be $8.76 extra per year.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't have the figures; I've asked the department.

—They are facts. You might not like the facts, Senator Neal, but they are the facts: 16c per week. If you look at the most vulnerable group, as you claim, the average use per elderly concession is 30 scripts. That means an average of $15 a year for the most vulnerable group. For goodness sake, $15 a year! I do not know how you can stand there with a straight face and say that we are ripping those people off; that we are attacking them and undermining the whole fabric of society. Bear in mind that we maintain in script terms the same safety net as we had before. I do not understand how you can stand there with a straight face and pretend to be protecting the poor and disadvantaged when what we are doing here is something which is necessary and essential.

BREAK.PARA: We want a pharmaceutical benefits scheme that works. Under the Labor Party, I think the figures are that over the last four years the cost of the PBS has doubled. You may think that is maintainable but the fact is it is not. If you want to do that, the only way of actually maintaining it is to cut drugs off the PBS or, worse perhaps, not allow new drugs to go onto the PBS. What you finished up with with your system is a PBS which basically does not offer any worthwhile pharmaceuticals and which removes from people who need them the medications on which they depend.

If you want to have a maintainable system, you have to be sensible and realistic. The extra costs for individuals are minimal, as I pointed out, and the benefits to the system are very real indeed. There is not an infinite health budget. It is finite. There is a limit to what we can spend on health in terms of pharmaceuticals and medical benefits—and indeed other issues. In this regard, this is a way of making the system viable. If we did not do this, if we did not undertake these measures, I think the expectations are that the cost of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, which is already $2.6 billion per year, would increase rapidly again under the plans which you had.

Because we are running out of time, I will address briefly some of the other issues. I think Senator Lees actually pointed out some of the salient facts here. There were some attempts by Senator Brown to try to justify his support for the opposition to this bill on the grounds of things like: `It is the graduate's rightful place.' I am not quite sure what that means. I would have thought the most important thing is what happens to the Australian community and indeed the community as patients of those doctors. He claimed that it was not for the good of the residents themselves, not for the good of rural dwellers, not for the good of 18 million patients but it was simply for the good of the debt, the black hole.

Let me say right away: yes, there is a benefit here in terms of the black hole because there is a major financial problem which is largely supply driven. That basically means that there are too many doctors. There are not many people around Australia who argue with the fact that there are too many doctors, and this is an appropriate way of addressing that issue: to make sure that those doctors are practising in the right place.

Contrary to what Senator Cooney said, who claimed that there was no basis in merit on this issue, there is enormous benefit in this. What we are saying is exactly what the GP strategy under your government, the ALP government said, Senator Cooney. I can actually quote the 1992 document which said:
The AMA, the College of General Practitioners and the government—
that is your government—
support the principle that GPs should complete appropriate postgraduate training as signified by the FRACGP.

I am quoting your own government's comments. Now, of course, a couple of years later, it has all changed. Or Jenny Macklin, that independent reviewer of the health system who happens now to be a Labor member, said in her strategy paper:

There is widespread agreement on the need for vocational training to produce doctors with general practice skills. General practice should not be a dumping ground for people who cannot practise anywhere else or who cannot be bothered to get extra training.

The leader of the Deans of the Australian Medical Schools, Professor John Young, says the same thing. There is no question that this is a matter of merit. It is also a matter of blocking an unlimited supply. The cost of each new graduate in GPs is something like $200,000 a year because of not only the medical fees they generate but the fees they generate from radiology referrals, pathology referrals and a whole range of other referrals.

So there is a budgetary component. But the bottom line is that we will finish up with a better quality of doctor—and not an undifferentiated graduate but somebody with appropriate training who will actually supply a better quality of care to our patients. Indeed, there are encouragements and inducements for people to practise in rural areas. That is something that the Democrats have been very keen on pushing—and I congratulate them on that. It is also something which is very sensible, and we can address the details of what is going on in that area.

But, essentially, this is about merit, about extra training, about quality of medicine. It also does address some of the budget issues, which is so crucial. If we want to maintain Medicare we have to make sure there is an appropriate budgetary constraint which allows it to be viable, because an uncontrolled Medicare blow‐out would essentially undermine the principles of Medicare. That is something which I think nobody in this chamber seriously wants.

PARA.TAB: (4) A rating is only to be assigned after a comprehensive history and examination. For a rating to be assigned the condition must be fully documented and diagnosed. A rating should be provided once a working diagnosis based on the best available evidence is reached, or following arrangements for the investigation of poorly defined conditions, and once the condition is, where appropriate, considered stabilised.

(4A) A condition should be considered stabilised unless there is likely to be significant functional improvement, with or without treatment which is suitable and reasonable for the person, within the next two years.
