SPEECH.PARA: I want to briefly explain amendments 1 and 5. Amendment 5 provides for a mid‐term review of the legislation in the form of a requirement upon the minister to report to parliament by the end of 1999 and the operation of the provider number restriction. As part of that review, the minister has agreed that the Institute of Health and Welfare will monitor the impact of the legislation on the delivery and the cost of health services, and the Australian Medical Workforce Advisory Committee will monitor its impact on supply and distribution of medical practitioners.

Amendment No. 2 sets up the medical training review panel as proposed by us and now agreed to by the government. This panel will be given the brief to monitor medical training. Although its specific functions are still being finalised, the minister has given assurances as to what these functions will be. I seek leave to incorporate those assurances which form part of the responses. This is the fine detail of what this will involve.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
The establishment of a Medical Training Review Panel to oversee the take‐up of training places

The Government accepts the need for careful monitoring of the impact of these measures on the Australian medical graduates and would therefore agree to establish a Medical Review Training Panel. The Department of Health and Family Services (HFS) would establish by end February 1997 a medical Training Review Panel (MTRP).
The MTRP would be chaired by HFS and have membership as follows:
all States and Territories
representatives of specialist colleges
representatives of the deans of medical schools
representatives of doctors‐in‐training, RMOs and career medical officers
representatives of Divisions of General Practice; and
a representative of the Australian Medical Workforce Advisory Committee.

While the Government believes professional organisations which do not provide specialist or vocational training would be inappropriate members of the Panel, it believes that the Panel should consult actively with those associations on training issues.
The MTRP in the first instance will:
1. identify the number, type (eg part‐time/full‐time) and location of training places to be offered during 1997 for commencement in 1998;
2. estimate by specialty the number of training places likely to be offered in 1999 and 2000;
3. identify the pool of interns/RMOs available for placement at the end of 1997;
4. publish by end June 1997 the details of 1 and 2 above; and

5. report by end December 1997 to the Commonwealth Minister for Health and Family Services on the places filled or unfilled and on the number of applicants who have not found a place, with special reference in the report on the male/female mix and the availability of part‐time training places.
The MTRP will also:
1. review the training needs for career medical officers in hospitals and arrange for appropriate training to be made available through the universities and colleges;
2. keep under review the transparency of arrangements for selection of graduates into training places and for review of selection decisions, including complaints processes; and
3. work with the States on arrangements to improve the career structure for hospital career medical officers, especially in the light of improved training opportunities.
The Minister will table the annual report of the MTRP in Parliament.

It will involve all states and territories; several representatives of the specialist colleges; representatives of the deans of medical schools; representatives of doctors in training, RMOs and career medical officers; someone from the divisions of general practice; and a representative of the Australian Medical Workforce Advisory Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: In the first instance, it will identify the number, type—for example, full time or part time—and location of training places to be offered during 1997 for commencement in 1998. It will estimate by specialty the number of training places likely to be offered in 1999 and 2000; identify the pool of intern RMOs available for placement at the end of 1997; publish, by the end of June 1997, the details of one and two above; and report by the end of 1997 to the Commonwealth Minister for Health and Family Services on the places filled or unfilled and the number of applicants who have not found a place, with specific reference to the report on the number of women who have had the opportunity to take part in training. SPEECH.PARA: I will go through this amendment:
Schedule 1, item 14, page 9 (line 9), after "service" (first occurring), insert ", rendered after the commencement of this section and before 1 January 2002," . . .

It will now read `a Medicare benefit is not payable in respect of a professional service'—then you put in your amendment—`rendered after the commencement of this section and before 1 January 2002 if the person who rendered that service first became a medical practitioner on or after 1 November 1996'. That means that between now and the year 2002, or between the time this section commences until the year 2002, their patients cannot claim Medicare benefits. But as soon as 1 January 2002 comes, they can, even if they have not practised between now and then. That is just how it reads.

TALKER.NAME: Senator WOODS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think your interpretation is right. It is an effect of putting in the sunset clause. Obviously, that would have to be dealt with in the review which occurs at that time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —That was our intention: that this legislation would no longer apply. In other words, Medicare provider numbers would be available, as they are now, to anyone who basically has the primary qualification, as opposed to what this legislation is doing, which is making sure that GPs are GP trained before they get the provider numbers. When the sunset clause comes into operation, we go back to the situation as it is now, which means that doctors can basically finish their degree and come out and get a Medicare provider number.

—First of all, I cannot see any sunset clause here. If there is no sunset clause, my objection remains that people between now and the year 2002 are going to be penalised because of this. As soon as the year 2002 comes, we go back to the situation that now operates, before the passage of this legislation.
—Unless we decide otherwise.
—Yes; but, through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, you keep talking about a sunset clause which does not exist.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the sunset clause. Our instructions to the clerks, whose ability I respect without question, were to make sure that, after this legislation has had a trial period—and the decision was to take it through to those five years—we would revert to the status quo; that is, going back to the situation as it is now, which means that general practitioners do not need any specific general practice training.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things that the Democrats support, and one of the reasons we have worked so hard on this legislation, is that we believe general practitioners should be trained for general practice. But we also believe that we should have an opportunity to look at all those annual reports so they mean something, so that this review panel we have—the medical training review panel—is not ignored with its reports accumulating. The parliament then will make the decision whether or not to wipe out what I am now putting in as my amendments 3 and 4.

TALK.START.PARA: —I declare not a financial interest but an emotional interest at this point of time. If I can use my daughter as an example, she now will be denied the ability to have her patients claim Medicare benefits, and so will people between now and the year 2002. Then straight after that, we go back to the situation that now exists. So what you are doing, with great respect, is choosing a group of people—not forever, but over a period, it seems to me, of about six years—penalising them, and then the system just disappears after that. If you consider that to be fair, there is nothing I can do about it because the numbers are against us. But I just say that that is not my idea of fairness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I explain to Senator Cooney that, if his daughter is part of a recognised training program, she will be able to have a Medicare provider number and her patients will be able to claim through Medicare. We are only knocking out one of the options that current graduates have, that is, to go out immediately that they graduate or after a year or two in a hospital and set themselves up on the corner as a general practitioner without any GP training. She can do a range of other things. Part of the reason that we are setting up the review process and have the register of opportunity is to make sure that your daughter, along with all the other recent graduates, is fully aware of what all the options are.

SPEECH.PARA: I read into Hansard earlier—and I am quite happy to go back over—the sorts of jobs that are going to be available. Just with the RMO years, we are looking at least $30,000. Most of the paid hospital positions are getting at least $50,000 with overtime up towards $70,000 to $75,000. That is one avenue they may choose. They may also choose to go into GP training and that will mean that, as they go through the process they are earning, and, as they get into the GP section of it, they will get Medicare provider numbers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am talking about the generational unfairness. Why should her generation and the next six years be penalised by that and yet on 1 January 2002 people coming after do not have to go through the training course? They can come out as they do now, do an internship and get their provider numbers. Why do you pick out those people and those six years for special treatment, whereas it all disappears in the year 2002?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Personally, I hope that this legislation works and that we will not need the sunset clause, that this parliament will meet, look through all the reports and decide this is really working well. We are actually now getting graduates out into some of the positions that have been very hard to fill, and that includes some of the rural hospital positions and places at the moment often graduates do not know about. They do not bother to find out what a lot of the options are. It is easy to get a Medicare provider and set up down on the corner.

SPEECH.PARA: Hopefully, we will not need this clause. I have put this clause in for all those doctors and students out there that believe that this is going to be a disaster. One of the ways of making sure that we have some power over it is to put in this clause. We, in this place, will have to consciously come back in here and deliberately make the decision to continue it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator WOODS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The bottom line, I think, for Senator Cooney is that there will be a review and, if the review does not make any recommendations and enact any more legislation, then the whole thing will be dead. From that point of view, you are quite right. But you are making the assumption that there will not be a review. That is pretty unlikely. There will be a review. That is guaranteed. It is very likely if this thing works as we believe it will work, there will then be legislation continuing this on to whenever.
—Is this the appropriate time for someone to explain to me how this is going to improve access to rural and disadvantaged areas to GPs?
—I am not sure that it is the appropriate time, Senator West. I will see if anybody wishes to answer.
—Where do you want me to deal with it?
—Under the next item, item 14.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that amendments 3 and 4 moved by the Democrats be agreed to.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —We now move to item 14.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to make a number of general comments before we dealt with some detail, in particular the agreement that seems to have been nutted out between the Democrats and the government. The first point I want to make is that cuts to health to the extent of $1.7 billion over the next four years have been justified by an allegation of this government that there is some sort of general financial crisis but, in particular, there is some moment of panic in relation to health expenditure in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: If that were the case, as it appears the parliamentary secretary was stating earlier, I would like to ask the senator: why did the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare health expenditure bulletin that came out just recently indicate that, as a percentage of GDP, expenditure on health in Australia has declined over the past two years and has not been this wildly uncontrollable increasing amount, as the government would have us believe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods, Sen Bob

TALKER.NAME: Senator WOODS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the figures speak for themselves. On many, many occasions, until suddenly you lost an election, your various ministers for health were saying exactly the same thing. If we look at the PBS—we will be dealing with some of the issues on the PBS in a few moments—over the last four years, the cost of the PBS has doubled. Now if that is not spiralling wildly out of control, I do not know what is.

SPEECH.PARA: If we do not do anything about the PBS, for example, then over the next three years—I am not sure about the years—it will increase by 50 per cent. Certainly, in the next few years, it will increase by another 50 per cent. So that is certainly spiralling out of control.

If you look at the increasing costs of the MBS, they are going up perhaps not quite as quickly. But, certainly, some areas within that are, again, completely out of control. One of the reasons we had to take tough action is that if we do not do that we will undermine the whole viability of Medicare. In areas like radiology and pathology, you can look at the graphs and you know that they are almost exponential in the broad sense of the word—not literally the exponential curves. There is no doubt at all that things are actually increasing very rapidly.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question was not whether, in straight dollar terms, the health expenditure had increased. The question was whether, as a proportion of GDP, expenditure on health in Australia had declined over the last two years.

TALKER.NAME: Senator WOODS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you are trying to blur a few edges here. What you are talking about is total health expenditure, which includes state expenditure. We do not have any control over that. Essentially, if I can paint in the broad brush, PBS and MBS have gone up, which are the two main areas under Commonwealth control. But expenditure on hospitals has gone down—in particular, state spending on hospitals. That is the reason why there has been that decline. But, in terms of Medicare, which I think is what we are addressing tonight, expenditure has gone up in almost all of the important areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —There certainly has been a decline in spending on hospitals. I would suggest that the $800 million that this government has cut out of hospitals in this budget has probably got something to do with it. But there certainly is some connection between what the states expend in health and what money is provided to them in this area by the federal government.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the proposal that is before us, I want to clarify a number of issues that were raised by the parliamentary secretary where he misrepresented the position that I put in the second reading debate. The parliamentary secretary seemed to make a statement that we were opposed to the training of GPs. I have to say very clearly and very strongly that that is not the case. We are very supportive of the general concept of training in all the professions—particularly in the area of general practice in medicine.

What we are concerned about is not the issue of providing training at all but the issue of fairness and the implementation and how this is being done retrospectively. We believe that the main purpose of this legislation that the government is putting into place is not to enhance the standards of general practice but to place a gate to reduce the number of general practitioners using Medicare.

That is not inherently bad in itself. We are well aware that during the time that we were in government this was an issue that Labor health ministers grappled with and tried to bring about. But the real question is whether it is fair to put a gate in seven years after someone has commenced a medical degree or whether it would be fairer to put the gate in before they ever commenced. That is very strongly our view—that it is unfair to put a gate in after someone has undertaken six years of a medical degree and one year of internship and, in some cases, even more time than that.

The situation that is created is that the medical graduates themselves expend a lot of time, effort and money in gaining this training. Not only that but also, through our university system, where we provide a portion of money in training, public money is being wasted training doctors who will not get through the gate which you put in seven years on—not only seven years on but also retrospectively.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods, Sen Bob

TALKER.NAME: Senator WOODS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me deal with those issues as quickly as I can. First of all, I will refer to spending on health. The figures you quoted I think you said were from 1994. Am I right? I am sure you said 1994. Those figures do relate to 1994—
—The figures are 1993-94 and 1994-95.

—It may have escaped you, but you were actually in government in those years. You were actually controlling it yourself. Let us put aside the point scoring. Let us ignore the fact that the $800 million figure is wrong and that Commonwealth expenditure went up by $75 million. You really cannot say the $800 million, which does not exist in reality but even if it did exist would not have existed until next year, can have affected the expenditure from three years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the question about whether you want people to be trained or not. The facts of the matter belie what you are saying. You are saying that you want people to be able to go straight out of internship into the wider community and set up a shingle as a GP even though they are not trained. You are saying you want them to be trained, but what you are promoting is the ability of these people to set up and be funded by the taxpayer when they are not trained.

PARA.BREAK: We are saying quite the opposite. We are saying that we do not think they should go out there and set up a shingle as a GP until they are properly trained and have had the appropriate experience and vocational training or whatever the training might be. So the facts of the matter belie what you are saying. It is a nice airy-fairy principle, but the reality is that we are saying we want the public to be treated by doctors who are trained appropri ately and we are going to make sure that is the case.

SPEECH.PARA: You said that your respective ministers of health `grappled' with the supply side. I think that is probably an appropriate word. You did just grapple; you never came to terms with it and you never did anything about it. When you make the reference that money is wasted on training doctors—and I do not think anybody is exactly sure how much it costs—you wave the figure of $130,000 around. If that money is invested on doctors, that is fine. But if you think that is a waste in some way, are you going to compound that by saying that they can then go out into the community and consume on their supply induced expenditure something close to $200,000 per year per doctor in general practice?

There is something about quitting while you are ahead. Just looking at the economics of it, not the rights and wrongs of the training or quality of training, the money is not wasted. You talked about the expectations of people who have been training for seven years. It is usually a bit shorter than that, but never mind. I am not sure that that is not a very elitist point of view. There are lots of people who go through a lot of training.

We are not saying that they cannot practise medicine. We are saying that it may not be possible for them to practise medicine in a general practice in the middle of Sydney without further training. We are saying they need more training. We are saying that we cannot necessarily have the complete freedom of choice of free slather that they had under your government.

Our point of view, and I think the Democrats support this, is that there will be a position for all those people who want it to be able to go into practice. We are not saying that you cannot get through that gate. We are saying, `When you get through the gate, you may not be able to go up to the yellow brick road. You might have to choose the red brick road.'

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one item that I wish to clarify. I suspect that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services (Senator Woods) is intention ally misunderstanding the issue, but I want to clarify it for the record. The opposition is not opposed to further training for general practitioners. The opposition is not opposed to the requirement of having general practitioner training in order to be given a Medicare provider number. What we are opposed to is those two measures being coupled with a restriction—in this case to 400—for the number of places available for training so that a person who is ready, willing and able to undertake training in order to qualify for a provider number may not be able to achieve that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods, Sen Bob

TALKER.NAME: Senator WOODS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Neal has just confirmed exactly what I was saying: you may not be able to choose that particular type of medical practice to have a provider number, to set up a shingle and to practise as a GP in the middle of one of the major cities. We are saying that there will be an ability to practise medicine. It may be in a hospital or in a range of other options, and there will be training places for virtually every single doctor who wants it. But it may be that they cannot choose the most lucrative or most attractive option. The better ones will be able to, and there will be an element of competition there. But, as a result of this bill and helped by the amendments from the Democrats, there will be a number of places available which will be equivalent to the number of doctors looking for those places. It may be that their first choice will not be acceptable.

SPEECH.PARA: To say there are only 400 places is wrong. There are approximately 1,200 graduates each year plus a couple of hundred overseas trained doctors. If you look at the number of places, it almost exactly equates to that. If you allow for a few minor variations in people going to admin and a whole range of things like that, there will be enough places for the doctors. They may not be the places of their first choice, but that's life, that happens. We do not all get our first choice. Some of us finish up in the Senate rather than the Reps or vice versa. Some of us finish up in New South Wales rather than South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —But at least you got a chance before you got thrown out of the Reps.

—Yes, but we had a choice about it as well. We do have a choice about where we go and what we practise. And the same thing applies to any other career. What I think you are suggesting is that there should be some sort of special treatment for doctors. I would take the view that no other profession has the sorts of guarantees that you are saying that the young doctors should have.
—No, I'm saying they should not be allowed in if they can't graduate.
—The group which is responsible for there being too many doctors because there are too many graduates, if that is what you are saying, is the Labor government, of which you used to be a member.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not speak in the second reading debate because of the pressure of time, but I really cannot let this go without putting on the record my total objection to a clause that is as retrospective as this is. I also find that your arguments, Senator Woods, are straining credulity. You are doing very well, jumpin' from left foot to right foot, duckin' and twistin' and weavin'.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish we had on the record what you thought when we were actually discussing the introduction of vocational registration at all. It would have been very nice if we could have come back here today with some of the Hansard quotes of when you vilified and pilloried this government for even contemplating the idea that a graduate with one year's internship should be encouraged to do vocational registration at all before they should have the option of two tiers of fees, depending effectively on whether they had participated in vocational registration or not.

PARA.BREAK: But your arguments to Senator Neal a minute ago were deliberately misunderstanding and misrepresenting her. When she talked about a person training for six or seven years, there's not much mileage in making petty points about whether it is six or seven, Senator. It is six or seven until we get into the four years undergraduate and four years post graduate. If you want to nitpick like that at this stage of the night, do not think it does you much credit.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, if doctors finish six or seven years of training and then discover that there is not a course place in postgraduate general practice training and the options for them are very few or that there are options that they had not planned to participate in, I ask you to consider, Senator, what your attitude would be if we were introducing this legislation. You would be over the top, foaming at the mouth and carrying on. What you have to face up to is the fact that you are actually committing a dreadful error here—it is worse than an error; I would regard it as almost a crime but certainly it is an appalling piece of legislation—because it is introducing a retrospective effect of effectively six years.

If you came in here and said, `This government is intent on doing this, on seeing a restriction on the number of doctors who can just walk out and automatically start practising and we are going to give three years notice,' I think a lot of people would have said that that was reasonable. It is rough. It is rough for people who have started down three years of a course, but for people who have finished it is a disgrace. I would like to see you take on the legal profession in the same way. I would like you to take on anybody else.

Secondly, Senator, you can remind us if you like what you anticipate the savings will be on this. But if out of one side of your mouth you are saying there are some savings because the costs are huge and out of the other side you are saying that there are really going to be no doctors affected, there are going to be a lot of jobs for them, then I do not know how you can hold both of those and tie both of your shoes straight.

The other thing too, Senator, is that Senator Neal is right: if somebody trains for six years at the cost you estimate of around $130,000 and then cannot proceed to practise medicine, particularly the medicine that they choose to—some doctors will not want to, Senator—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is their choice. Anybody who wants to can.

—it is not their choice. it is like saying to people, `You can choose nothing or blue'. That is not really a choice. It is a Liberal coalition government that has brought down this gross injustice to the current generation of graduates. That is all it is and nothing more: a gross injustice. If you were on the other side of the chamber arguing against us introducing this bill you would be fulminating about it. It is to legislate a gross injustice, as Senator Cooney said, to a particular generation of medical students and medical graduates—no more and no less.

SPEECH.PARA: I do believe that it is important that this Labor opposition makes very clear its total objection to what you are doing. I can only concur utterly with all the words that my colleagues have said and, vested interest or not, I think Senator Cooney explains it very well—a generation. I would say, Senator Lees, that you have been sold a pup or else you have helped to sell it. But I am not persuaded by your arguments. Indeed, I understand your intent about being serious about what are the consequences for graduating medical students—the information, for example, that might be constructive for us in terms of further understanding and planning in this area—but I do not believe the way we are doing it is just or fair. That is the main objection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise the question I foreshadowed earlier. I want someone to explain to me precisely how it is anticipated that this is going to improve access to rural areas of adequate numbers of general practitioners who are adequately trained. We know that this is being implemented to improve the training of GPs, and that is fine. That is great. But then we keep hearing about how this is going to improve, in their training years, access of GPs by sending them out to the country areas.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to know some of the details about how you anticipate doing this, because I do not want to see the whereby you will end up sending out young, inexperienced people to work in these places without adequate supervision and support. I think that that is a question that you need to explain to me. You offered to explain it to me when you were wrapping up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —As this was a major part of our proposal, one of my major interests was to make sure that we really did tackle the issue of doctors into rural areas a little more seriously than it has been done in the past. With all the efforts that are going on to date, we have less than a one per cent increase. We are barely holding the line. Yes, we are encouraging a few more doctors out there, but they are retiring and moving back at almost the same rate as we are encouraging them out there.

SPEECH.PARA: But for Senator West to somehow expect we could wave a magic wand and get adequately trained doctors out into rural areas overnight is ridiculous. It would mean some sort of conscription. Are you advocating, Senator West, that we allocate Medicare provider numbers by location? There is no short cut. If we are going to get doctors out there, it is going to take time. I have been arguing that we need to do more than we are doing at the moment.

There are a range of measures in this bill. The 250 additional rural places are only at the bottom of the safety net. I would just like to go through a couple of the other proposals. One of them has nothing to do with us. It was already in the package and it was a good reason to, indeed, support what the minister was doing in order to get those clinical assistantships, because they are a way of short‐circuiting yourself into the college of general practice if you will agree—we are talking about newly registered doctors—to go out into a rural hospital.

There are other avenues such as Aboriginal medical services. They are supervised, pre‐training positions which would count towards the requirement of the RACGP training program. Provided that these doctors meet the RACGP's minimum standards, doctors working as clinical assistants would be guaranteed entry to the training program after a minimum of one and a maximum of four years if a place had not been obtained sooner. In other words, it is helping those people who are either deciding to wait a year or very keen to get into the RACGP training program. They can go and spend that time out there in a rural area and it gives them that additional boost.

We also have an undertaking with the minister to go back again to the RACGP to keep negotiating. They already have, as of 1 July 1995, a requirement that all their trainees undertake a period of training either in the country or another area of need. We are arguing that we can tighten that up and increase the percentage of places within the 400 quota. I think Senator Neal was at the hearing when we found that they have 900 places but they can fill only 400, of which 60 per cent can be in the city, which means we can basically have no-one out training in the country. We are looking at that equation and that problem with the RACGP to increase the percentage of places for training in rural areas.

Also, the deans of the medical faculties around the country are already required to provide a small amount of time in the country. We have asked that that be increased and that they use every opportunity right throughout those five or six years in university to get some experience out in a rural area—in other words, rather than ending up at Flinders, they go down to Victor Harbour or perhaps out to Murray Bridge for a couple of weeks during their university time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think it is fair to require someone who has done six or seven years training at university and one year as an intern to then have to do between one and four years of pre-training training and then four to six years of training before they can be provided with a Medicare number? Aren't we getting to a stage where it is becoming a little silly to go that far?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —You are the one that just suggested that you supported the basic concept of GPs being fully trained. I think you were also at the hearing when it was discussed that the RACGP was now recognising up to 18 months of hospital service as part of that three or four years people spend training as a GP. So we are not looking at continually adding that up. A lot of that work will concertina. Many doctors now—indeed, I am told the vast majority—do not come straight out of that one hospital year and move straight into a training course. Virtually all the young doctors who have been spending time with me back in Adelaide and visiting my office here are saying that it is two or three years now that doctors spend doing hospital work and other things before deciding on which training program they even want to apply for.

SPEECH.PARA: So I do not believe we are extrapolating this. We must remember that through this training process they are on $30,000, $40,000, $50,000 or $60,000 a year and sometimes over that. We are not talking about unpaid training, as some people may think we are. We are talking about well paid training with a whole range of options. Part of the package we have negotiated with government is that we look at reforms for the RMOs and salaried medical practitioners. Part of the trouble of getting people into hospitals has been that they hit a brick wall. After those three or four years of making up their minds, they really have to go back to square 1. We need a better range of training opportunities and pathways through the public hospital system, and different pathways to be a GP rather than just the RACGP training program. That is part of what this package is dealing with as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand the argument that young doctors who are not yet fully trained should not be allowed to treat patients. I can understand that proposition, but that is not the proposition that this legislation puts forward at all. Your proposed section 19CC makes that very clear. There is nothing to stop a doctor who has done an internship treating patients. So it is not about merit. It is not about protecting patients from doctors who are not qualified. If it were, you could follow that argument. But proposed section 19CC makes it quite clear that that is not the case.

SPEECH.PARA: This is about ensuring that the patients they do treat do not get Medicare, because it is budget driven. If you do not have a Medicare number, the only way you can be punished for treating a patient is if you do not tell the patient that you do not have a Medicare number. That is the only thing, if you look at proposed section 19CC; it is a compulsion on the doctor for treating a patient. It is an obligatory section. There is a penalty unit if he or she does not do that. If that is not conscription within the meaning of 23A, then how else would you describe it?

TALK.START.PARA: —A medical service is being provided.

—A medical service is being provided and the person who is providing it is obliged to carry out the consumer protection for the Commonwealth. So why isn't proposed section 19CC a form of civil conscription? Why do you let people who are not—on your own statement—worthy, who do not have enough merit and who do not have enough training treat people?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods, Sen Bob

TALKER.NAME: Senator WOODS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me deal with a whole range of issues. Firstly, let me just look at the general point raised by Senator Crowley. She asked me what I would do if it were the other way round and we were in opposition and she was introducing this measure. I would be up there in the rafters with the bogongs, swinging around, beating my chest and saying, `Thank God Senator Crowley has at last done something worth while.' It is not often over the last eight years I have been able to say that, Rosemary, I must say.

SPEECH.PARA: She also raised the question of whether we would be prepared to take on the legal profession. If the legal profession had these sorts of rorts, yes, we would have to take them on. Let me use this example: a rort in the legal profession which would be equivalent to what has been happening here—I do not think there has been rorting going on in the medical profession—would be to say to somebody coming out of law school that not only can they set up a shingle as a criminal litigation lawyer and go straight to the bar and earn a fortune from trial procedures but also the government will pay them to do it. That is essentially the equivalent. There is no suggestion that is going to happen in the legal profession much. If that sort of thing were happening in the legal profession, we would be doing exactly the same thing to the legal profession. Hopefully, you would have done it in the past anyway, bearing in mind your general opposition—

TALK.START.PARA: —You have already done it to them. You have cut legal aid.

—You are saying we have cut legal aid. We can argue about the cuts, but nobody in the legal profession can hang up a shingle and become one of the leading trial lawyers until they actually have the extra training and extra experience. We are saying exactly the same thing here: you need the training and you need the experience.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a discrepancy between what Senator West was saying and what Senator Neal was saying. On the one hand, Senator Neal was saying that she supported adequate training; on the other hand, Senator West was almost saying, `How dare you send undertrained people out into the bush.' Yet Senator Neal is saying you can because they are actually trained okay. There is a bit of a chasm between those two views: either you are going to have trained doctors or you are not going to have trained doctors.

As I think Senator Lees pointed out, we are not talking about unpaid training—we are not talking about students on Austudy—we are talking by and large about doctors who, after their intern year, are earning $50,000, $60,000 or $70,000 a year. Most of our society would be very happy to be earning that while they are training. It is not as though we are actually putting them on the breadline. It is not as though they are going to be stricken with poverty. They are earning quite a good income.

If you look at Senator Eggleston's incorporated speech, I think you will find that the average time between qualifying and actually going out into the big wide world as a medical practitioner is some 3½ years. I stand to be corrected on that but in general terms that is right. One of the points Senator Eggleston was making was that, in some regards, it is what already happens in the real world.

BREAK.PARA: We are saying a number of things. Firstly, you should not be able to go out and practice by yourself unsupervised and without the appropriate training. Indeed you should not also be an extra burden—which is getting towards $200,000 a year—upon the taxpayer. We are talking about not so much the question of whether you can move into the area of practice; we are talking about what sort of practice you can do. Can you go out and set up a shingle, be a GP and be a burden on the taxpayer with supply-driven demands, which are very high indeed, or should you go through the training. We are saying that you should go through the training. It is better for quality and it is better for economics.

Turning to what Senator Cooney was saying, it is quite difficult to stop a qualified medical practitioner from practising. We as a Commonwealth have no powers to do that. We are saying that they should be under some sort of supervision or some sort of training. We are ensuring that there will be a range of programs which will mean that virtually everybody who wants to undergo further training will be able to get that. I am not aware of any powers that we have which could stop a doctor from practising. Sure, we are making it difficult for them to practice by themselves, and that is entirely appropriate. We are pressuring them, if you like, into undergoing appropriate training and experience gathering.

In regard to the question of the penalty being on not informing patients that they are not going to get a Medicare rebate, I thought this was something you were greatly in favour of. In terms of Carmen Lawrence's legislation when she was health minister, I thought you were urging us to make sure that patients knew exactly what they were up for. We are doing exactly the same thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't that civil conscription?

—If that is the case, then Carmen Lawrence, the previous health minister, was also guilty of conscription. Of course it is not conscription. What we are saying is, in general principles, what you have been saying; that is, the patient should know what they are up for. If they are not going to get a rebate, they should know that in advance. If they are going to be faced with a bill which they cannot get any rebate on, we believe they should know. I thought everybody in this chamber supported the proposition of giving patients as much information about what they are likely to be up for as they possibly can. I am surprised there is any question about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I fully support higher education and greater qualifications for general practitioners, but my concern is that I do not know that you have fully thought through how you are going to implement this. I do not think there has been adequate consultation. I know you are always going to be able to buy a fight with the AMA. They are the most powerful union in Australia. You are a member of the AMA—
—Would you please stop telling me that.
—They are the most powerful union in Australia.
—What about the law society.
—The law society, yes. But there are more lawyers over here on this side. I do not want to put them offside.
—The nursing association.

—We will flex our muscles. In country areas there is a shortage of medical practitioners. It is quite possible that the clinical assistant‐ships will go some way to overcoming this shortage, but they do require supervision. The places which are short of doctors that I can think of in rural New South Wales are small communities where I do not think the current GPs are in a position to take on any additional supervisory load. That to me is of great concern.

SPEECH.PARA: I am flagging to the parliamentary secretary the issues that I think are of concern. I am sorry that Senator Eggleston had to go back to Western Australia for the election tomorrow, because we would have been able to have had a very constructive discussion with his being a doctor who has worked in rural areas and in isolation.

BREAK.PARA: There is a sort of dichotomy I cannot quite understand and comprehend. We hear that it should be compulsory to have six months or even 12 months either in rural health or Aboriginal health out of the capital cities, but we also hear the call for cognisance to be taken of the needs of females who will be undertaking this training, especially those with small families. They will not have the capacity to move out of the capital cities, or wherever their spouse is located, for six months. I am just not sure there is going to be enough flexibility built into this training to accommodate the needs of these people.

We do recognise that the needs of women in receiving additional training in colleges for doctors are not being addressed. There is inadequate part-time training offered. The glass ceilings there have been well identified. I am flagging a possible barrier for women in that this proposal will disadvantage them. I do not want that to happen.

As I say, I do not know that they will have the support there for supervision in small country areas. I do not even know whether there would be enough accommodation, somewhere for them to live, in these small towns. These are all issues that have to be addressed. I am not disagreeing with clinical assistant‐ships necessarily but I am saying that there are problems which I do not think you have addressed. They are good sounding words, but I do not see how it is going to work. You have not put enough thought into it. I just flag those concerns to you.

TALKER.NAME: Senator WOODS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services)

They are very supportive. There is enormous support from the divisions of general practice which, as you know, cover pretty well all the rural areas nowadays. There is also additional support through the university departments of rural health. I have no doubts at all that there will be adequate resources and facilities.

SPEECH.PARA: I have circulated a draft bill. I am very much a supporter of the view that patients are entitled to access their medical records and to participate, in a fully informed sense, in decisions about their medical care. In light of the hour, I ask leave of the Senate to incorporate some words that I have on this amendment.
Leave granted.
PATIENT ACCESS TO MEDICAL RECORDS
Schedule 4—Amendments relating to patient access to medical records. (Amendment to the Health Insurance Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996)
This bill aims to address the consumer and consumer group concern about patient access to medical records.
In the UK, Canada, New Zealand and in most states in the United States, people have a right to gain access to their own medical records.

At the moment, patients can get access to records held by public authorities through Commonwealth and State Freedom of Information Legislation. Medical records held by private practitioners can also be subpoenaed or compulsorily disclosed through the process of discovery in a court of law.
The limitation, as shown in the recent High Court decision of Breen v Williams, is that proceedings must have already commenced. Records could not be obtained before proceedings were underway.

Under present legislation NSW patients treated in private hospitals, day procedure centres and residents of nursing homes can make a written request to the organisation for access to their health records.

As soon as possible the organisation must make the medical record available for the patient or a representative to inspect. Access can only be denied if it would harm the patient's physical or mental health.
The patient must be given help with the interpretation of test results, for example, and where the patient disagrees with the information their comments must be attached to the record on request.
A patient can appeal to the Director-General of the Health Department if the patient is refused access to their medical records.
The NSW legislation and the UK model is similar to the model I propose both in intent and style.

The amendment I move today seeks to extend current access and to make it a uniform and legislated right. It is the minimalist position. It seeks to incorporate doctors concerns while covering most medical professionals not already covered and most patients.
There are much more complicated routes that can be taken, which will be confusing to consumers and complicated for health organisations and doctors to administer.
Many people may not want to read their own medical records but few people realise they don't have a right to see information which is kept on their health by doctors and other medical professionals.
Most people would think they were able to view their files just as they are entitled to see a file held on them by the Department of Social Security, for example.

There are many reasons why people want to see their medical files. People may want to be better informed about their health, in which case they will want to discuss their medical records with their current GP.
Some patients want to take their current and past medical information to a different doctor, for a second opinion, or because they have moved.
Essentially, many people want ownership of the management of their own health. People want to have a greater role in making decisions about their own health care.
I do not believe there will be, or should be, information contained in a medical record kept on a patient that a patient could or should not view.
There will be situations, where a patient shouldn't see his or her medical file. This amendment takes that into account.
The amendment provides that where a doctor is of the view, based on reasonable grounds, that access to the records may cause serious physical or mental harm to a person then access can be denied.
It has mainly been psychiatrists and other medical professionals working in areas of mental health, that are worried about patients access to medical records.

Where a patient will suffer serious mental or physical harm from viewing their record then access can be denied. But even in this situation, a doctor should think carefully. A patient shouldn't be denied the same rights as other people solely on the basis that he or she is suffering a condition that affects mental health.

The Government often talks about the need for greater competition in the health sector, between doctors, other practitioners, hospitals and health funds for example, but are not prepared to give patients the information they need to make more informed decisions about treatment options.
The most fundamental information a patient requires is their own medical history.

Patients are given copies of their x-rays for example, so they can take them to other doctors and will always have information about the injury for future consultations. Patients will generally pay for x‐rays.
Most people think that because medical information is recorded on files about their own health that they must own or have a right of access to that information.

In Breen v Williams the court ruled that because doctors recorded the information and a patient didn't pay for the information, as they do for an x-ray, for example, ownership rested with the person compiling the medical record and the doctor could refuse access.
Justice Brennan stated in his judgement that if a patient's health would be jeopardised by not viewing his or her records, then the patient should be given access.
In the judgement, it was emphasised that any changes regarding patient access to medical records was a matter for the parliament rather than the courts.
Patients also want to be able to correct the information recorded about them on their medical records, or to at least have the file noted that they disagree with a certain piece of information.

Article 17.1 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, ratified by Australia, enshrines a right to privacy. The right to privacy has been interpreted to include the right to have some control over the perceptions of a person contained in his or her medical records.
The amendment will allow a patient to ask for his or her record to be corrected and where a doctor disagrees, to have the record noted with the patient's concern.

Allowing patients access to their medical records will enhance the doctor-patient relationship. It will allow patients to have greater trust in their doctor knowing they are able to view their records.
Doctors and other health professionals are willing to discuss these issue with patients, but there is no right of access for patients to view records that are written about their health.
Many doctors already allow patients access to their medical records but this amendment would make it a right.

The AMA in its code of conduct, encourages doctors to give patients access to their health records. I applaud this initiative. The point is that this access is entirely at the discretion of the doctor and not a right.
This legislation makes access to a person's medical records a right, enforceable by sanctions that are reasonable but persuasive.

To me it states a philosophy that a person's health and life should not be entirely in the hands of all knowing professionals, who whisper behind doors and determine in private what is best for you, the patient.
Health management I believe should be the function of a mutual relationship of trust between us: the patient and the medical worker, each with equal access to information and input into the process.
The objective of this amendment is to bring this type of environment about.
I urge you to support the amendment.
Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 gives legislative effect to the 1996 government budget decision to discontinue the payment of the untargeted operational subsidy to community based long day care centres from 1 July 1997. This bill also gives effect to the 1996 budget decision to apply a reduced rate of entitlement to the child-care cash rebate for families on higher incomes while retaining the current rate for families on lower incomes. This change will take effect from 1 April 1997.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill also introduces amendments aimed at clarifying eligibility issues and compliance requirements consistent with the intentions of the Commonwealth child-care cash rebate scheme. The removal of operational subsidy is about equity for parents. Operational subsidy is currently paid on a non-means tested basis to community centres which provide around only 30 per cent of all centre based care catering for 70,000 families. Operational subsidy has never been paid to private centres even though they provide 70 per cent of centre based care and cater for more than 220,000 families.

The removal of the untargeted operational subsidy from community child-care centres removes a significant inequity in government assistance that currently exists for families using private rather than community based long day care. Inequities exist between the 70,000 families in community based centres receiving operational subsidy, the 220,000 families in private centres not receiving operational subsidy, the 27,000 low income families receiving maximum child-care assistance benefiting from operational subsidy in community centres, the 96,000 families receiving child-care assistance who are in private centres which do not benefit from operational subsidy, the 14,000 babies in community centres receiving operational subsidy and the 26,000 babies in private centres which do not receive operational subsidy.

An examination of comparative figures for other areas shows that twice as many children with special needs are in private centres, over twice as many private centres are in rural and remote areas and that the private sector provides double the number of places for children of sole parents compared with the community sector. I know that all those figures will be of surprise to many people.

Importantly, all special or high cost services provided by community child-care centres are also provided by the private sector. Perhaps the greatest inequity relates to the 18,000 high income families—those families earning above the child-care assistance cut‐offs—in community centres that benefit from operational subsidy compared to the 96,000 low income families receiving maximum child-care assistance who are in private centres and who do not benefit from operational subsidy. It is inequitable that none of these parents receive the same level of subsidy as parents using community based long day care centres.

Since the budget, families have been told by the opposition that, because of the removal of operational subsidy, community based centres will close and/or fees will increase dramatically. I would strongly encourage parents to challenge such claims. The government has set aside $8.3 million over two years to help centres purchase management and financial advice to assist them to increase efficiencies, to reduce costs and to operate without operational subsidy. This $8.3 million is additional to the $11.5 million available over three years to assist centres to upgrade and to amalgamate.

The government will also provide $12.5 million over four years to ensure that families in severely disadvantaged areas maintain access to child care. Such assistance will minimise service closures and the need for fee increases.

Claims have also been made that quality of care will fall as a result of this measure. But nothing could be further from the truth. Quality care is best ensured not through operational subsidy but by the quality improvement and accreditation system and state licensing requirements which both private and community based long day care centres are subject to. Eight‐five per cent of all private services that have completed the quality improvement and accreditation system have achieved the standard necessary to achieve accreditation without the benefit of operational subsidy.

The government is committed to maintaining the accreditation system for child‐care centres and to extending it to family day care and outside school hours care. Senators Faulkner and Lundy have indicated that services offered by centres contribute to quality and that operational subsidy has enabled community child‐care centres to offer additional services such as dance classes and music lessons.

I accept that quality encompasses services as well as the developmental activities and interactions offered by a child‐care centre. However, as Senator Lundy pointed out, services such as dance classes and music lessons are `part of the choice that parents make when they send their child to a specific centre.' Such choices should not be funded by the taxpayer. The parents of the 220,000 children in private long day care centres, whether they are low or high income earners, pay for such services themselves.

The government's decision to cease paying an operational subsidy to community based long day care centres will eliminate the inequities of the current system, treating families who use community based long day care no differently from the majority of families who use private long day care. Savings from this measure have been directed towards areas of need. Over the next four years, $10.9 million will be provided to fund new places to ensure families in rural and remote areas have access to flexible child care, and $31 million has been set aside to support the inclusion of children with high levels of additional needs into child‐care services.

Five hundred and twenty‐six million dollars in operational subsidies will be provided over the next four years to support family day care, outside school hours care, occasional care, multifunctional children's services and multifunctional Aboriginal children's services—services which are crucial to meeting the diverse needs of Australian families.

Before I go on to discuss the second measure implemented by this bill, the change to the child‐care cash rebate, I would like to address some of the misconceptions that have been raised in the course of this debate about the position in Tasmania. Tasmania, as has been pointed out, has more community based long day care centres than it has private centres. Senators opposite have described Tasmania as being rural and remote; that it is disadvantaged. Senator Mackay went on to claim that the government's decision would mean that half of the existing community based centres will close over the next two years as every centre is reliant on the operational grants subsidy to survive.

As I indicated at the start of my speech, the removal of operational subsidy is about equity for parents. Why should the 555 high income families using community based long day care in Tasmania receive the benefit of a subsidy that the 427 low income families in private centres in Tasmania cannot access? As is the case in every state and territory, community based child-care centres in Tasmania do not necessarily care for low income families. I am aware of one child-care centre in southern Tasmania where 56 per cent of the children attending the centre have parents whose incomes are above the child-care assistance cut‐offs. The national average is only 26 per cent. In the rural and remote regions of Tasmania family day care provides more child‐care places than does community based long day care—517 places compared to 378 places. As I said stated earlier, operational subsidy has been retained for family day care.

While there are more community based centres in Tasmania than there are private centres, there is no significant difference in fees between the two sectors. On average the community based sector charges only $4 a week less than private centres. The average weekly fee charged by community based centres in Tasmania is $155.50 for 50 hours of care, while private centres charge on average $159.50 per week. Despite receiving on average $25 per week per child, Tasmanian parents are not necessarily benefiting from operational subsidy. And I note that the previous government and this government over the last two years have put $232,000 into management restructuring grants and to deal with problems of community child-care centres, looking at pre-existing management problems and problems relating to committee governance. Yet surely that is a recognition of the fact that there has been considerable need for the restructuring finance which this government is offering to child-care centres to become viable and more efficient.

This government has kept its election commitment to retain child care assistance and the child-care cash rebate. The government has not applied a means test to the child-care cash rebate as stated by Senator Faulkner. The rebate remains available to all families using care for work related reasons. However the government considers that it is only fair and equitable that high income earners make a greater contribution to their child-care costs. Families with incomes below the new family tax initiative cut‐offs of $70,000 for one child families, rising by $3,000 for each additional dependent child, will continue to receive a 30 per cent rebate, while families with incomes above those cut‐offs will receive a 20 per cent rebate. This measure only reduces benefits for families in the top 20 per cent of incomes in Australia. So the opposition to this measure is puzzling. It is odd that the interests of higher income earners are being so keenly promoted.

Before I conclude, there were points that were made in the debate by Senator Crowley which I wanted to address. In answer to a question by Senator Crowley on an amendment to the child-care rebate act which concerns section 36C, this amendment will prevent payment of the rebate for care provided by a registered carer to children of that carer's spousal partner or business partner in a child-care business.

In the case of a spousal partner's children, it will prevent payment of rebate for care that would usually be provided free. This is consistent with existing provisions that prevent a carer claiming rebate for caring for their own dependent children. In the case of a business partner, it ensures that a parent cannot pay their own business for child care and then claim the rebate on that payment. I trust that that gives the answer Senator Crowley was looking for.

The measures contained in this bill eliminate Labor's inequities and establish a strategic direction for child care which is sustainable in the long term and protects the benefits of low and middle income earners while ensuring that high income earners who can afford to make a greater contribution to child-care costs do so. I commend the bill to the Senate.

The opposition is committed to opposing this particular schedule for a number of very good reasons. Firstly, we take very seriously our responsibilities as an opposition to keep this very deceitful government to its promises. This is a government that made clear before the election that they intended to keep the operational subsidy for community based long day care. This is yet another promise to be defined as a `non-core promise', one that the coalition believes it is appropriate for it to break.

This is a government that made clear before the election that they intended to keep the operational subsidy for community based long day care—of course, yet another promise to be defined as a non‐core promise, one that the coalition believes it is appropriate for it to break. The effect of removing the operational subsidy will be that centres will have two choices: they will put up their fees by anything up to $20 and $25 a week per child or they will have to reduce their services—and that is the alternative that the government favours.

One service that all the community based centres around Australia are considering removing is the more extensive, highly qualified staff that they have in their centres. The direct impact of that of course will be a reduction in the quality of care that children in community based centres have in this country. Parents will be required to pay more for food or provide lunches for their children in child‐care centres. That will mean that parents will be indirectly paying more for their children's care.

Other sorts of services that centres are considering removing are nappy services and other services that in any other place would be considered essential. Any suggestion that these are moves that in some way might improve efficiency can only be described as very short‐sighted indeed.

The view that the government seems to have of efficiency equates with poorer quality, more children per staff member in child‐care centres, less qualified staff and fewer services. It is the sort of deceitful action that we have come to expect from this government that specialises in betrayal. I commend amendment 1 standing in my name to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Schacht, would you mind if I ruled on the point of order? I have been saying the same thing. The particular question before the chair is—and I will say it again—that item 18 of schedule 2 stand as printed. I do believe that the first contribution which was in order was Senator Evans's because he was addressing matters which are in this particular schedule. As long as contributions are on that particular schedule, they are in order.
—Having ruled that way, Mr Chairman, I would appreciate it if you would ask the minister to reply to the propositions and questions that I put to her.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the minister: why did the coalition, in its election manifesto, say that a coalition government will maintain the non-means tested child‐care cash rebate?

—Mr Chairman, on a point of order: that is not relevant to item 18, which you are seeking to replace. What you should be debating is the calculation of the new rebate. This is the committee stage of the bill. This is when you seek out and explore the detail of the clause that is before the committee. That question is totally irrelevant to that. Mr Chairman, I respectfully put to you that the question ought to be ruled out of order.

—Mr Chairman, on the point of order: it is quite relevant for the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate to ask a question about what clearly was a policy change which affects this section of the legislation. If this is ruled out, the committee stage is not worth two bob, because no-one will be able to ask any questions other than in relation to those narrow, restricted, technical definitions. Ever since I have been in the Senate, the committee stage has been involved in wide ranging discussion on the policy implications of particular clauses. Mr Chairman, the question from Senator Faulkner is on the policy implication of the government's changing their policy from what they announced in the election to what they have introduced in the parliament through this clause.

—I mention that item 18, schedule 2, goes from page 8 to page 13. It covers matters other than the calculation of the rebate. For example, 46 speaks about family payment notices and family income notices. If there are contributions relating to that item of the schedule, they are in order.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for that, Mr Chairman. That is a good and proper ruling. I now ask the minister for an answer.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation is that there is not a means test on the child-care cash rebate, and to portray that there is would be a total misrepresentation. We have an equity measure which gives the rebate at two different levels. But it is still open to anybody in the work force to access. It is not means tested.
—Could you tell me what the difference is between an equity measure and a means test?
—What is the difference between a means test and an income cut‐off?

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That schedule 2, item 18 stand as printed.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Schedule 2, item 22, page 14 (line 26), omit `Penalty: 20 penalty units.'.

Here we have a situation where the government is proposing to insert a new penalty provision where penalties already exist for providing false and misleading information. The view of the opposition is that this particular provision is completely superfluous and absolutely unnecessary. It is hardly surprising that we have a provision in a bill under the stewardship of such an incompetent minister as Mrs Moylan in the House of Representatives who has been forensically exposed by Jenny Macklin, the shadow minister, in this particular area. In fact, I think this has even been the subject of debate in the House of Representatives, while we on this side of the chamber, and some other senators—most of us with the exception of Senator Newman—have been concentrating on the social security legislation before the chamber.

I ask the minister at the table why the minister believes that this provision is necessary, given the fact that section 60 of the substantive act, which already has a considerable section in relation to penalty provisions, is required.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the answer to the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate is something like this. Currently the act imposes penalties for people knowingly making false or misleading statements in connection with registration or claims under the act. Whether a statement is false or misleading depends on the circumstances in which it is made and is open to interpretation in a court of law. The proposed penalty provisions are different. They relate to situations which are not open to interpretation, such as whether or not a cancellation notice of family payment or family income has been issued to a person, or to circumstances that would make a carer's registration no longer valid. If the situation exists, the person must notify the commission of it in writing. If they do not, they are subject to the penalty.

SPEECH.PARA: The interesting thing is that legal advice on the opposition amendment to remove the penalty provision from proposed section 58 is that this would render the provisions unenforceable. I find it very hard to understand why the opposition is persisting with their amendment, Mr Chairman. They have tried this tack in the other house and have already been apprised of the fact, if they did not know when they started out on this engagement whether their amendment was to be successful, that they would replace the $2,000 penalty with a term of imprisonment. If that is what the opposition considers to be a more desirable outcome, then one could only assume that they will be urging us all to support their amendment very thoroughly. The government thinks that a $2,000 penalty would be quite sufficient and a term of imprisonment is not appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, is it appropriate for a minister from the House of Representatives to be wandering around on the floor of the Senate? Is that in order?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I am certain that the minister will take a seat if she is in the chamber. The question is that the amendment be agreed to.

Bill agreed to.
