SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

Mr Deputy President, I am sure that at the end of a long session and at nearly 2.30 a.m., you would not mind me recognising that this has been an exceptionally good year for the new government. It is a government that was elected with a big mandate. It has had the opportunity and has already demonstrated its commitment to implement its program for the benefit of all Australians.

When one reflects on what has been achieved in this session, we have seen major reforms. The changes to industrial relations in this country via the workplace relations legislation, which will allow employers and employees to work together for their mutual benefit in an unprecedented way in this country, can only be of benefit to all Australians. The decision to sell one‐third of Telstra, which will lead to a more competitive and efficient telecommunications industry, will give us the opportunity to repay large sums of public debt and therefore take pressure off interest rates and help small business and, therefore, help the unemployed.

We have seen the introduction of the family tax initiative, which has been spoken about a bit tonight. It has the opportunity to benefit some two million Australian families, particularly those in the lower to middle income levels. The implementation of the national firearms program was a wonderful reform in this country that will ensure that we do not head down the path of those countries in which carrying weapons is part of their culture. It is taking us for the first time in a new direction in relation to firearms. We have seen a great demonstration of leadership from the new Prime Minister, Mr Howard, on that particular reform.

The introduction of very significant reforms to higher education, schools and vocational education will improve the efficiency and effectiveness of education in this country and enhance its quality and opportunity for all Australians. If I might be allowed to say it, reforms have been introduced to secure the funding base to set up for the first time in the history of this country a natural heritage trust that will allow the reinvestment of $1.1 billion in our natural heritage. It is a wonderful opportunity. It is a moment of history that will be remembered by future generations. It is a very exciting agenda and it has been a great thrill to achieve so much in just a short period.

I want to pay credit to my colleagues. They worked hard, they had a sense of purpose and they cooperated. I turn around and see the whips, my ministerial colleagues, the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Campbell) and the whole team. Senator Ferguson did a great job. They all deserve credit for the achievements that we have been able to put on the register in just a short period.

I would also like to thank the other side—the Labor Party, the Democrats, the Greens and the Independents—for at least their cooperation in the process, because without that cooperation we would not have had the opportunity to put to the vote such a very large legislative program in a short period of time. I do record our appreciation for that cooperation which has enabled us to put so many of our reforms into place on such an early occasion.

I take this opportunity at the end of the year to thank the officials, the clerks, the Senate staff, attendants, security, transport, Hansard, library—all of those who work so hard for this institution and to enable us to fulfil our legislative responsibilities. Half past two in the morning is a good time, I think, to add extra thanks to them for service beyond the normal call of duty. All that is left for me is, on behalf of the government, to wish everyone a merry Christmas and a happy New Year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also would like to thank all those people who have contributed during this year so willingly and effectively to the work of the Senate. I thank the clerks. I particularly thank Rosemary Laing, who has so often responded in such a cheerful way to what have often been quite outrageous requests, really, from the opposition. I thank Hansard, I thank the others within the Department of the Senate, the committee staff, the library staff, the attendants in this building, the transport officers, the catering staff, the gardeners, the cleaners, the maintenance workers, security staff, the Comcar drivers, the dining room, the printery, in fact all those who contribute—
—Gardeners.
—I have already said gardeners—everyone who contributes to the running of the Senate, because without their help and support we would not be able to do our job in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I also want to acknowledge the parliamentary liaison officers, Gail Bansemer who has just come on board in the Senate, and Nhan Vo Van. I do wish Nhan Vo Van well. He has gone to work for Senator Hill—probably a pretty poor career move, frankly—and I hope that he does not bring the government up to speed too quickly on parliamentary business. Oh boy, he's got his work cut out for him. Nhan was appointed to the very important position in the Senate of parliamentary liaison officer in the good old days when I was Manager of Government Business, and we wish him well in his new found home.

This year has been a very eventful one in Australian politics. It has not been a great year for the Labor Party—and we have acknowledged that—since what was a very thumping defeat back in March. We suffered an awful loss at the election and all of us in the caucus of the parliamentary Labor Party saw the departure of very many of our good friends and comrades. But, for all that, I think that it is a great thing that the Labor Party has remained so strong and so united since that adversity in March. Slowly but surely, with the support of our party members and our supporters, we are rebuilding the party and we look forward to the challenges ahead.

I would have to acknowledge that we have taken some knocks on legislation in the Senate. I admit that the passage of the Telstra bill was a blow. It was a blow not only to the Labor Party and our membership, but to the whole Australian community. But we are proud of our efforts in relation to our parliamentary struggle on that bill. We fought long and we fought hard to secure a very important amendment to the Telstra bill. The truth is that we did not have the numbers and we did not have the pork, but we fought it out, as we have on all the legislation that has come before the chamber, every inch of the way.

I want to thank, very sincerely, the deputy leader, Senator Nick Sherry, who has done such an outstanding job in this parliament, my frontbench colleagues, the Manager of Opposition Business, Senator Carr, the whips, and all my friends and colleagues in the parliamentary Labor Party. The cooperation and support that I have had from them as leader is something that I have very much appreciated. The opposition in the chamber has put in a great team effort since the election, and I think that is a credit to each and every one of my colleagues, who have really put their shoulder to the grindstone. For my part, I sincerely appreciate it and acknowledge it.

BREAK.PARA: I think we have made an effective team here in the Senate. We have been able to keep the government more than on their toes in this place. We have already got a couple of ministerial scalps in the Senate hanging off the belt; we have got a series of members of the executive in the Senate, ministers in the Senate, who I think we have been able to expose and humiliate. It has been a very weak performance, in fact, from a very weak government team. So my sincere thanks go to all of my colleagues.

I also want to place on record Labor senators' appreciation of the tremendous efforts of the leader of the parliamentary Labor Party, Kim Beazley. It has been an outstanding performance in very difficult circumstances. I say to Kim and his team—Gareth Evans, the deputy leader, and Simon Crean, the Manager of Opposition Business in the House of Representatives—that we thank them for their support, friendship and, of course, leadership.

I also want to place on record the support that we on this side of the chamber have received from our staff. It has been absolutely fantastic. My personal thanks go to all the opposition staffers, be they staffers of frontbenchers or backbenchers in this place. It is true to say that none of us would have been able to operate without the support and the enthusiasm of members of our staff, and we sincerely appreciate that. They, too, have adapted extremely well to new circumstances, to difficult circumstances, and I think they have done wonders with their limited resources.

I certainly want to say a particular word of appreciation and thanks to my own staff, who have worked so fantastically and have been so dedicated throughout the life of the parliament. I appreciate it very much. We would not have been able to be anywhere near as effective an opposition—or, in my case, as effective an opposition leader—without their support. I appreciate it very much. I want to pay tribute to their efforts tonight in this valedictory speech.

I say to senators from other non‐government parties and to government senators, obviously, these spring sittings have been a long session for us all. I join with the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill) in wishing all of you a happy Christmas, a successful new year, and I hope that all senators in the chamber and all those who work in Parliament House and work with us all have an opportunity of having a well deserved rest with their families and friends over Christmas.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some observations at this time. I think all 76 of us would feel particularly humble that there are so many people in this building who work so hard and with such dedication to enable us to function as we do in this chamber. It is not my intention tonight to refer to all of them, but I do want to refer to three who will not be part of the functioning of the parliament when we next come back here.

INTERJECT.PARA: Most significantly of all, of course, I refer to Malcolm McGregor from Hansard. I am pleased that you are present at this time, Malcolm. There is a great deal that can be said about anyone who has given 40 years of public service, almost 30 of them to this parliament. I shall not embarrass Malcolm by canvassing the whole of his career, but there are some things that ought to be said.

Having completed his education, he became a court shorthand reporter in the New South Wales court system and became part of the Hansard staff of the federal parliament in 1967, the third longest serving officer of the current Hansard staff, and on the Monday before last he completed 40 years of public service.

When Malcolm joined Hansard, Harold Holt was Prime Minister, John McEwen was the Deputy Prime Minister, Senator Denham Henty was the Leader of the Government in this chamber, Senator Lionel Murphy was Leader of the Opposition and Senator Sir Alister McMullin was the President.

Malcolm's career through the ranks of Hansard has been steady and consistent, with the sort of commitment that he has always given to the parliament, adjusting from the very early days of very much pencil and notebook, to the highly mechanised system that we have here today.

Nine presidents, eight speakers of the House of Representatives, nine prime ministers—it is an impressive record. Hansard has been very much part of Malcolm's life, along with the other activities that went with it—parliamentary committees, premiers conferences, ministerial bodies such as CHOGM and conferences of that nature.

There would be many highlights and anecdotes, if he was prepared to share them with us. I understand that in the 1970s, there was an occasion in the old Parliament House when the electricity failed and the chamber was plunged into darkness. To assist senators to leave the chamber, matches were struck and cigarette lighters were lit. I do not know what we would do today, now that nobody smokes. But in those days, it was possible to provide a little light by this means. At the time, Senator Gordon Davidson was addressing the chamber. Plunged into darkness, but with the assistance of cigarette lighters, it was possible for Senator Davidson to observe that Hansard was still at its post, so to speak. In other words, Malcolm was at the Hansard table. So Senator Davidson said, `Well, Hansard is still here, so I shall continue my remarks.' I understand Malcolm's response at the time was not reported in Hansard, but it was to the effect that in darkness it was not really easy to record what anybody was saying.

Life at Narooma will indeed be pleasant and I hope the fish are waiting for you, Malcolm, when you get there. I hope that you will continue to enjoy golf at Royal Canberra Golf Club and improve your handicap and enjoy being a part of this community. As a non‐working person I hope that you will not see this hour of the night very often, unless it is a very good party and something worth while.

The Rabbitohs perhaps will climb up a bit as time passes but the Raiders will still be there. I am sure that, between the two of them, you will have a football team you can enjoy watching.Quite simply, from all of us, thank you for your dedication. The parliament depends upon people like you. We are very indebted to you for what you have given to us over so many years.
Ralph Bain from the ABC retires today. I do not think he is here tonight. I cannot see his silvery locks behind the window. He has given a great deal of service to this parliament.

Hamish Mitchell from the gardening service retires to go to another job in Melbourne. He has been very much a part of the development of the grounds and gardens of this building, which are splendid. In recent times, he has been involved with allowing the public in to see the gardens. What he has done for the President's courtyard in the last few months is certainly magnificent. His career is going extremely well. Because of that, he has been enticed to Victoria to a good job down there. Hamish will be missed, and I am sure all of us wish him well.

I give my thanks to all occupants of the building for what they have contributed this year. I wish them a happy Christmas and an opportunity to recover from this session, as I hope we all will, and return next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to make a lengthy contribution. But, since I have imposed such discipline on coalition senators, I will truncate my speech as many of them have done. Could I firstly congratulate you, Madam President, on your new role in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a time for some valedictory remarks. We have had a number of senators leaving us during the past few months but we have also had a large troupe of new people join us. In an entirely non‐partisan way and having entered into debate with them during the workplace relations bill, I think that all of them—and there are too many to name—have slotted into the Senate very well. I guess it is very much jumping in at the deep end with a sitting the length of this one.

Could I also say that I wish my close friend and colleague Senator Crane a very brief convalescence and hope to see him back with us on 4 February. I hope that he enjoys a very restful summer and good health soon.

BREAK.PARA: For those who like statistics, the Senate has had a very busy year. We actually sat on 71 days of this year—probably 71 and a bit now—which was only seven days less than 1995, and that is quite a record for an election year. The Senate, when this speech was written, had passed 83 bills. It might have gone up to 90‐odd by tonight. That was quite considerably less than 1995 when we passed over 183 bills. There were reasons for that. It was an historic year. We had two of the longest debates in Senate history. The workplace relations bill was the second longest debate in Australian parliamentary history and the Telstra bill took quite a long time as well.

From the point of view of being the Manager of Government Business, in government legislation time in 1996 we averaged about 10 hours and 42 minutes per week, which was about an hour or so less than the averages for the previous two years, but we achieved about half the amount of bills being passed through the chamber. People should not be too concerned about that because I do not think there is a great correlation between the amount of legislation we pass and the wellbeing of the good citizens of Australia.

Can I thank in some detail the people who work in the building and to whom you, Madam President, have paid special attention. Firstly, Senator Panizza, Senator Calvert, Senator Evans and Senator Conroy, the whips and their staff. Indeed, those of us who were involved in those leaders' and whips' meetings, including Senator Harradine, Senator Colston, the Green senators—Dee Margetts and Bob Brown—Vicky Bourne and Cheryl Kernot, Senator Faulkner and Senator Chris Evans, who through long discussions, often coming from opposite points of view and through cooperation and consensus that were often hard fought and hard gained, have been able to make this place work. We achieved the legislation this last week through cooperation from all senators, and I have learnt in this job that you need the cooperation of everybody in this place to make things work. So I thank, particularly, the whips and their staff.

I thank the clerks, Harry Evans, Anne Lynch, Rosemary Laing, Cleaver Elliott and the others, who are an absolutely pivotal part of this place. They give us guidance and, at short notice, under enormous stress—at least to us anyway—give incredibly outstanding and impartial advice that makes this place tick.

To the parliamentary counsel who turn our political ideas and policies into a legislative form, who turn our often handwritten scribbled amendments into some sort of legal translation, particularly Hilary Penfold and her staff, I extend my thanks for the outstanding job they do.

The people in the Table Office, working in extremely cramped quarters, John Vander Wyk, Angie and Bev, who have provided so much crucial support to all of the Senate, have done an outstanding job and deserve a very good Christmas holiday.

The Parliamentary Liaison Office, which Senator Faulkner referred to: Nhan Vo Van has served me very well in helping me come to grips with this new job of managing government business and has provided excellent advice and guidance at a time when I needed it. Gail Vansemer has jumped very much into the deep end of this job in one of the busiest sessions in Senate history. She arrived at the most hectic time and was dropped in the deep end. But Gail's performance over the last few weeks certainly would do Kieran Perkins, another marathon swimmer, proud. The parliamentary library provided us with all the support. The Senate committee staff have had a very busy session.

I would also mention all of the staff in our Senate offices who perform miracles and put up with all of our funny ways; the procedure office; parliamentary printing; Hansard, particularly you, Malcolm, here on your last evening before your retirement; the Sound and Vision Office; PISO; all of the attendants who are always so cheerful to us, regardless of what we get up to; Senate transport, Bruce and Kearen, who always look after us so very well; and all of the drivers, the caterers and the cleaners who have had to put up with so much in these last few months—a couple of attacks of Bogong moths and all of that—in keeping the place looking tidy; the maintenance workers; the electricians; the plumbers; and the painters. Every one of them, as has been said in previous contributions, in their own way make a great contribution to ensuring one of the greatest democratic institutions on planet earth ticks from day to day.

We have a large agenda which remains unaddressed in the Senate—we face a huge job. We look forward to returning to try to pass some of that legislation through this place. I conclude by again repeating my thanks to the Hansard staff who have to get in before all of us and leave long after us. They have to grapple with our torture of the English language and try to decipher many almost inaudible interjections and render them intelligible for the record. I will now reward the Hansard staff by ceasing my remarks at this point and wish everybody in the building a very merry Christmas, particularly the families that we leave behind, the families of all the staff in this building that we leave behind, particularly the families of senators. I wish you well for the festive season and a safe journey home and a very happy, successful and healthy new year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take a very brief time to record my thanks to the people we have worked with and who have served the needs of all the senators, and to wish my colleagues on both sides of the chamber all the best for Christmas, as the day has arrived at 2.50 in the morning that we have all been looking forward to for the last two weeks. It has slowly crawled around to the time where we can all go back to the pleasures of our family—the younger ones like Senator Campbell, to his young children, and my colleague on the right, to his grandchildren and children as they gather at Christmas around the table. I would like to put on record my appreciation to Senator Hill. We have gone through some difficult issues over the last couple of days but nevertheless we have been calm and cool on these and we have come out of it very well.

SPEECH.PARA: While I have the opportunity, let me say that one of my staff, who has been working with me for 4½ years, leaves me in another week or two to go to America to get married. I would like to wish Tracey Arnison all the best as she goes over there and seeks a new life and best wishes to my other staff—Prue Regan, Joanne Newbery and Ana Bisset—who have looked after me and have been very good in standing up and getting everything ready that we need. Finally, Madam President, can I just leave you this message: Jesus is the reason for the season.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened carefully to those who have spoken before me during this adjournment debate and they have covered everybody in their thanks—I will not repeat that except for a heartfelt thanks to all those mentioned specifically by previous speakers. I also would like to wish Ralph Bain and Malcolm McGregor the very best. I don't know how Malcolm hasn't gone right up the wall after 30 years of reporting parliament—and he hardly has a grey hair in his head, which is also quite remarkable. I do thank you Malcolm for what you have done over the years and I must say that Dennis Strangman, a former staffer of mine, who was in the old building for quite a large number of years and whom you knew well, had the greatest of respect for your professionalism and your ability to write down what is said the way it is said and to have it come out grammatically correct, somehow. All the very best to you and your family for Christmas and for the future.

SPEECH.PARA: This Senate has been preoccupied with economic issues—as indeed has the parliament—over the last few months. This has taken a great deal of concentration, but it is hardly uplifting stuff. Tuesday of this week was a beautiful day as I walked towards the front entrance. I generally get in before the press get out there but I didn't on Tuesday morning—I was walking around and enjoying the place. I said to the journalist, `It's a wonderful day and I was there for that historic moment at 1.30 this morning in the House of Representatives.' The House of Representatives passed a bill which I think is absolutely fundamental to the preservation of society, indeed civilisation.

BREAK.PARA: I look forward to having such a measure come before this chamber because it makes an enormous change from an over‐concentration on economic matters, important though they are. It is a life and death issue and I think it will dignify this chamber to have such a measure considered. It was, indeed, an honour for me to be present during that historic moment.

I am not sure that we have mentioned the committees of this Senate in our thanks tonight but I certainly as an Independent do appreciate the work of the committees. I might just say in passing that they distil material, which is very handy for me. All in all, I just wish everybody the very best for Christmas, and a happy and a successful New Year. Thank you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address an issue in a recent publication by Treasury to the Wallis inquiry into the financial system. That submission recommends that, in deregulating the superannuation industry, the responsibility for supervising the management of superannuation savings should actually fall on the investor. In essence, they are saying `caveat emptor'. The effect of their proposal, they argue, is that investors, who under liberalisation will shop around for the fund or funds which best suit them, will shy away from poorly managed funds and support those that act with integrity and produce the best outcome. Consequently, those which do not measure up to the investors' expectation of prudential supervision will actually fall by the wayside.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two significant flaws in this particular argument. Firstly, superannuation funds are not collective investments which come under the supervision of the ASC. Collective investments are managed on a `best endeavour' basis. If the manager does not perform then investors vote with their feet, as Mr George Pooley, Commissioner of the ISC, said recently. But investors in superannuation funds would not have the protection of the ASC.

Secondly, investors in superannuation funds must invest; they do not have the choice of not investing at all. The principle of caveat emptor assumes that the buyer—in this case the buyer of a superannuation package—need not buy at all. But people are required by law to purchase superannuation. Superannuation funds will survive because the compulsory nature of superannuation guarantees their survival.

Thirdly, Australians are increasingly treating superannuation as their savings for the years following retirement and for their senior years. In assuming that it is a buffer against poverty in the future, they are treating it like a bank savings account. When such reliance is placed on superannuation savings, investors should be entitled to a properly supervised institution.

Fourthly, the ISC's recent reviews of superannuation funds have brought to light that some funds which are subject to supervision have some serious shortcomings in their prudential management. Commissioner Pooley explained to a conference in Sydney in September this year that the ISC, when undertaking its reviews, found that only 45 per cent of all funds either complied with the SIS legislation or had only minor technical breaches. He reported that the main problems were with trustees understanding neither their responsibilities nor the requirements of SIS, and that there were inadequate financial controls.

Trustees can be sued if they act wilfully or recklessly to the detriment of the members of the fund. Mr Pooley said a handful of investors would legitimately be able to sue their trustees in such circumstances. Examples were where, for instance, the trustee board had delegated virtually all of its powers to an unrepresentative executive committee. In another case, an employee who had a key role in a fund's financial affairs defrauded the company, its clients and the fund for many years. If this happens in supervised funds, how much grater is the opportunity for mismanagement of unsupervised funds?

It is often too late for investors to move their funds elsewhere by the time they become aware of such malpractices. People in their senior years of life should not be subjected to unnecessary worry about whether they can trust the managers of their savings. Many are at the mercy of the trustees of their funds. Their livelihoods should not be prejudiced in this way.

Fifthly, the likelihood that trustees would provide adequate disclosure in an unsupervised regime is extremely questionable. Mr Pooley, in the Australian of Wednesday, 11 December, is quoted as saying that half the funds the ISC looked at are making inadequate disclosures. The ISC's response to the Wallis inquiry discussion paper gives details of trustees who have failed to give members correct information about their fund. It also explains how trustees have failed to ensure that their fund was properly administered and how they have failed to ensure the prudent investment of their assets. He cites such breaches. As my time is brief, I wonder whether I could have the leave of the Senate to incorporate the remainder of my speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
failure to disclose parties receiving fees
lack of service agreements with fund managers and administrators
significant delays in paying benefits
failure to prepare an annual report
failure to arrange an external audit
accounts in the wrong names
benefits paid to wrong accounts
lack of an investment strategy
poor documentation of transactions
uncontrolled derivatives trading
I could go on.

Nevertheless, if these funds were under no prudential supervision the opportunity for defrauding investors would be even greater. Mr Pooley himself says that the structure does offer protection if you make it work. Treasury seems to fear that the trustee system places the government under some moral obligation to bail out fund members who lose their money. If this is the case, the government will have a greater interest in ensuring the trustee system does work so that the government does not have to bail them out.

Liberalisation/deregulation and supervision need not be mutually exclusive. In fact, as Mr Pooley says, the more you deregulate the better the prudential supervision needs to be. "Prudential supervision is aimed at stability; it encourages financial institutions to remain solvent and investment schemes to be run well. Liberality and consistency in the rules improve efficiency by fostering competition and innovation in the marketplace." [ISC Commission Submission to the Inquiry into the Financial System, Executive Summary, Page (iv).]

I therefore believe, Madam President, that at the same time as Australians are given more choice in the way they invest their superannuation funds adequate prudential supervision of those funds must be instituted. Failure to institute suitable prudential supervision will jeopardise the savings of thousands of Australians, and cause unnecessary distress. In the long term those worse affected will fall back on the taxpayer for their livelihood.

As I finished writing this speech I received a copy of the most recent ISC media release in which Mr Pooley restated what he had said in a supplementary submission to the inquiry: "We see no alternative to `hands on ` prudential supervision of the insurance and superannuation industries.
I thank the Senate.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United Nations Decade for Human Rights Education

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Senator Margetts

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 24 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the statement of the World Conference on Human Rights held in Vienna in June 1993 that human rights education, training and public information are essential for the promotion and achievement of harmonious relations among communities and for fostering mutual understanding, tolerance and peace, and the fact that, as a consequence, the United Nations General Assembly in its resolution 49/194 proclaimed the years 1995‐2004 as the United Nations Decade for Human Rights Education:
(1) What steps have been taken by the Australian Government and each of its agencies to implement each of the five objectives and eight components of the decade.

(2) Which events, activities, projects and programs that could be and/or were regarded as coming within the broad scope of human rights education have been cancelled, are threatened, or are unlikely to proceed as a result of the economic and staffing cutbacks that the Howard Government has initiated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: With respect to the objectives and components of the Decade Plan of Action, there are a variety of activities underway in Australia and, through the aid program, in our region aimed at raising awareness and understanding of human rights. These take place in the government and non‐government sectors and are part of Australia's overall efforts to promote and protect human rights.
The following information has been provided by Commonwealth departments in respect of their human rights education activities:
Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in January 1996 initiated action at the Federal level to develop an Australian program of action for the Decade of Human Rights Education. A Working Group of Commonwealth agencies was convened to assess what is currently being done and identify areas that require development. The first step involves identifying and collating materials, courses, programs and curricula which are currently in use or available in Australia. The next step is the development of a strategy by HREOC for the implementation of the Decade's main objectives.

DFAT and AusAID have commenced joint training programs for staff on human rights issues to foster greater knowledge about the role of human rights in foreign policy and development cooperation. Human rights training for DFAT and AusAID officers was introduced in a pilot form in 1994 in recognition that human rights knowledge and expertise cannot be confined to officers working directly on human rights matters but are an important skill for all officers including those on overseas postings. Efforts in 1995 were concentrated on using the experience developed in the pilot course to design a flexible course for officials of other Government Departments . The aim of the revised course is to provide officers with a sound understanding and awareness of human rights issues and government policy in this area.

The new Human Rights Training Course was launched on 22‐23 February 1996. The course covers a range of issues including the nature and history of human rights; human rights and Australian foreign policy; the UN human rights system; and the domestic aspects of human rights including the rights of indigenous peoples. It is expected the course will be offered at least four times a year.

Australia, through the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has participated in workshops organised by the Commonwealth Secretariat on human rights education. The first, held in Oxford in 1995, was attended by participants from 36 Commonwealth countries, the second, held in Port Vila from 1‐5 July, involved participants from twelve Commonwealth Pacific countries.

Human rights related assistance provided by AusAID and under the Human Rights Fund (previously administered by DFAT) has been directed toward human rights education. Activities include legal literacy, training for the judiciary and officials, and awareness raising on children's rights. Countries involved include Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Cambodia, Vietnam, Bangladesh and Solomon Islands.

Through AusAID, the Government approved funding of approximately $20,000 for the Asia‐Pacific Workshop of Human Rights Educators held in Sydney from 22 to 25 August. This workshop was jointly sponsored by the University of New South Wales' Australian Human Rights Information Centre (AHRIC) and the Diplomacy Training Program (DTP—a body based at the University of NSW that promotes human rights education for Asia‐Pacific NGOs). It was organised with the assistance of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. The workshop brought together prominent NGO representatives from many Asia‐Pacific countries, including India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, Thailand and the Philippines, as well as Australian practitioners, to discuss strategies for the UN Decade in the region.
Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission

Australia's Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (HREOC) (established in 1986) is charged with increasing the understanding, acceptance and observance of human rights in Australia and has a mandate to carry our research and education programs.

HREOC has developed training packages, e.g., on discrimination in employment for private sector managers, and produces a range of publications on human rights and discrimination. Australia's Federal Human Rights Commissioner (one of six full time HREOC Commissioners) has highlighted the need to develop an awareness and understanding of "rights" in Australia which would build on the well‐established awareness of a democratic civil tradition. A more detailed summary of the Commission's education activities is attached.
Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

(1) Following the recommendations contained in the report of the Civics Expert Group Whereas the People in 1994, a four year Civics and Citizenship Education Program was established in 1995, with $20 million committed for the formal education sectors. The overall aim of the Civics and Citizenship Education Program was to help Australians develop the basic knowledge, skills and attitudes they need to engage effectively in civic life.

The Government believes that to be effective, the program must also develop knowledge of basic democratic values and attitudes, such as tolerance and respect for individual and human rights. The Program and associated curriculum materials will reflect this commitment.
(2) While the Government is continuing to fund the Civics and Citizenship Education Program, its details are currently under review.

(1) Within DSS the most significant activity undertaken relevant to human rights education is its implementation of the Department's Access and Equity Blueprint for Continuous Improvement. This is a facet of human rights education which ensures service providers within DSS are trained to assist customers from diverse cultural and linguistic backgrounds (including Indigenous Australians) in a culturally appropriate way. This is expressed concretely through the use of specialist staff and targeted services and includes provision of language services and multilingual publications. In these ways DSS is ensuring that customers are not disadvantaged by reason of their cultural backgrounds. For example, during the 1995‐96 financial year the Department provided interpreter services to 196,695 customers and its Multilingual Telephone Service Centres handled 366,000 calls in 53 different languages.

Details of staff education and training related to human rights legislation and issues together with information about specific services responding to the needs of customers from diverse cultural and linguistic backgrounds are attached.
(2) The Department of Social Security advises that none of the human rights education activities undertaken by that Department have been cancelled or have been otherwise adversely affected.
Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs

(1) DIMA has been involved with a number of activities associated with human rights issues. In 1995 the (former) Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs established a Secretariat to coordinate a range of activities designed to promote the goals of the International Year of Tolerance. The activities were directed to raise awareness of our achievements and to take pride in them, to recognise the social and economic advantages of our diversity, to take stock of our situation and to commit ourselves to becoming an even more tolerant Australia.

The Community Relations Agenda (CRA) Grants Program has funded a range of projects designed to help community groups relate better to one another and to foster greater tolerance and harmony. Forty‐eight grants totalling $2.24 million were awarded under the CRA Grants Program in March 1995 for a variety of innovative projects in the areas of youth, local government, law/police, media, the arts, culture and sport. Funded projects have varied widely in terms of content, approach and duration. The CRA grants were a "once‐only" event and all grants will have expired by 30 June 1997.

DIMA is funding the Refugee Council of Australia to carry out a number of projects to assist with the settlement of the Humanitarian Program entrants in Australia. One of these is to develop and implement strategies for encouraging, in the electronic media, recognition of the situation of Humanitarian Program entrants and their value to the Australian community. Another is to develop procedural guidelines and a training module for case managers and administrative staff in dealing with protection visa applicants with special needs, such as torture/trauma victims, applicants with psychological/physiological disabilities/difficulties, applicants who specify gender‐based persecution, and unaccompanied minors.

In the August 1996 Budget the Government announced funding for an anti‐racism education campaign, to be managed through the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. A sum of $5 million has been made available in 1996‐97. The possibility of further funding will be considered in the 1997‐98 budget context, following a review of the campaign's progress. The Government recognises that racism continues to be an underlying concern in Australia, and supports education as a viable long‐term strategy to reduce racism. The Government considers racism to be unacceptable and un‐Australian and will work to ensure that Australians are not subject to racism and are able to participate as full members of the Australian community. The campaign will be two‐pronged, incorporating a public awareness element and community education projects. The campaign will focus on schools, workplaces, sporting organisations and will involve the whole Australian community.
(1) The Attorney General's Department advises that the following projects are currently underway or have been completed:
SCAG Working Group on Human Rights

A Standing Committee of Attorneys‐General (SCAG) Working Group on Human Rights was established in 1995. The Working Group is considering ways to harmonise Commonwealth and State human rights and anti‐discrimination legislation and ways to facilitate cooperation with States in preparing Australia's treaty body reports and response to communications to these bodies by individuals.

In 1995, the Government announced that it would establish a new Law Revision Unit within the Office of Parliamentary Counsel to rewrite legislation that has been identified as needing simplification. It will simplify and consolidate Commonwealth human rights legislation.
Domestic human rights forum for non‐government organisations

The Government is in the process of establishing a regular domestic forum for non‐government organisations to exchange information and discuss domestic human rights issues and developments. It is proposed that the first forum be held in late 1996.
National Action Plan on human rights

In March 1994, Australia presented its National Action Plan on human rights at the United Nations Commission on Human Rights held in Geneva. It has been updated every year with a major revision to be undertaken every five years.

The National Action Plan was the result of an Australian initiative at the World Conference on Human Rights in June 1993. The then Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Evans, suggested that States prepare National Action Plans as a means by which they could, in a practical way, improve their observance of human rights standards. The proposal was endorsed by the World Conference and was one of the recommendations contained in the Vienna Declaration adopted by the Conference.

In June 1995 the Attorney‐General's Department made a seed grant of $50,000 to the Australian Human Rights Information Centre at the University of New South Wales to assist in the establishment of a national human rights database and documentation centre. A home page was established on the Internet on 12 February 1996.
Gender awareness project for the judiciary

The Australian Institute for Judicial Administration (AIJA) was provided with funding to develop gender awareness programs for the judiciary. A pilot program for approximately 140 participants was held in Victoria in October 1995. The Department is awaiting the results of an evaluation questionnaire issued to delegates by the AIJA.
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural awareness

In response to Recommendation 96 of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, a series of pilot cultural awareness programs for the Australian judiciary were run under the auspices of the Australian Institute for Judicial Administration. Programs have been held in Western Australia, Queensland, South Australia and the Northern Territory. All States and Territories will have conducted programs by June 1997.
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander language interpreters

In response to Recommendations 99 and 100 of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, the Attorney‐General's Department has developed pilot programs to train Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people as interpreters in the legal environment. Programs have been conducted in South Australia, Western Australia, Queensland and the Northern Territory. A total of 38 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have attained NAATI para‐professional accreditation as legal interpreters.
(2) There have been no discontinued projects.
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission
(1) ATSIC's contribution to the Decade has been the development of an information kit on the Draft Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples. This kit contains:

PARA.TAB: a plain language version of the Draft Declaration;
2 information sheets on the United Nations Human Rights structure and the World's Indigenous Peoples;
a detailed analysis of the Draft Declaration; and
a detailed history of the development of the Draft Declaration through the UN (yet to be printed).

ANSWER.PARA: The kit is aimed at both indigenous and non‐indigenous Australians as an educational tool about the Draft Declaration, indigenous rights issues, and the United Nations human rights machinery. It was launched by the Chairperson of ATSIC, Miss Lois O'Donoghue, at Old Parliament House on Monday 16 September 1996.

The kit is being sent to 2000 indigenous organisations Australia‐wide and other human rights organisations. The Plain Language version of the Draft Declaration will also be shortly available to all the community, both national and international, on the Internet.
Department of Health and Family Services

(1) The Department broadly incorporates human rights issues into its training, development and recruitment processes through its Equal Employment Opportunity Plan. The Plan includes specific strategies and activities relating to gender equity and addresses the issues relating to staff from non‐English speaking background, staff with a disability and indigenous staff.
The Decade's Plan of Action has relevance for the Office for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health Services (OATSIHS) in two areas:

PARA.TAB: initiatives to improve access for Aboriginal and Torres Strait islander people to culturally appropriate mainstream health services through agreements currently being negotiated between the Federal Government and State/Territory governments; and

support for culturally appropriate programs (e.g., in mental health services for indigenous communities) and training initiatives (e.g., a training relief scheme for Aboriginal health services and cultural awareness programs for staff working in the health care field);
hearing initiatives to prevent hearing loss in young children—this is particularly relevant to their education and life outcomes; and
strategies to promote successful Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander projects and their initiators.

The Australian Defence Force incorporates training in human rights law and practice into the normal legal training given to its personnel. The approach to education and training is set in the context of a society committed to the rule of law. This training comprises (a) normal garrison training courses which include general human rights issues, and (b) specific pre‐deployment training. Prior to any deployment to either exercises or actual operations, there is specific pre‐deployment education and training which supplements and builds on the normal garrison training. Training varies in duration and content . Areas covered include relevant international law (including International Humanitarian Law as it applies both in armed conflict and at other times), the law and customs in countries of deployment, rights of all persons, including civilians, to due process (especially with respect to detention) and military discipline. The training deals with human rights concepts as opposed to the detailed content of human rights law. In summary, there is general garrison training supplemented, for deploying personnel, with more detailed training which allows a greater focus on the specific problems and issues likely to face those personnel on the specific deployment.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The AFP plays a role in relation to human rights education and training for police services internationally. Under the auspices of AusAID, the AFP maintained police training advisers in Vanuatu and the Solomon Islands for six years. A major component of their role was to raise the status of women in the local police services through education and training. In 1994, the first Melanesian Police Women's Forum was held with women attending from Australia, Papua New Guinea, the Solomon Islands, Vanuatu and Fiji.

The ACT Sexual Assault Unit has provided training on sexual assault aimed at police services over a number of years. In 1996, this unit provided trainers to Thailand and the Philippines. The workshops concentrated on the skills required to deal with victims of paedophilia and other sexual abuse. Presented by experienced Australian policewomen, workshops also ensured that participants appreciate that it is increasingly common for women to play investigative roles in other parts of the world.

The AFP is developing a training module on human rights for presentation in other countries. This module is being developed in conjunction with the Australian National University and is the subject of a Master's degree by an AFP officer.
The AFP also provides training to its personnel on several fronts which relate to human rights, both within the Australian and international contexts:

PARA.TAB: arising from the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, all personnel undergo two days cross cultural awareness training. It is expected that all personnel will have completed a course by the end of the 1996/97 financial year

the AFP is represented on the National Police Ethnic Advisory Bureau which provides advice and research on police/ethnic relations within Australia. One of its recent projects was a train the trainer course for police services. The AFP participated and is now developing inclusion of cross‐cultural awareness into the training program as an integral component of education courses and as basic knowledge of trainers and presenters

education and awareness is a key outcome of the AFP's Equity and Diversity Program 1996‐2000. Strategies include seminars for managers and personnel and trained contact officers in each region who can provide advice on discrimination and other equity issues. AFP publications and the internal Netscape are also used to develop awareness among AFP personnel

prior to postings in relation to the AFP's international peace keeping role, police officers are given briefings on human rights in general and within the relevant region as part of their pre‐embarkation induction. One officer with the contingent which is due to leave for Cyprus in late October, is a united Nations recognised trainer in human rights.

ANSWER.PARA: (2) AFP has not had to cancel any scheduled programs that encompass human rights education.
