(1) Within DSS the most significant activity undertaken relevant to human rights education is its implementation of the Department's Access and Equity Blueprint for Continuous Improvement . This is a facet of human rights education which ensures service providers within DSS are trained to assist customers from diverse cultural and linguistic backgrounds (including Indigenous Australians) in a culturally appropriate way. This is expressed concretely through the use of specialist staff and targeted services and includes provision of language services and multilingual publications. In these ways DSS is ensuring that customers are not disadvantaged by reason of their cultural backgrounds. For example, during the 1995‐96 financial year the Department provided interpreter services to 196,695 customers and its Multilingual Telephone Service Centres handled 366,000 calls in 53 different languages.

Details of staff education and training related to human rights legislation and issues together with information about specific services responding to the needs of customers from diverse cultural and linguistic backgrounds are attached.
(2) The Department of Social Security advises that none of the human rights education activities undertaken by that Department have been cancelled or have been otherwise adversely affected.
Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs

(1) DIMA has been involved with a number of activities associated with human rights issues. In 1995 the (former) Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs established a Secretariat to coordinate a range of activities designed to promote the goals of the International Year of Tolerance. The activities were directed to raise awareness of our achievements and to take pride in them, to recognise the social and economic advantages of our diversity, to take stock of our situation and to commit ourselves to becoming an even more tolerant Australia.

The Community Relations Agenda (CRA) Grants Program has funded a range of projects designed to help community groups relate better to one another and to foster greater tolerance and harmony. Forty‐eight grants totalling $2.24 million were awarded under the CRA Grants Program in March 1995 for a variety of innovative projects in the areas of youth, local government, law/police, media, the arts, culture and sport. Funded projects have varied widely in terms of content, approach and duration. The CRA grants were a "once‐only" event and all grants will have expired by 30 June 1997.

DIMA is funding the Refugee Council of Australia to carry out a number of projects to assist with the settlement of the Humanitarian Program entrants in Australia. One of these is to develop and implement strategies for encouraging, in the electronic media, recognition of the situation of Humanitarian Program entrants and their value to the Australian community. Another is to develop procedural guidelines and a training module for case managers and administrative staff in dealing with protection visa applicants with special needs, such as torture/trauma victims, applicants with psychological/physiological disabilities/difficulties, applicants who specify gender‐based persecution, and unaccompanied minors.

In the August 1996 Budget the Government announced funding for an anti‐racism education campaign, to be managed through the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. A sum of $5 million has been made available in 1996‐97. The possibility of further funding will be considered in the 1997‐98 budget context, following a review of the campaign's progress. The Government recognises that racism continues to be an underlying concern in Australia, and supports education as a viable long‐term strategy to reduce racism. The Government considers racism to be unacceptable and un‐Australian and will work to ensure that Australians are not subject to racism and are able to participate as full members of the Australian community. The campaign will be two‐pronged, incorporating a public awareness element and community education projects. The campaign will focus on schools, workplaces, sporting organisations and will involve the whole Australian community.
(1) The Attorney General's Department advises that the following projects are currently underway or have been completed:
SCAG Working Group on Human Rights

A Standing Committee of Attorneys‐General (SCAG) Working Group on Human Rights was established in 1995. The Working Group is considering ways to harmonise Commonwealth and State human rights and anti‐discrimination legislation and ways to facilitate cooperation with States in preparing Australia's treaty body reports and response to communications to these bodies by individuals.

In 1995, the Government announced that it would establish a new Law Revision Unit within the Office of Parliamentary Counsel to rewrite legislation that has been identified as needing simplification. It will simplify and consolidate Commonwealth human rights legislation.
Domestic human rights forum for non‐government organisations

The Government is in the process of establishing a regular domestic forum for non‐government organisations to exchange information and discuss domestic human rights issues and developments. It is proposed that the first forum be held in late 1996.
National Action Plan on human rights

In March 1994, Australia presented its National Action Plan on human rights at the United Nations Commission on Human Rights held in Geneva. It has been updated every year with a major revision to be undertaken every five years.

The National Action Plan was the result of an Australian initiative at the World Conference on Human Rights in June 1993. The then Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Evans, suggested that States prepare National Action Plans as a means by which they could, in a practical way, improve their observance of human rights standards. The proposal was endorsed by the World Conference and was one of the recommendations contained in the Vienna Declaration adopted by the Conference.

In June 1995 the Attorney‐General's Department made a seed grant of $50,000 to the Australian Human Rights Information Centre at the University of New South Wales to assist in the establishment of a national human rights database and documentation centre. A home page was established on the Internet on 12 February 1996.
Gender awareness project for the judiciary

The Australian Institute for Judicial Administration (AIJA) was provided with funding to develop gender awareness programs for the judiciary. A pilot program for approximately 140 participants was held in Victoria in October 1995. The Depart ment is awaiting the results of an evaluation questionnaire issued to delegates by the AIJA.
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural awareness

In response to Recommendation 96 of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, a series of pilot cultural awareness programs for the Australian judiciary were run under the auspices of the Australian Institute for Judicial Administration. Programs have been held in Western Australia, Queensland, South Australia and the Northern Territory. All States and Territories will have conducted programs by June 1997.
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander language interpreters

In response to Recommendations 99 and 100 of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, the Attorney‐General's Department has developed pilot programs to train Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people as interpreters in the legal environment. Programs have been conducted in South Australia, Western Australia, Queensland and the Northern Territory. A total of 38 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have attained NAATI para‐professional accreditation as legal interpreters.
(2) There have been no discontinued projects.
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission
(1) ATSIC's contribution to the Decade has been the development of an information kit on the Draft Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples. This kit contains:

PARA.TAB: a plain language version of the Draft Declaration;
2 information sheets on the United Nations Human Rights structure and the World's Indigenous Peoples;
a detailed analysis of the Draft Declaration; and
a detailed history of the development of the Draft Declaration through the UN (yet to be printed).

ANSWER.PARA: The kit is aimed at both indigenous and non‐indigenous Australians as an educational tool about the Draft Declaration, indigenous rights issues, and the United Nations human rights machinery. It was launched by the Chairperson of ATSIC, Miss Lois O'Donoghue, at Old Parliament House on Monday 16 September 1996.

The kit is being sent to 2000 indigenous organisations Australia‐wide and other human rights organisations. The Plain Language version of the Draft Declaration will also be shortly available to all the community, both national and international, on the Internet.
Department of Health and Family Services

(1) The Department broadly incorporates human rights issues into its training, development and recruitment processes through its Equal Employment Opportunity Plan. The Plan includes specific strategies and activities relating to gender equity and addresses the issues relating to staff from non‐English speaking background, staff with a disability and indigenous staff.
The Decade's Plan of Action has relevance for the Office for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health Services (OATSIHS) in two areas:

PARA.TAB: initiatives to improve access for Aboriginal and Torres Strait islander people to culturally appropriate mainstream health services through agreements currently being negotiated between the Federal Government and State/Territory governments; and

support for culturally appropriate programs (e.g., in mental health services for indigenous communities) and training initiatives (e.g., a training relief scheme for Aboriginal health services and cultural awareness programs for staff working in the health care field);
hearing initiatives to prevent hearing loss in young children—this is particularly relevant to their education and life outcomes; and
strategies to promote successful Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander projects and their initiators.

The Australian Defence Force incorporates training in human rights law and practice into the normal legal training given to its personnel. The approach to education and training is set in the context of a society committed to the rule of law. This training comprises (a) normal garrison training courses which include general human rights issues, and (b) specific pre‐deployment training. Prior to any deployment to either exercises or actual operations, there is specific pre‐deployment education and training which supplements and builds on the normal garrison training. Training varies in duration and content . Areas covered include relevant international law (including International Humanitarian Law as it applies both in armed conflict and at other times), the law and customs in countries of deployment, rights of all persons, including civilians, to due process (especially with respect to detention) and military discipline. The training deals with human rights concepts as opposed to the detailed content of human rights law. In summary, there is general garrison training supplemented, for deploying personnel, with more detailed training which allows a greater focus on the specific problems and issues likely to face those personnel on the specific deployment.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The AFP plays a role in relation to human rights education and training for police services internationally. Under the auspices of AusAID, the AFP maintained police training advisers in Vanuatu and the Solomon Islands for six years. A major component of their role was to raise the status of women in the local police services through education and training. In 1994, the first Melanesian Police Women's Forum was held with women attending from Australia, Papua New Guinea, the Solomon Islands, Vanuatu and Fiji.

The ACT Sexual Assault Unit has provided training on sexual assault aimed at police services over a number of years. In 1996, this unit provided trainers to Thailand and the Philippines. The workshops concentrated on the skills required to deal with victims of paedophilia and other sexual abuse. Presented by experienced Australian policewomen, workshops also ensured that participants appreciate that it is increasingly common for women to play investigative roles in other parts of the world.

The AFP is developing a training module on human rights for presentation in other countries. This module is being developed in conjunction with the Australian National University and is the subject of a Master's degree by an AFP officer.
The AFP also provides training to its personnel on several fronts which relate to human rights, both within the Australian and international contexts:

PARA.TAB: arising from the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, all personnel undergo two days cross cultural awareness training. It is expected that all personnel will have completed a course by the end of the 1996/97 financial year

the AFP is represented on the National Police Ethnic Advisory Bureau which provides advice and research on police/ethnic relations within Australia. One of its recent projects was a train the trainer course for police services. The AFP participated and is now developing inclusion of cross‐cultural awareness into the training program as an integral component of education courses and as basic knowledge of trainers and presenters

education and awareness is a key outcome of the AFP's Equity and Diversity Program 1996‐2000. Strategies include seminars for managers and personnel and trained contact officers in each region who can provide advice on discrimination and other equity issues. AFP publications and the internal Netscape are also used to develop awareness among AFP personnel

prior to postings in relation to the AFP's international peace keeping role, police officers are given briefings on human rights in general and within the relevant region as part of their pre‐embarkation induction. One officer with the contingent which is due to leave for Cyprus in late October, is a united Nations recognised trainer in human rights.

ANSWER.PARA: (2) AFP has not had to cancel any scheduled programs that encompass human rights education.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Senator Murray

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, upon notice, on 24 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the timetable for the implementation of the proposed changes to the export market development grants (EMDG) scheme.

(2) What advice is Austrade currently giving to potential claimants: is it giving claimants advice along the lines of the current legislation which does not expire until 30 June 1999, or is it giving advice along the lines of the Minister's statement during the 1996‐97 Budget.
(3) If it is giving advice along the lines of the proposed changes, under what authority is Austrade giving that advice.
(4) Does the Government consider the advice is sufficiently detailed for exporters to appreciate the full extent and impact of all the proposed changes.
(5) How can exporters plan overseas marketing activities if Austrade is not able to advise what assistance is available under the EMDG scheme.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The changes are planned to come into effect as soon as the necessary legislation receives Royal Assent in the first half of 1997. The measures will then be applied to all EMDG claims lodged after 30 June 1997, for the grant year starting on 1 July 1996 and subsequent grant years.

Drafting of the required amendments commenced in September 1996. It is expected that they will be completed by December 1996, and then released for public comment. They would then be introduced in the Autumn 1997 session of Parliament.
(2) Claimants requiring advice concerning the 1995‐96 grant year and grant years previous to it are being advised along the lines of the current legislation.

Claimants requiring advice concerning the 1996‐97 grant year are being advised along the lines of the Minister for Trade's statement during the 1996‐97 Budget, but are also being advised that the proposed legislation to implement the changes is subject to passage through Parliament.

For instance, in October 1996 Austrade released information brochures entitled Grants at a glance and An outline of the Export Market Development Grants scheme . These brochures set out the provisions of the scheme along the lines of the Minister for Trade's statement during the 1996‐97 budget. However, the following statement is displayed prominently on the front of both brochures:

PARA.TAB: "This brochure provides an explanation of the EMDG scheme with intended changes relating to expenditure from 1 July 1996 onwards. The proposed legislation to implement the changes is subject to passage through Parliament. Businesses seeking to claim for the 1995‐96 Grant Year should contact Austrade for eligibility criteria relating to that year".

ANSWER.PARA: Copies of these brochures have been provided to the honourable senator.

(3) Austrade is giving advice along the lines of the proposed changes consistent with the government's announced intention to legislate to implement those changes, and with an explicit qualification that the proposed legislation to implement the changes is subject to passage through Parliament.

(4) The written and verbal advice made available by Austrade explains the proposed changes in enough detail for exporters to appreciate their extent and impact. In some cases, the advice given is contingent on the precise definitions of the proposed changes, which will be available when the proposed legislation is released for public comment at the end of 1996.

(5) In most cases, Austrade is able to give full, detailed advice on what assistance is available under the EMDG scheme. This is done both verbally and through information brochures such as Grants at a glance and An outline of the Export Market Development Grants scheme . In some cases, the advice given is contingent on the precise definitions of the proposed changes, which will be available when the proposed legislation is released for public comment at the end of 1996.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Senator Robert Ray

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 6 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Apart from the question of the Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras, on how many occasions has the Minister written to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation on programming matters.
(2) What was the subject matter of the correspondence in each case.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: — The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Since I accepted responsibility for this portfolio I have responded to over 300 letters on ABC programs. I have personally referred about 100 of those letters to the Managing Director of the ABC so that he is aware of the concerns being expressed. In most other cases comment has been sought from the ABC by my Department to assist in responding to the letters. I now refer all programming letters to the ABC.

On six occasions, however, I have asked the ABC to either investigate specific program concerns, including graphic and explicit depictions of sexual activity and the possible condoning of illegal activities (for example, under age sex or growing cannabis), or to take concerns into account when making future programming decisions.
I have also sought advice from the ABC on several occasions where correspondents have queried the non‐inclusion of particular items/issues in programs aired on the ABC.

I have not sought in any of these cases to apply pressure to the ABC to take a particular course of action. The ABC is an independent body which makes its own decisions on programming matters. However, I have a responsibility to represent to the ABC the views of those who write to me and, where serious breaches of law or standards are alleged or where significant community concern is expressed, to seek appropriate advice from the ABC.
(2) The six program concerns about which I have written to the ABC, other than the broadcast of the Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras, are:

PARA.TAB: the ABC TV program "Maple Street Maleny", which allegedly focused in part on an illegal act, namely the shooting of Aborigines;
the ABC TV youth program "Recovery", which allegedly condoned sexual activity by under age children;
a program on the ABC's Triple J service which allegedly encouraged an illegal industry, namely the growth of cannabis crops;
the ABC TV program "King Street, Newtown", which contained a scene regarded by some viewers as unnecessarily graphic and tasteless;
several episodes of the Radio National program "Women Out Loud", in which potentially offensive material was broadcast in a timeslot regarded by some as inappropriate; and
language and program content on the ABC's Triple J service and its potential impact on Australia's youth.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Senator Bourne

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the date originally approved for completion of new submarine boat 01.
(2) On how many occasions, and by what degree, has this date been varied.
(3) As against the original Government approval and original contract targets, how many months behind schedule is the new submarine project.

(4) What action was taken by the former Government, and what action is planned by the present Government, to deal with the serious criticisms of the new Submarine Project Office contained in the Auditor‐General's Audit Report No. 22 of 1992‐93.
(5) What was the original approved project cost.
(6) What is the presently approved project cost, expressed in dollars comparable to prices in (5).
(7) Have any customer‐initiated contract variations been approved since the original contract entered into force; if so: (a) on what dates; (b) to what purpose; and (c) at what extra or reduced cost.

(8) What proportion of the increase in project cost since the original contract entered into force is due to: (a) customer‐initiated contract variations; (b) Consumer Price Index inflation; (c) exchange rate variations; (d) project delays; and (e) other reasons (please specify in each case).

(9) Is it a fact, as reported in Jane's Defence Weekly of 17 July 1996, that the Navy will provisionally accept HMAS Collins after the boat's software systems have run without a crash for 7 days; if not, what is the position.
(10) Are many RAN submarine operational patrols of considerably more than 7 days length.
(11) What redress does the Commonwealth have if, after provisional acceptance, the software crashes after 8 days running.
(12) Will a copy be tabled of: (a) the original submarine contract; and (b) the contract as it presently stands (less national security sensitive operational parameters); if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The original contract delivery date for Submarine 01 was 7 January 1995.

(2) The contract delivery date for Submarine 01 has been amended twice. In September 1994 it was amended by 11 months to 30 November 1995 and this year it was extended by seven months to 8 July 1996. Submarine 01 was delivered on 15 July 1996.

(3) Delivery date of the last submarine (06) has been amended once and is now contracted to be delivered 11 months later than originally planned. Other submarines will have varying delays ranging from the 18 months of 01 to the 11 months of 06.

(4) A wide range of the recommendations from the Auditor‐General's Audit Report No. 22 of 1992‐93 have been implemented in the Submarine project as well as throughout Defence project management. Actions taken by the Department were reviewed by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts when it reviewed the Auditor‐General's report on the new submarine project. Its report (No 337) "A Focus on Accountability" was tabled in June 1995. The Auditor‐General is currently conducting a follow up audit of the new submarine project which will validate that appropriate action has been taken to implement recommendations of the Auditor General's report.
(5) The original approved project cost was A$ 3892 million based on June 1986 prices and exchange rates.
(6) The current approved project cost is A$ 3890 million expressed on the same June 1986 price and exchange basis.

(7) There have been 995 amendments to the contract since contract award. Many of these have been of an administrative nature such as clarifying aspects of the contract, responding to changed industrial conditions and changing price variation indices. About 250 have been engineering changes to better define or correct a contract requirement, or include changes that were sensible to incorporate during construction.

The changes have been a mix of customer and contractor initiated with a significant number being for the mutual benefit of both parties. Incorporation of the changes into the contract has been on a progressive basis.
The variations to the contract price from the amendments has been $12m. Funding has been provided from project contingency included within the original cost approval.

(8) There has been no increase in project costs due to customer‐initiated contract variations. As noted previously, variations to the contract have increased the contract cost by $12m, this being provided from within the approved project cost.
Consumer Price Index inflation, or variations for price escalation using the formulae in the contract has resulted in a price escalation of $1248m.
Exchange rate variation has resulted in a decrease in project costs of $102m.
There has been no increase in contract costs resulting from the delay in the submarines.

Project costs were reduced by $2m to reflect transfer of $2m towards acquisition of HMAS Protector. Protector is the RAN trials ship with a prime task of acting as a safety vessel during initial submarine trials.

(9) HMAS COLLINS was delivered on 15 July 1996 and provisionally accepted by Navy. A requirement for provisional acceptance was that the combat system software run without a system crash for seven days. This was achieved.
(10) RAN operational patrols are of more than seven days duration with the Collins Class submarines being designed for patrols of 70 days.

(11) If the combat system software, or any equipment or system in the submarine, does not meet the contracted requirement the contractor is obliged to rectify the deficiency, without cost to the Commonwealth, under the terms of the warranty. The contract also contains a substantial performance guarantee which the Commonwealth may draw on in the event of contractor default.

Provisional acceptance of the submarine has occurred. Prior to this known deficiencies of the submarine were recorded and responsibility for rectification of contractor responsible deficiencies agreed by the contractor. At this stage the Commonwealth has not accepted the combat system software but has agreed that it is adequate to allow continued and more detailed test and evaluation of the submarine by Navy.

(12) It is not intended to table a copy of either the original submarine contract; or the contract as it now stands. The contract is a commercial‐in‐confidence document between the Australian Submarine Corporation and the Commonwealth.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are HMAS Shoalwater and HMAS Rushcutter primarily used for training and minehunting in contained waters.
(2) Are these vessels too unstable to operate effectively outside confined waters.
(3) On how may occasions has either vessel operated outside Sydney Harbour or its immediate vicinity.
(4) Is the sonar system in each of these vessels still ineffective.
(5) What was the final cost of the project which resulted in the construction of these vessels.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) HMA Ships Rushcutter and Shoalwater , undertake operational minehunting in inshore waters, support training on behalf of the Naval Training Command, and assist with Defence Science and Technology Organisation trials and tactical development.

(2) The Inshore Minehunter (MHI) is designed to conduct operations in ports, focal areas and approaches, in conditions up to Sea State Four. ADF capability to conduct minehunting in conditions beyond Sea State Four will be vested in the Huon Class Minehunter Coastal when it enters service.

(3) MHI operate from Sydney and in the vicinity of Jervis Bay, Port Botany, Port Kembla and Newcastle in the normal course of operations. In addition, the vessels have successfully deployed on at least 38 occasions since 1986 in ports ranging from Adelaide to Darwin. HMAS Rushcutter is currently participating in Exercise Short Scope with other Mine Countermeasure units off Mackay.

(4) The STN Atlas DSQS11M sonar, retrofitted to the MHI performs beyond original MHI design requirements. The DSQS11M, in service with the Republic of Germany Navy, is also the successful contender for the recently announced Royal Thai Navy GAETTA Class Minehunter Coastal acquisition.

(5) The likely final project costs of the MHI project is $130,808 million. There is still future expenditure for the project, which equates to the life of the vessels, that has been accounted for in the total costing, hence a `likely' final project cost.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs: Visit to Jakarta

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Senator Brown

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 21 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the visit to Jakarta in August (actually July) 1996 by the Minister and, in particular, his return trip to Australia.
(1)(a) What was the mode of travel; and
(b) How much did it cost.
(2) What alternatives were available.
(3) Was the Minister offered a lift on the same day by Mr Warren Christopher of the United States of America; if so, was this offer turned down and why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: — The Minister for Foreign Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)(a) Mr Downer travelled to Jakarta on a commercial airline flight and returned to Australia by RAAF Special Purpose Aircraft (SPA).
(b) The cost from Jakarta to Sydney on the 25 July 1996 was $46,810.00, but this cost was partially offset by $22,320.00, being the portion of the party's return tickets to Australia.

(2) The RAAF Special Purpose Aircraft (SPA) was the only viable alternative. Two other options were investigated but were not found to be viable given Mr Downer's responsibilities which required him to stay in Jakarta until after midday on 25 July and to arrive in Sydney to meet commitments associated with the Australia‐United States Ministerial Talks on 26 July 1996.
(3) The Minister was offered a lift on Mr Christopher's flight. Mr Downer was unable to accept Mr Christopher's offer as Mr Christopher's flight left before the completion of Mr Downer's commitments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Senator Cooney

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 25 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Are there any programs for people on disability pensions who have been injured in the work place and who wish to work and educate themselves beyond the year 2000 and where can one seek these programs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: — The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: People receiving disability support pension can seek vocational assistance through the Disability Reform Package (DRP). The DRP provides access to rehabilitation and training opportunities for people receiving disability payments. Programs accessible through the DRP include vocational rehabilitation through the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service (CRS), labour market and training assistance through the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs and assistance by specialist employment services funded under the Disability Services Act.

All customers claiming disability payments, as well as those who have their payments reviewed, are considered for possible assistance by a Disability Support Officer (DSO). A customer receiving a disability payment may also, at any time, ask to meet with a DSO to discuss possible vocational assistance. Customers considered potentially suitable for assistance are invited to an interview with a disability panel, comprised of the DSO and representatives of the CRS and Commonwealth Employment Service (CES), where their requirements and options for assistance are discussed in detail.

Customers receiving disability support pension who are registered as job seeking with the CES may also elect to participate in case management which offers a variety of labour market and training assistance.
